description: In “Bodies on the Line,” Lauren Rankin traces the civilian efforts to protect abortion seekers from those who would stand in their way.
text: BODIES ON THE LINE At the Front Lines of the Fight to Protect Abortion in AmericaBy Lauren Rankin

title: Anti-Abortion Activists Say They Were Allowed to Take 115 Fetuses
description: A medical waste disposal company denied their account. Most of the fetuses were buried in secret, the activists said, but they kept five that were later removed by the police in Washington, D.C.
text: Anti-abortion activists claimed on Tuesday that five fetuses that were removed from an apartment in Washington last week had been in a box containing a total of 115 that the driver of a medical waste truck voluntarily allowed them to take from his dolly outside an abortion clinic.

title: Oklahoma Lawmakers Approve Near-Total Ban on Abortion
description: The measure is part of a wave of stringent abortion restrictions enacted by legislators in Republican-led states.
text: Lawmakers in Oklahoma on Tuesday approved a near-total ban on abortion, making it the latest Republican-led state to forge ahead with stringent abortion legislation as the Supreme Court weighs a case that could overturn Roe v. Wade later this year.

title: Abortion Pills, Once a Workaround, Are Now a Target
description: In advance of a Supreme Court decision, states are proposing new restrictions and heavier criminal penalties on medication abortion.
text: Last year, after Texas passed its strict abortion ban, surgical abortions in the state dropped by half. Many women found a workaround: pills. The week the law took effect, requests for medication abortion shot up to 138 a day from 11 a day at just one service that delivers the pills by mail.

title: Sacramento Shooting Renews Calls for Tighter Gun Legislation
description: California lawmakers are promoting a package of bills, including one modeled after Texas’ controversial abortion ban.
text: Despite its strict gun laws, California is by no means spared from the pains of gun violence.

title: Four Opinion Writers on How the G.O.P. Fringe Took Over American Politics
description: Jamelle Bouie, Ezra Klein and Jane Coaston join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss culture-war legislation, political strategy and sanctions on Russia.
authors: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Ezra Klein, Jane Coaston and Jamelle Bouie
text: Lawmakers in Ohio this week proposed legislation that would restrict discussion of sexual orientation and gender identity in schools, borrowing from Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” law. It’s the latest in a raft of culture-war legislation in Republican statehouses aimed against abortion, transgender rights, L.G.B.T.Q. rights and critical race theory.

title: Idaho Supreme Court Halts 6-Week Abortion Ban Based on Texas’ Law
description: The court says Idaho’s law cannot go into effect this month as scheduled while it reviews legal challenges. The ban prohibits abortions after fetal cardiac activity is detected.
text: The Idaho Supreme Court on Friday temporarily blocked a law modeled after one in Texas that relies on ordinary citizens to enforce a ban on abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy as a way of sidestepping challenges to its constitutionality.

title: Woman in Texas Charged With Murder in Connection With ‘Self-Induced Abortion’
description: Whether the woman had the abortion or was aiding one was unclear.
text: A South Texas sheriff’s official said on Saturday that a 26-year-old woman had been indicted on a murder charge in connection with the “death of an individual through a self-induced abortion.”

title: Texas Will Dismiss Murder Charge Against Woman Connected to ‘Self-Induced Abortion’
description: A district attorney said on Sunday that the woman “cannot and should not” be prosecuted.
authors: By Giulia Heyward and Sophie Kasakove
text: The murder charge against a woman in Texas in connection with a “self-induced abortion” will be dismissed, a Texas district attorney announced Sunday.

title: Maryland Lawmakers Expand Abortion Access, Overriding Governor’s Veto
description: The new law allows trained medical professionals other than physicians to perform abortions and requires insurance providers to cover more costs.
text: Maryland is joining 14 other states in allowing trained medical professionals other than physicians to perform abortions. That change is part of a bill expanding abortion rights that was passed Saturday by state lawmakers, overriding the veto of Gov. Larry Hogan.

title: Yelp Will Pay for Employees to Travel for Abortion Access
description: The company has relatively few workers in Texas, which has the most restrictive abortion law.
authors: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Lauren Hirsch
text: Yelp announced on Tuesday that it would cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, becoming the latest company to respond to a Texas law that bans the procedure after about six weeks of pregnancy.

title: More Companies Take a Stand on Abortion
description: Yelp is the latest to pay for employees to travel out of state for treatment, responding to a recent Texas law that bans abortions after six weeks.
authors: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
text: Yelp, the online search and review platform, is expected to announce today that, beginning next month, it will cover expenses for its employees and their spouses who must travel out of state for abortion care, The Times’s Alisha Haridasani Gupta and DealBook’s Lauren Hirsch report. It is the latest company to respond to the Texas law that bans abortion after about six weeks of pregnancy.

title: What’s Happening With Abortion Legislation in States Across the Country
description: Florida’s governor signed a law banning most abortions after 15 weeks. It is part of a cascade of restrictive abortion legislation in Republican-led states.
text: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has signed into law a ban on most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, severely restricting access to the procedure in a state that has long been a refuge for women from across the South.

title: Fighting the Latest Efforts to Outlaw Abortion
description: Readers discuss moves to ban abortion pills and lament passage of an Oklahoma anti-abortion bill. Also: Saving baseball; sex and manners; Covid vaccines.
text: To the Editor:

title: Underpaid, or Unpaid, College Faculty
description: Readers discuss the plight of adjunct professors and lament the salaries of full-time academics. Also: Macron vs. Le Pen; employers and abortion.
text: To the Editor:

title: These Laws Are Making Miscarriage More Traumatic in America
description: Anti-abortion laws that don’t prioritize women’s health.
text: In December, I wrote a newsletter with the headline, “Overturning Roe Will Make Miscarriage Care Worse.” I pointed out that because the options that doctors have to end a miscarriage that doesn’t happen on its own — medication or surgery — are the same ones involved in an abortion, outlawing abortion would have a chilling effect on medical providers, as evidenced by cases in countries such as Malta and Poland where abortion is severely restricted.

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience in New York City.
text: Alison Leiby has written for late-night topical TV on Comedy Central (“The Opposition With Jordan Klepper,” “The President Show”) as well as for the prestige period series “The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel” on Amazon Prime Video. In between, she has helped Ilana Glazer behind the scenes, punching up scripts for “Broad City” and producing Glazer’s first stand-up special for Amazon. Now Glazer is returning the favor by presenting Leiby’s Off Broadway debut, “Alison Leiby: Oh God, a Show About Abortion.”

title: Oklahoma Legislature Passes 6-Week Abortion Ban Modeled on Texas Law
description: The bill, which says civilians can sue doctors who perform the procedure, would close a door to women who had come to the state for abortions because of restrictive bans elsewhere.
text: The Oklahoma Legislature approved a bill on Thursday prohibiting abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, a ban that could sharply reduce abortion access not only for women in the state but for those who have been crossing its borders to work around increasingly strict anti-abortion laws across the South.

title: Connecticut Moves to Blunt Impact of Other States’ Anti-Abortion Laws
description: The state is among several acting to strengthen abortion rights protections as a Supreme Court ruling that could overturn Roe v. Wade looms.
authors: By Sarah Maslin Nir and Kate Zernike
text: Connecticut lawmakers approved a bill late Friday night that takes direct aim at states that have passed aggressive anti-abortion laws as the country prepares for a Supreme Court ruling this summer that could weaken or overturn the constitutional right to abortion enshrined in Roe v. Wade.

title: What American Mothers Really Need
description: If red-state legislators truly want to limit abortions — legal and illegal — they must create conditions that give women a genuine choice.
text: NASHVILLE — I’ve been watching anti-abortion bills sweep the red states this season, and it occurs to me that the week of Mother’s Day might be a good time for a red-state mother like me to weigh in. I fervently support a woman’s right to choose, but I still spend a lot of time thinking about how Republican legislators could achieve their real goal without also trying to undo settled legal precedent.

title: Why the Supreme Court could overturn Roe v. Wade.
description: The landmark decision that established a constitutional right to an abortion has been contentious since it was made in 1973.
text: A majority of the Supreme Court has privately voted to strike down Roe v. Wade, according to a leaked draft opinion from February that was published by Politico. Here’s a look at the history of the landmark decision and the case from Mississippi now being decided by the court

title: What Would the End of Roe Mean? Key Questions and Answers.
description: Abortion would remain legal in about half of states, but the rest would likely ban it. The number of abortions would probably fall, particularly among poor women in the South and Midwest.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: A leaked Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade describes a United States not seen in half a century, in which the legal status of abortion is entirely up to the states. If the draft, from February and published Monday night by Politico, ends up being similar to the court’s final opinion, expected next month, reproductive rights will be rewritten almost immediately.

title: Demonstrators flock to the Supreme Court after leak of draft decision.
description: The mood outside the court was a mix of anger and mourning, with some demonstrators sitting silently in front of a long line of candles.  Others shouted defiant chants.
text: WASHINGTON — Just hours after reports emerged that a majority of justices had voted to strike down Roe v. Wade and the abortion protections it enshrines, scores of protesters began to assemble outside the Supreme Court, flowing into the area well into the early morning hours on Tuesday.

title: A leaked draft opinion indicated that a seismic shift was imminent.
text: A leaked draft opinion indicating the Supreme Court has voted to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark decision that guaranteed abortion access, sent immediate shock waves throughout the United States, as many Americans braced for a future without reproductive rights that had been established for nearly a half-century.

title: In Europe, Possible Roe Reversal Elicits Concern and Criticism
description: European countries have been moving toward more, not less, abortion access.
text: On Tuesday, news that the United States Supreme Court might overturn Roe v. Wade triggered criticism and concern across Europe, a continent that in recent decades has consistently moved toward freer access to abortion.

title: Roe, on the Edge
description: Roe v. Wade seems to be on the cusp of falling.
text: The Supreme Court has decided to overturn Roe v. Wade and allow states to outlaw abortion, according to a written draft of the justices’ decision obtained by Politico.

title: Quick Facts You Should Know About Roe v. Wade
description: A short history of the landmark case.
text: Nearly 50 years ago, the Supreme Court legalized abortion in the United States with its decision in Roe v. Wade, reshaping the nation’s social and political landscape.

title: Business and Roe v. Wade
description: After a Supreme Court bombshell, companies may find themselves thrust further into the political fray.
authors: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
text: A draft Supreme Court opinion shows that a majority of justices voted in February to overturn Roe v. Wade, the landmark case establishing the right to abortion. The opinion, obtained by Politico, is still subject to change and debate up until its official release, which is expected by this summer. Regardless of the outcome, the draft is likely to have immediate consequences for business, thrusting companies further into the political fray.

title: What a Roe v. Wade Repeal Would Mean for California
description: Abortion access is unlikely to change in California if the landmark law were to be struck down.
authors: By Soumya Karlamangla and Shawn Hubler
text: News that the Supreme Court privately voted to strike down the landmark Roe v. Wade decision reverberated across California on Monday night, eliciting outrage from abortion rights supporters and a sudden effort from top Capitol leaders to enshrine the right to abortion in the State Constitution.

title: Reversing Roe v. Wade: What It Would Mean for Women, and the Court’s Credibility
description: Readers react to news of a leaked draft indicating a likely overturning of the landmark abortion rights decision.
text: To the Editor:

title: Here are key passages from the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion.
description: The wording in the 98-page ruling by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. could still change. As drafted, it shows a majority of the court voted to overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., who wrote the draft opinion for the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, said in it that nothing in the text of the Constitution supports a right to abortion and that the authority to regulate abortion belonged to the states.

title: How companies have handled restrictive abortion laws.
description: A leaked Roe v. Wade draft ruling could raise pressure on business leaders to take a stand.
text: With Roe v. Wade on the verge of being overturned, according to a draft Supreme Court ruling obtained by Politico on Monday night, business leaders are likely to face greater pressure to address the state of abortion access.

title: Supreme Court Roe Reversal Would Jeopardize Other Rights, Biden Says
description: President Biden said the leaked draft of a Supreme Court ruling poised to reverse Roe v. Wade, if finalized, could undermine a range of rights beyond abortion, including same-sex marriage.
text: President Biden said the leaked draft of a Supreme Court ruling poised to reverse Roe v. Wade, if finalized, could undermine a range of rights beyond abortion, including same-sex marriage.

title: Where Abortion Could Be Banned Without Roe v. Wade
description: If the Supreme Court were to end Roe v. Wade, about half of states would be expected to ban abortion quickly or limit it heavily.
authors: By Allison McCann and Taylor Johnston
text: If the Supreme Court were to end Roe v. Wade, about half of states would be expected to ban abortion quickly or limit it heavily.

title: An America Without Roe v. Wade Will Be a Dark Place
description: The coming nightmare of illegal abortion.
text: A 26-year-old Texas woman named Lizelle Herrera was arrested and charged with murder last month after an alleged self-induced abortion. It was only after Herrera spent two days in jail and, amid a national uproar, was released on $500,000 bond that the local district attorney concluded she had committed no crime.

title: Demonstrators Gathered at Supreme Court Lament, and Celebrate, Leaked Draft
description: Armed with megaphones, signs, buttons and at least one letterpress for speedy poster production, groups supporting and opposing abortion rights demonstrated.
authors: By Linda Qiu and Sarahbeth Maney
text: WASHINGTON — Scores of protesters took to the steps in front of the Supreme Court on Tuesday hours after a draft opinion overturning the landmark Roe v. Wade decision leaked. Armed with megaphones, signs, buttons and at least one letterpress for speedy poster production, groups supporting and opposing abortion rights demonstrated and occasionally confronted one another in front of the barricaded court.

title: What is a trigger law? And which states have them?
text: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, it would not outlaw abortion. Instead, states would be able to individually determine the procedure’s legality.

title: ‘I Refuse to Go Backwards’: New York Lawmakers Vow to Protect Abortion Access
description: Democratic leaders said they were working to solidify New York as a safe haven for women seeking reproductive care.
authors: By Karen Zraick and Grace Ashford
text: Democratic leaders in Albany decried the news coming out of the Supreme Court on Tuesday, suggesting they were considering a range of options that would help to enshrine New York as a safe haven for women seeking reproductive care.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing: The End of Roe?
description: Abortion is in jeopardy in the U.S.
text: The U.S. Supreme Court confirmed the authenticity of a leaked draft ruling that would overturn the Roe v. Wade decision, which established a constitutional right to abortion almost 50 years ago.

title: Do You Work at an Abortion Clinic?
description: We’re interested in hearing from people whose work may be directly affected by a Supreme Court reversal of Roe v. Wade.
text: If it becomes final, the Supreme Court’s draft ruling overturning Roe v. Wade that was leaked on Monday will alter the work of many organizations involved in abortion rights. That’s especially true in states that are likely to ban abortion, or where so-called trigger laws will do so automatically.

title: Democrats Vow a Response to Roe’s Demise but Have Few Options
description: With neither the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster of legislation to protect abortion rights nor the 50 votes to pass it, Senate Democrats said they would try anyway.
text: WASHINGTON — With much of the Democratic Party raging over the seemingly imminent end to the almost 50-year-old constitutional right to an abortion, Senator Chuck Schumer of New York vowed on Tuesday to bring legislation to a vote that would codify a woman’s right to end her pregnancy.

title: For Conservative Legal Movement, a Long-Sought Triumph Appears at Hand
description: For half a century, right-wing legal thinkers have been working toward the moment foretold by a leaked draft of a Supreme Court opinion.
text: WASHINGTON — In May 1987, Attorney General Edwin Meese III traveled to St. Louis and spoke before a group of clergy members opposed to abortion. Denouncing Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court’s 1973 ruling on abortion rights, he told them that he saw reason to hope that “in our lifetimes” it would be thrown on “the ash heap of legal history.”

title: Roe’s Fall Would Alter Political Battle Lines. But in What Way?
description: Democrats hope abortion rights will motivate the party’s base. Republican strategists are skeptical, though they are privately unsure how the issue might affect the midterms.
text: Democrats who were privately hoping for a surprise development to shake up the midterms have gotten their wish. Nobody expected it to come in the form of a leaked draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, however.

title: Overnight, Midterms Get a White-Hot New Focus: Abortion
description: Exultant Republicans planned new bans. Democrats, who have struggled to rally around abortion rights, hoped a bruising Supreme Court loss could jolt their voters into action.
authors: By Katie Glueck and Reid J. Epstein
text: A leaked draft of a Supreme Court ruling overturning Roe v. Wade instantly propelled the debate over abortion into the white-hot center of American politics, emboldening Republicans across the country and leaving Democrats scrambling to jolt their voters into action six months before the midterm elections.

title: The Leaked Draft Opinion on Roe Draws on Familiar Arguments
description: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. argued two basic points: The Constitution is silent on the question of abortion and Roe’s flaws make it unworthy of respect as precedent.
text: WASHINGTON — The draft Supreme Court opinion overruling Roe v. Wade is a sort of white paper prepared by the conservative legal movement long ago, awaiting only the arrival of a conservative majority ready to adopt it.

title: Hochul Says New York Will Fight for Abortion Rights
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul denounced the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade and vowed that New York State would continue providing reproductive care.
authors: By Governor Kathy Hochul Via Youtube
text: Gov. Kathy Hochul denounced the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade and vowed that New York State would continue providing reproductive care.

title: Protesters Gather in Manhattan in Support of Roe
description: With the Supreme Court slated to strike down Roe v. Wade, demonstrators in New York City, as well as Gov. Kathy Hochul in Albany, rallied in support of abortion rights.
authors: By Lola Fadulu, Téa Kvetenadze and Sadef Ali Kully
text: More than a thousand demonstrators gathered at Foley Square in Lower Manhattan on Tuesday evening to protest the possibility of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, which has guaranteed the right to abortion for nearly half a century.

title: Rising Anxiety and Increased Demand at America’s Imperiled Abortion Clinics
description: On Tuesday, it was business as usual. But abortion providers, many of whom anticipated being shut down, worried about the future health and safety of their patients.
authors: By Rick Rojas, Sophie Kasakove and J. David Goodman
text: On the calendar at Jackson Women’s Health Organization on Tuesday, every appointment slot was filled. Patients drove in from across Mississippi, as well as from Louisiana, Tennessee and as far away as Texas, taking the long trip to obtain an abortion from a clinic that now seemed doomed.

title: Leaked Threat to Roe v. Wade Stuns, Then Energizes Americans
description: Supporters and opponents of abortion rights were anticipating a Supreme Court decision this summer, but the sudden release of a draft opinion set off a wave of impromptu protests.
authors: By Kate Zernike, Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
text: Opponents and supporters of abortion rights had expected for months that the Supreme Court would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade, but the leaked draft opinion late Monday came as if out of the blue, setting off shock, outrage and jubilation on both sides of the nation’s deeply polarized abortion debate.

title: Oklahoma bans abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy.
description: Gov. Kevin Stitt signed the Oklahoma Heartbeat Act, modeled on the law restricting abortions that came into effect in Texas last year.
text: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma on Tuesday signed a bill prohibiting abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy, the latest attempt by Republican lawmakers in the state to find legal avenues to ban abortions that will withstand judicial challenges.

title: Abortion Rights Demonstrators Rally in U.S. Cities
description: Thousands of protesters took to the streets after a leaked draft decision showed a majority of Supreme Court justices would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: Thousands of protesters took to the streets after a leaked draft decision showed a majority of Supreme Court justices would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Shockwaves from a Supreme Court leak.
text: The Supreme Court confirmed that a leaked draft ruling to overturn the landmark Roe v. Wade decision on abortion rights was authentic, but said it was not final. The disclosure triggered protests outside the court, as well as political upheaval with potentially broad electoral and legal consequences. Here’s a guide to the Mississippi law at the center of the decision.

title: Is This How Roe Ends?
description: A leaked draft opinion from the Supreme Court suggested that it was preparing to overturn the constitutional right to abortion.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Rob Szypko, Chelsea Daniel, Anita Badejo, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
text: The revelation that the Supreme Court could end the constitutional right to abortion in the United States has set off a political firestorm and deepened divisions about one of the most contentious issues in American society.

title: Which states are reinforcing abortion rights?
description: Several states have already taken steps to protect abortion rights, and many are taking additional measures in anticipation of the Supreme Court ruling.
text: Out of 50 states, there are 13 that have passed so-called trigger laws that would outlaw abortion if the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade. But what’s happening in states that do not have a trigger law?

title: Abortion Is a Business Issue
description: Women make up half of the work force, but the issue’s divisiveness has led many companies to keep quiet on the issue for now.
authors: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
text: After a Supreme Court draft ruling showed that Roe v. Wade may be overturned, many of America’s corporate leaders reacted with silence. Abortion is a business issue: Women make up more than half of the work force, and those who were unable to get abortions were less likely to be employed full time six months after denial of care, according to a 2018 paper.

title: Roe Inspired Activists Worldwide, Who May Be Rethinking Strategy
description: Feminist movements in some countries similarly sought abortion protections in their courts, but for others, the goal was legislative change.
text: The draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade that leaked Monday night is not yet final. But when the dust settles, American women may conclude that they had lost the right to abortion the same way that an Ernest Hemingway character said he had gone bankrupt: gradually, and then suddenly.

title: What is a trigger law? And which states have them?
description: More than a dozen states have implemented legislation that would outlaw or severely restrict abortions, on the assumption that the Supreme Court will overturn Roe v. Wade this summer.
text: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, it would not outlaw abortion. Instead, states would be able to individually determine the procedure’s legality.

title: Do Americans Support Abortion Rights? Depends on the State.
description: Polling suggests an overturning of Roe v. Wade might not carry political consequences in states that would be likeliest to put in restrictions.
text: A majority of Americans believe that abortion should be legal in all or most cases. But the story is more complicated in the states where the future of abortion policy is likely to be decided if — as is now expected — the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade.

title: In France, a Film Has Women Sharing Their Stories of Abortion
description: Following the release of “Happening,” about an illegal abortion in 1963, the country’s contemporary stigma around the procedure is facing scrutiny.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: The Mississippi clinic at the center of the Supreme Court case is still open.
description: Jackson Women’s Health has seen an increase in patients, many from states like Texas and Louisiana that have restricted access to abortions.
text: The morning after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion in a case concerning Mississippi’s only abortion provider, ​​Derenda Hancock arrived at the clinic around sunrise, just as she does most days, to lead a group of volunteers escorting patients. Wednesday morning, the group was back to do it again.

title: Imagining a Post-Roe America: ‘I Am Scared’
description: A 22-year-old woman fears losing control over her body, and an 80-year-old recalls her illegal abortion. Also: Russian oligarchs’ property; Pelosi in Kyiv.
text: To the Editor:

title: The Fight Over Abortion History
description: The leaked draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade also takes aim at its version of history, challenging decades of scholarship that argues abortion was not always a crime.
text: History, and arguments about history, have long been central to abortion jurisprudence.

title: Corporate America Doesn’t Want to Talk Abortion, but It May Have To
description: In a deeply divided nation, public statements on Roe v. Wade can affect everything from recruiting to a company’s bottom line. So far, that has kept almost everyone quiet.
authors: By Emma Goldberg, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Lauren Hirsch
text: Some political and cultural events set off a cascade of emails from brands — sneaker, makeup and food companies telling their customers that they stand with them in a stressful time, or reminding them to vote. But after a draft opinion obtained by Politico revealed the Supreme Court’s intention to overturn Roe v. Wade, the overwhelming reaction from corporate leaders was silence.

title: As Leak Theories Circulate, Supreme Court Marshal Takes Up Investigation
description: Not since Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein refused for decades to disclose the identity of their Watergate source has Washington been as eager to unmask a leaker.
authors: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
text: WASHINGTON — Maybe it was a liberal law clerk who leaked the draft opinion in the Supreme Court’s biggest case in years, hoping to gin up outrage among Democrats at the prospect of an end to legal abortions.

title: Once Close Allies, Roberts and Alito Have Taken Divergent Paths
description: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. have become emblems of a stark divide at the Supreme Court as it confronts whether to overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: WASHINGTON — There was a time when Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., the author of the leaked draft opinion on abortion that rocked the nation on Monday night, was Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.’s closest ally on the Supreme Court.

title: Schumer Says Senate Will Vote on Federal Abortion Rights Bill
description: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York said that Senate Democrats would bring legislation codifying the right to an abortion to the floor for a vote, though the party lacks the support necessary to pass it.
text: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York said that Senate Democrats would bring legislation codifying the right to an abortion to the floor for a vote, though the party lacks the support necessary to pass it.

title: ‘I Can’t Have This Baby’: A Lone Abortion Clinic on the Border
description: In the Rio Grande Valley, women seeking abortions navigate the complex challenges of religion, culture and a new Texas law.
text: McALLEN, Texas — The colorful murals outside the storefront clinic a few miles from the Mexican border celebrated “dignity, empowerment, compassion, justice.” Inside, there was a reminder posted on the wall for anyone who had begun to doubt it: “Abortion Is Legal in Texas!”

title: Seth Meyers Is Tired of Republicans’ Playing the Victim
description: “Do all these pundits whining about the leak really think this is what will shatter the integrity of the court?” Meyers said of the disclosure of a draft ruling from the Supreme Court overturning abortion rights.
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: With Roe Under Threat, Biden Is an Unlikely Abortion Rights Champion
description: Over the course of a half-century in national politics, President Biden has evolved from an outright critic of Roe to a seemingly reluctant and largely quiet supporter.
text: WASHINGTON — When abortion rights supporters protested outside the Supreme Court this week after the leak of a draft decision overturning Roe v. Wade, they turned their ire at one point toward the same president who just hours earlier denounced the possible ruling just as they were doing.

title: The ‘Frighteningly Autocratic’ Implications of Overturning Roe v. Wade
description: The abortion rights advocate Nancy Northup discusses Justice Alito’s leaked draft opinion and an America without guaranteed abortion rights.
text: Justice Samuel Alito’s leaked draft opinion has offered a chilling preview into what America will look like if Roe v. Wade is overturned. But the president and C.E.O. of the Center for Reproductive Rights, Nancy Northup, has been preparing for this battle. Her organization represents the Mississippi abortion clinic whose legal battle sparked the Supreme Court case, and Northup’s colleagues argued the case in front of the Supreme Court in December. “We are not waking up today to realize this was a threat,” she says. “We were looking at it back in 2004, and probably half the states in the United States would ban or severely limit abortion if Roe were overturned.”

title: Ten Books to Understand the Abortion Debate in the United States
description: Nearly 50 years ago, the Supreme Court legalized abortion. The decision has since divided the country. Now that the issue is before the court again, here are 10 books that help frame the debate.
text: As the Supreme Court reconsiders Roe v. Wade months shy of its 50th anniversary, and likely prepares to overturn it, according to a leaked draft opinion, it is worth pondering how the ruling that established the constitutional right to abortion came to divide our country.

title: Beware the Feminism of Justice Alito
description: Women apparently have advanced so far, they no longer need guaranteed access to abortion.
text: In Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade, perhaps what’s hardest to bear for abortion rights advocates is the implicit suggestion that the progress women have made is a reason to throw out Roe. In a sense, he turns feminism against itself.

title: As the Supreme Court Weighs Roe v. Wade, These Novels Offer Perspective
description: Fiction that grapples with abortion, fertility, motherhood and reproductive rights illuminates the debate from different viewpoints.
text: Haigh’s timely seventh novel centers on a Boston women’s clinic where readers get to know patients, counselors, demonstrators and volunteers — and have a chance to consider abortion from each perspective. “It would be a terrible mistake to give it a miss because of its hot-button topic,” wrote our reviewer, Richard Russo. “Why? Because, far from being depressing, the book is wonderfully entertaining, boasting a large, varied cast of vividly drawn characters whose company readers will find deeply rewarding, in no small part because lurking in their shadows is the devastatingly wry humor of their creator.”

title: Abortion Pills Stand to Become the Next Battleground in a Post-Roe America
description: Medication abortion allows patients to terminate early pregnancies at home. Some states are moving to limit it, while others are working to expand access.
authors: By Pam Belluck and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
text: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, the legal and culture wars over abortion that have consumed the United States for decades would increasingly shift to a new front: the use of abortion pills.

title: A Post-Roe Map of America
description: Where in the United States would access to abortion be assured, and where would it be in jeopardy?
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Eric Krupke, Stella Tan, M.J. Davis Lin, John Ketchum, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
text: If the Supreme Court revokes Roe v. Wade, individual states will probably be left to make their own decisions about abortion provision.

title: Democrats Aim to Use Abortion Rights to Jolt State Legislative Races
description: A party group has circled a handful of states where Democrats hope to hold or flip control. The draft ruling on Roe v. Wade “has the potential to be a game-changing issue,” its leader said.
text: WASHINGTON — A draft Supreme Court opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade has jolted the battle for control of state legislatures, where the next stage of the struggle over abortion rights is likely to play out.

title: Performing a Comedy About Abortion, Watching the Supreme Court
description: Alison Leiby had just performed her show “Oh God, a Show About Abortion” when she learned of the leaked draft opinion showing that the court could be on the verge of overturning Roe v. Wade.
text: After finishing a preview performance of her hourlong stand-up show about reproductive rights, “Oh God, a Show About Abortion,” the comedian Alison Leiby was finishing dinner Monday night when she checked her phone.

title: ‘Happening’ Review: An Abortion Story, an Existential Drama
description: In this powerful French movie set in the early 1960s, a young woman struggles to obtain an abortion when the procedure was criminalized.
text: Her body, her choice, her life. That’s the unambiguous refrain that runs through “Happening,” a powerful French drama about a woman seeking an abortion. Set in the early 1960s, when the procedure was criminalized in France, it arrives in the United States at a fraught moment, with the Supreme Court seemingly poised to overturn Roe v. Wade. When I first saw the movie, it felt like a warning shot from a still-distant land. Now it feels urgently of the moment.

title: Democrats Plan a Bid to Codify Roe, but Lack the Votes to Succeed
description: In announcing a Wednesday vote on doomed legislation to enshrine abortion rights into federal law, the top Senate Democrat teed up a political fight for the midterm campaign.
text: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.

title: In Ireland, Abortion Rights Activists Oppose a Hospital Deal
description: The government delayed a decision on the proposal, amid concerns that a private charity might follow Catholic doctrine and limit abortions at a state-funded maternity hospital.
text: DUBLIN — The Irish government has postponed a decision on a plan to give control of a proposed $840 million state-funded maternity hospital to a charity set up by an order of Catholic nuns. Abortion rights activists and opposition politicians are fighting the plan, saying they fear the charity might apply Catholic doctrine on abortion and other matters in the running of the hospital.

title: Justice Alito’s Invisible Women
description: He would erase the right to abortion without acknowledging the impact on women and on the constitutional understanding of sex equality.
text: Yes, the leak of the draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade was a shock. And it was shocking to read Justice Samuel Alito’s airy dismissal of a decision the Supreme Court has reaffirmed numerous times in the past 49 years as “egregiously wrong from the start.” That was on Page 6 of the draft opinion that Politico published last Monday, and Justice Alito spent the next 61 pages explaining why, in his view and perhaps ultimately in the view of four other justices, the court needs to overturn Roe now.

title: Democrats Announce Vote to Guarantee Abortion Rights
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic majority leader, said he planned to bring up a bill that would codify abortion rights into federal law, despite clear evidence that the measure lacks the support to be enacted.
text: Senator Chuck Schumer, the Democratic majority leader, said he planned to bring up a bill that would codify abortion rights into federal law, despite clear evidence that the measure lacks the support to be enacted.

title: Weekly Health Quiz: Abortion, Cigarette Bans and Weight Loss Drugs
description: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
text: Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

title: Draft Opinion Overturning Roe Raises a Question: Are More Precedents Next?
description: The legal reasoning that the Supreme Court’s conservative bloc is considering to end abortion rights could uproot a series of other past rulings that created modern rights.
text: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.

title: Texas Governor Ready to Challenge Schooling of Migrant Children
description: Gov. Greg Abbott may target a 1982 Supreme Court ruling that requires schools to educate undocumented children. Some conservatives see an opening for a fresh look at old precedents.
text: HOUSTON — With the Supreme Court signaling a willingness to reverse decades-old precedents like the Roe v. Wade decision on abortion, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said on Thursday that he would seek to overturn a 1982 court decision that obligated public schools to educate all children, including undocumented immigrants.

title: Bill Classifying Abortion as Homicide Is Advanced by Louisiana Lawmakers
description: The proposal threatens to prosecute women who end a pregnancy, a possible new frontier in the abortion debate as the Supreme Court appears inclined to overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: The State Legislature in Louisiana advanced a proposal this week that would classify abortion as homicide, going further than anti-abortion measures in other states by making it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy.

title: Why I Learned to Perform Second-Trimester Abortions for a Post-Roe America
description: On training to provide second-trimester procedures.
text: For almost a decade as a family doctor in California, I have provided first-trimester abortions and trained family medicine residents to do the same.

title: The Death of Roe Is Going to Tear America Apart
description: You think we hate each other now? Just wait.
text: In his draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, Justice Samuel Alito blamed that 1973 abortion decision for sparking “a national controversy that has embittered our political culture for a half century.” He quoted Justice Antonin Scalia: “Roe fanned into life an issue that has inflamed our national politics in general, and has obscured with its smoke the selection of justices to this court in particular, ever since.”

title: She Ran an Abortion Clinic Before Roe v. Wade. She Has Some Thoughts.
description: Merle Hoffman was on the front lines in the early 1970s, when women would travel to New York for abortions.
text: In 1970, three years before the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade, four states, New York among them, repealed their anti-abortion statutes. At the time, Merle Hoffman was a concert pianist who had recently given up her professional ambitions. The world of classical music was too hermetic, but the sweeping political currents of the ’60s had not drawn her in either. She settled on graduate school in psychology, supporting herself with three jobs, one of them in the office of a doctor who wanted to open an abortion clinic and asked her to run it.

title: Why Republicans Are So Angry About the Supreme Court Leak
description: Whatever legitimacy the court had retained was sacrificed in the drive to build the majority that seems poised to overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: The country is divided. There are those Americans furious that the Supreme Court is soon to take away the right to have an abortion. And there are those Americans furious that someone leaked that the Supreme Court was soon to take away the right to have an abortion.

title: A Post-Roe America, Part 1: The Anti-Abortion Activists
description: What next for a movement that looks to have achieved a decades-long goal?
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Jessica Cheung, Michael Simon Johnson, Clare Toeniskoetter, Liz O. Baylen, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
text: Since the leak of the Supreme Court draft opinion on overturning the constitutional right to abortion, both sides of the fight have been scrambling.

title: Abortion is already starting to reshape these notable midterm campaigns.
description: In Pennsylvania, Georgia and beyond, the prospective fall of Roe v. Wade hangs over key primary and general elections.
text: There was never any doubt that an impending Supreme Court decision on abortion, expected over the summer, would have an outsize effect on the midterm campaigns this year. The issue just wasn’t expected to upend the races so soon.

title: The Abortion Case: A ‘Spurious’ Argument and ‘Clear Bias’
description: Readers raise questions about the constitutional reasoning and Catholic influence in the leaked draft ruling. Also: Preventing addiction; access to parks.
text: To the Editor:

title: Tesla will cover transportation costs for employee abortions.
description: The company recently moved to Texas, which is home to some of the country’s most restrictive abortion laws.
authors: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Lauren Hirsch
text: Tesla is covering transportation costs for employees to get out-of-state abortions, joining the likes of Citigroup and Yelp as various state regulations have limited access to abortion.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Recast Abortion Stance, Wary of Voter Backlash
description: While Democrats decry a draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion, Republicans who worked decades for this moment have been largely silent.
text: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.

title: Roe’s Potential End Forces Politicians Into a Deeper Abortion Debate
description: Republicans face new pressure to define exactly where they stand on the hot-button issue, while Democrats must now fully confront a topic many have approached carefully.
text: The precedent of Roe v. Wade has often offered a shield to politicians in both parties when it comes to discussing abortion, allowing them to take up their preferred label — “pro-choice” or “pro-life” — without wading into the details.

title: Battle Over Abortion Threatens to Deepen America’s Divide
description: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, all 50 states will be free to set their own rules, leading to one America where access to an abortion is guaranteed and another where it is outlawed.
text: WASHINGTON — For years, the United States has been drifting further apart, less a single country than an uncomfortable marriage of vastly disparate cultural and political entities, a Red America and a Blue America with starkly different realities on masks and vaccines, gun rights and voting rights, Donald J. Trump and the legitimacy of the 2020 election.

title: For South Texas Democrats, an Intraparty Test of Abortion Politics
description: A staunchly anti-abortion Democrat in Congress will face a young abortion-rights supporter in a pivotal primary runoff.
authors: By James Dobbins, Jennifer Medina and Katie Glueck
text: Follow our live updates on the midterm primary elections.

title: Half of U.S. Women Risk Losing Abortion Access Without Roe
description: Many of the millions of women who live in these states would be able to seek legal abortions elsewhere, but the barriers to access may be hard for some to overcome.
authors: By Weiyi Cai, Taylor Johnston, Allison McCann and Amy Schoenfeld Walker
text: Many of the millions of women who live in these states would be able to seek legal abortions elsewhere, but the barriers to access may be hard for some to overcome.

title: How Roe Shaped the World of Work for Women
description: Many factors drove women into the work force in greater numbers in the 1970s. Scholars argue that abortion access was an important one.
text: When Barbara Schwartz looks back at her younger days working as a Broadway stagehand, she remembers the electricity of it: the harried dancers slipping into their costumes backstage, the props people shoving past with flashlights between their teeth.

title: The Story of Roe v. Wade, Part 1: Who Was Jane Roe? (From the Archive)
description: How abortion became one of the most politically divisive issues of our time. (From 2018)
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Lynsea Garrison, Lisa Tobin, Paige Cowett, Chris Wood and Dan Powell
text: This week, the release of a draft Supreme Court opinion striking down Roe v. Wade has put a spotlight on the 50-year-old case that redefined abortion in America.

title: The Story of Roe v. Wade, Part 2: The Culture Wars (From the Archive)
description: After abortion was legalized, two powerful movements took opposing sides and forged a new political landscape. (From 2018)
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Lynsea Garrison, Lisa Tobin, Paige Cowett, Chris Wood and Dan Powell
text: Today, we revisit a two-part series that first ran in 2018 about the history of Roe v. Wade and the woman behind it.

title: How Will We Punish the Women Who Have Abortions?
description: We can’t pretend that making it a criminal act won’t have consequences.
text: In 2007 the conservative magazine National Review hosted an online symposium in response to a column by Anna Quindlen in Newsweek titled “How Much Jail Time for Women Who Have Abortions?” She argued that anti-abortion activists were dodging the reality that overturning Roe v. Wade would bring. If abortion became a crime in the United States, she wrote, those attempting to enforce such a law would have only two choices: “Hold women accountable for a criminal act by sending them to prison, or refuse to criminalize the act in the first place. If you can’t countenance the first,” she wrote, “you have to accept the second. You can’t have it both ways.”

title: How Conservatives Can Love ‘the Family’ and ‘the Free Market’
description: It is easier to reconcile than you might think.
text: We are witnessing, right now, a flurry of attacks on the freedom of Americans to live as they choose. Conservatives have renewed their war against L.G.B.T.Q. inclusion and are poised to excise the right to have an abortion from our constitutional order. At the same time, they have continued to fight against public goods and what’s left of the welfare state, slashing spending and cutting taxes in states where they have control.

title: The Pro-Family Agenda Republicans Should Embrace After Roe
description: The movement that describes itself as pro-life must encompass a broader vision of policy than just prohibiting access to abortion.
text: The leak of Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization allows social conservatives a glimpse into a post-Roe future. If his draft ends up the majority opinion, those who marched and prayed and rallied and voted for half a century to recognize in law the value of every human life will soon be celebrating — and rightly so.

title: Where Does the Anti-Abortion Movement Go After Roe?
description: The Supreme Court draft opinion signals a new era for the 50-year effort to end the constitutional right to abortion. Next goals include a national ban and, in some cases, classifying abortion as homicide.
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
text: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.

title: How Roe Warped the Republic
description: Why Roe v. Wade may be overturned by the very forces of polarization it unleashed.
text: In one sense, liberal outrage at the prospect of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade seems like an uneasy fit with liberalism’s current master narrative, which holds that liberals are defending democracy against the threat of authoritarianism and fighting for the principle of majority rule against a Republican Party that benefits from counter-majoritarian power. After all, overturning Roe would return the abortion issue to the democratic process, after two generations in which abortion policy has been set by a juristocracy, an elites-only vote of 7 to 2 or 5 to 4.

title: Weekend of Abortion Protests Brings Out Supporters
description: Rallies in Houston and Chicago were among numerous events planned across the country.
authors: By Maria Jimenez Moya, Scott Atkinson, Robert Chiarito and Lola Fadulu
text: HOUSTON — Several thousand people in Texas’ largest city rallied for abortion rights on Saturday, one of numerous demonstrations held across the country days after a draft opinion from the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade was leaked. They were joined by a host of Democratic officials, including former Representative Beto O’Rourke, who is running for governor.

title: ‘S.N.L.’ Imagines the Origins of Abortion Law
description: On an episode hosted by Benedict Cumberbatch, “Saturday Night Live” contemplated the possibility that the Supreme Court could overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: “Saturday Night Live” dug deep for its opening sketch this weekend, far into the text of a leaked draft opinion indicating that the Supreme Court has voted to overturn the Roe v. Wade decision, at the section where the draft opinion’s author, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., cites legal theory from 13th century England.

title: A Leak That Slowed, but Did Not Stop, the Presses
description: Here’s how the Times report on the leaked Supreme Court draft opinion to overturn Roe v. Wade came together — and made it into print.
text: On Monday night, an alert popped into a New York Times internal messaging channel: A draft United States Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade and end federal protection of abortion rights had been leaked and published. A court leak was an incredibly rare event and, if the document was confirmed as authentic, the decision would reshape women’s access to abortion in many states and send a shock through U.S. politics.

title: Midterms’ Biggest Abortion Battleground: Pennsylvania
description: The leading Republicans running for governor in the state want to outlaw abortion. The presumptive Democratic nominee promises to veto any ban.
text: Follow our live updates on primary elections and results in Pennsylvania.

title: If Roe Falls, Is Same-Sex Marriage Next?
description: The leaked draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to abortion sent mixed signals about what other precedents might be at risk.
text: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court heard arguments in December over the fate of the constitutional right to abortion, it was already clear that other rights, notably including same-sex marriage, could be at risk if the court overruled Roe v. Wade.

title: Senate Democrats Warn of G.O.P. Effort to Restrict Abortion Nationwide
description: The alarms came after Senator Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, called such a ban “possible” if a leaked Supreme Court opinion became final and his party gained control in Washington.
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats rang alarm bells on Sunday about the likelihood that Republicans would try to restrict abortion nationwide, two days after an interview was published in which Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader, said a ban was “possible” if his party gained control in Washington.

title: Anti-Abortion Group in Wisconsin Is Hit by Arson, Authorities Say
description: A Molotov cocktail was used against Wisconsin Family Action in Madison and did not ignite, but another fire was set, the police said.
authors: By Luke Vander Ploeg and Addison Lathers
text: The headquarters of an anti-abortion group in Madison, Wis., was set on fire on Sunday morning in an act of vandalism that included the attempted use of a Molotov cocktail and graffiti that read “If abortions aren’t safe then you aren’t either,” according to the police.

title: I’m a Pro-Choice Governor, and I’m Not Going to Sit on My Hands Waiting for Congress
description: A novel Michigan lawsuit will attempt to continue to make abortion available.
text: As I read the U.S. Supreme Court’s draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, I was devastated. It was shocking to see, laid out in cold legalese, the blatant ideological reasoning gutting the constitutional right to abortion.

title: Medication Abortions Are Increasing: What They Are and Where Women Get Them
description: Most abortions overseas involve pills, and the method is used in about half of legal U.S. abortions. It also seems to be the future of illicit abortion.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: Taking pills to end a pregnancy accounts for a growing share of abortions in the United States, both legal and not. If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade as expected, medication abortion will play a larger role, especially among women who lose access to abortion clinics.

title: New York Lawmakers Push for Abortion Fund to Establish ‘Safe Harbor’
description: Lawmakers in Albany are considering a range of options to expand abortion rights in New York, as many other states prepare to restrict them.
text: Even before the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973, establishing a constitutional right to abortion across the country, New York was a destination for women seeking the procedure.

title: Corrections: May 10, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, May 10, 2022.
text: An article on Saturday about Republican lawmakers’ silence concerning a draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion misstated the method by which morning-after pills prevent pregnancy. They prevent ovulation, not implantation.

title: Overturning Roe Will Disrupt a Lot More Than Abortion. I Can Live With That.
description: There may be radical consequences beyond the hundreds of thousands of additional babies born.
text: For years I have noticed a persistent inclination among my fellow opponents of abortion. Perhaps without meaning to do so, they downplay the possibility that the end of legal abortion will entail anything except the eradication of a great evil.

title: Loss of access to legal abortion would ‘set women back decades,’ Yellen says.
description: Restrictions would damage their economic prospects, the nation’s first female treasury secretary said in a Senate hearing.
text: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Tuesday that the loss of access to legal abortions would damage the United States economy and deal a blow to the financial well-being of women.

title: How Are Abortion Restrictions Affecting Medical Training? Tell Us.
description: The potential for limits on abortion, including a procedure that is used to treat uterine conditions other than pregnancy, will affect providers as well as patients.
text: With at least 22 states poised to drastically limit or end abortion procedures if Roe v. Wade is overturned, how will the training of doctors, nurse practitioners and physician assistants be affected?

title: The Movement That Put Alito on the Court Isn’t Finished
description: No one wages a generational battle to reshape American society for the sake of a partial victory.
text: The right-wing attack on abortion will not end with abortion.

title: Here’s How Democrats in Congress Are Trying to Protect Abortion Rights
description: Under legislation that is all but certain to fail on a test vote this week, abortion rights would be protected and a wide array of limits and bans would be barred.
text: Follow live updates as the Senate votes on abortion rights.

title: How Democrats Want to Put Republicans on the Defensive on Abortion
description: While conservatives control the courts and key states, the public tends to lean in favor of abortion rights. Democratic leaders are trying to translate that sentiment into victories for the party.
text: In politics, sometimes you need to lose in order to win.

title: If There’s a Loud Fight About Roe, ‘Centrist America Will Just Turn Down the Volume’
description: What a reversal of Roe v. Wade might mean at the ballot box.
text: Abortion, it almost goes without saying, is a singularly fraught issue. Pew Research describes the complexity in a May 6 report, “America’s Abortion Quandary”: “A majority of Americans say abortion should be legal in all or most cases, but many are open to restrictions; many opponents of legal abortion say it should be legal in some circumstances.”

title: A Post-Roe America, Part 2: The Abortion Providers
description: People working in abortion clinics describe the likely effects on patients if the constitutional right to a termination is struck down.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Diana Nguyen, Jessica Cheung, Rob Szypko, Paige Cowett, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
text: This episode contains descriptions of sexual violence.

title: Bill to Guarantee Abortion Rights Fails in Senate
description: Republicans used a filibuster to thwart the bill, but Democrats hoped the high-profile failure of their legislation would help them at the polls in November.
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats tried and failed on Wednesday to push forward legislation to guarantee abortion rights nationwide, as Republicans and one Democrat in the Senate blocked an effort to enshrine the landmark Roe v. Wade precedent in federal law.

title: Assessing the Claims in the Alito Draft Opinion Overturning Roe
description: In the leaked draft, Justice Samuel Alito made assertions about fetal development, abortion procedures and international laws that were disputed or omitted context.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Comic or Graphic, Shows About Abortion Surface a Stark Divide
description: Decidedly anti-sensationalistic, Alison Leiby’s shrewd and funny personal monologue plays downtown. Uptown, a staged reading focuses on a gruesome case.
text: A few nights after the leak of the Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn the right to abortion protected by Roe v. Wade, the comedian Alison Leiby walked onto the stage of the Cherry Lane Theater, in Manhattan’s West Village, to greet the audience before her monologue.

title: Why the Justice Department Is Unlikely to Investigate the Supreme Court Leak
description: The internal inquiry led by the court’s marshal has limited tools, but there are challenges to opening a criminal investigation.
text: WASHINGTON — After a leak of a draft opinion showed that the Supreme Court was poised to end women’s constitutional right to abortion, some Republicans and conservative commentators called for a criminal investigation.

title: Louisiana’s governor says he opposes a bill to classify abortion as homicide.
description: Gov. John Bel Edwards said he would veto legislation that, if passed, would make it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy.
text: Gov. John Bel Edwards of Louisiana signaled his opposition on Wednesday to pending legislation that would classify abortion as homicide and make it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy.

title: ‘1973’ Merch: How a Year Became Shorthand for Abortion Rights
description: On “S.N.L.” or at rallies, gear with the date signals support for Roe v. Wade.
text: The story of the women’s movement during the Trump era cannot be told without clothing: There was the knitted pussy hat, the white suffragist suit, the “Future Is Female” T-shirt and the Lingua Franca sweater, all of which now fall somewhere between important cultural artifact and mockable meme, depending on who you’re talking to.

title: How abortion is already animating the Senate race in Georgia.
description: Raphael Warnock is one of the most vulnerable Democrats in the coming midterm elections.
text: ATLANTA — Democrats are painting a future with limited abortion access as a Republican-manufactured problem, underlined by the Senate’s failure to advance a bill to codify the terms of Roe v. Wade.

title: Don’t Be Fooled. It’s All About Women and Sex.
description: What’s the difference between a woman and a sea turtle? The Senate wants to know.
text: When I was back in high school — a Catholic girls’ school in Cincinnati at the beginning of the sexual revolution — our religion class covered the abortion issue in approximately 45 seconds.

title: Newsom Offers Tax Breaks for Companies in Anti-Abortion States
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom’s plan to attract Texas and Florida businesses punctuates the battle between liberal and conservative states after a leaked Supreme Court draft opinion.
text: SACRAMENTO — Underscoring the nation’s widening divide as the U.S. Supreme Court seems poised to overturn the constitutional right to abortion, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Wednesday proposed a series of tax incentives explicitly aimed at recruiting employers from states that restrict reproductive and L.G.B.T.Q. rights.

title: Pregnant? Need Help? They Have an Agenda.
description: If Roe v. Wade is overturned, more than half of American women of reproductive age will live closer to a crisis pregnancy center than to an abortion facility.
authors: By Carly Thomsen, Carrie N. Baker and Zach Levitt
text: If Roe v. Wade is overturned, more than half of American women of reproductive age will live closer to a crisis pregnancy center than to an abortion facility.

title: Who Will Seek Abortions in California if Roe Falls?
description: The state is preparing for an influx of patients.
text: In anticipation of Roe v. Wade being overturned and abortion quickly becoming illegal in at least a dozen states, California is gearing up to become the nation’s abortion provider.

title: What’s the Best Way to Treat Addiction?
description: Readers discuss whether forced treatment is effective. Also: Republicans and abortion; Supreme Court decline; caution on Ukraine; disconnecting from social media.
text: To the Editor:

title: The Looming End to Abortion Rights Gives Liberal Democrats a Spark
description: The progressive wing of the Democratic Party appeared to be flagging until a draft Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade leaked — and shook the political world.
text: The Democratic primary in North Carolina’s first congressional district had been a low-key affair, despite a new Republican-drawn map that will make the longtime stronghold for Black Democrats a key battleground in the fall.

title: A Battle Over How to Battle Over Roe: Protests at Justices’ Homes Fuel Rancor
description: Many of the protesters have expressed concern that the scrutiny over the demonstrations has distracted from the real issue: restricting a woman’s right to have an abortion.
text: WASHINGTON — For the protesters chanting loudly outside Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh’s home, incivility was the point.

title: For Democratic Female Governors, the Roe Leak Alters the Midterm Calculus
description: As the constitutional right to an abortion hangs in the balance, Democratic women who occupy or are vying for governors’ mansions are on the front lines of the messaging fight.
text: Every female governor’s seat is up for election this year. All nine of them.

title: Harris Emerges as the Voice of Abortion Rights in the Biden Administration
description: The threat to Roe v. Wade presents Vice President Kamala Harris with an opportunity to recover from early political stumbles.
authors: By Michael D. Shear and Alisha Haridasani Gupta
text: WASHINGTON — With three words last week, Vice President Kamala Harris inserted herself forcefully into the roiling debate over abortion rights — and may have finally seized on an issue that is popular among key Democratic voters, plays to her strengths and is central to the future of her party.

title: After Tense Debate, Louisiana Scraps Plan to Classify Abortion as Homicide
description: The legislation had divided abortion opponents, many of whom objected to the idea of prosecuting women who end a pregnancy.
authors: By Rick Rojas and Tariro Mzezewa
text: Louisiana lawmakers torpedoed legislation on Thursday that would have classified abortion as homicide, overwhelmingly rejecting a proposal with far-reaching implications that included making it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal charges against women who end a pregnancy.

title: The Pro-Democracy Argument Against Roe Falters When It Meets Reality
description: In many states, Americans aren’t living now with fair and representative institutions.
text: A significant part of the case against Roe v. Wade is that the Supreme Court was wrong to intervene in 1973 to recognize a constitutional right to abortion while the democratic process was still playing out. Better, instead, to have left the issue to the states — to voters and elected officials — who could then tailor their laws to their respective communities.

title: How Overturning Roe Could Backfire for Republicans
description: The party was making headway with suburban women on crime, schools and inflation. Now the abortion debate is front and center.
authors: By Maya King, Alexander Burns, Dan Simmons and Ryan Patrick Hooper
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: How New York Is Preparing for an Influx of Out-of-State Abortion Patients
description: When New York legalized abortion in 1970, nearly two-thirds of New York City’s abortions were for women from elsewhere. If Roe is overturned, a new surge is expected.
authors: By Ashley Wong and Lola Fadulu
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
description: The late-night hosts had plenty of news to riff on this week, including Elon Musk’s potential Twitter takeover, an abortion-rights bill failing in the Senate, and North Korea reporting its first Covid outbreak.
text: The late-night hosts had plenty of news to riff on this week, including Elon Musk’s potential Twitter takeover, an abortion-rights bill failing in the Senate, and North Korea reporting its first Covid outbreak.

title: Where Does the Abortion Rights Movement Go Next?
description: Gloria Steinem reflects on the draft majority opinion leak, democratic backsliding and her life in the public eye.
text: It was a baptism, of sorts.

title: Crypto Joins the Abortion Conversation
description: Activists and nonprofits are considering digital currencies as a way to raise funds. But can they really do anything other payment methods can’t?
authors: By Anna P. Kambhampaty, Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Valeriya Safronova
text: In the loud and confusing world of cryptocurrencies, fund-raising efforts are forming around all sorts of causes. Groups known as decentralized autonomous organizations, or DAOs, have sent aid to Ukrainians whose lives have been upended by war, worked to offset carbon emissions, bought land and collected NFTs.

title: ‘A New Generation of Powerless Women’: On Life Before Roe, and Fears for the Future
description: Readers, including those who had abortions, an “unwanted fetus” and an obstetrician, recall how girls and women dealt with unplanned pregnancies pre-Roe.
text: This is the first in a two-part series of personal stories from readers.

title: With Roe in Peril, Thousands Gather at Marches for Abortion Rights
description: Nearly two weeks after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, protesters gathered in Washington, New York and other cities.
authors: By Madeleine Ngo and Lola Fadulu
text: WASHINGTON — In the nation’s capital, protesters marched to the Supreme Court in the rain while chanting “We will not go back” and “Abortion is a human right.” In New York, thousands crossed the Brooklyn Bridge. And in Los Angeles, demonstrators filled a park near City Hall to show their support for abortion rights.

title: Abortion Rights Supporters March in New York City
description: Thousands of people gathered in New York City and across the country to show their support for abortion rights nearly two weeks after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Ang Li and Christina Kelso
text: Thousands of people gathered in New York City and across the country to show their support for abortion rights nearly two weeks after the leak of a draft Supreme Court opinion overturning Roe v. Wade.

title: Abortions, Before and After Roe v. Wade
description: Readers recall abortions after miscarriages, rape and fetal abnormalities, and an obstetrician and adoptive parent tell their stories. Also: An abortion fund.
text: This is the second in a two-part series of personal stories from readers.

title: Young Americans Are Stressed. They Are Angry. And They Can Swing Congress.
description: Donald Trump, abortion rights and student loan debt create a narrow window for President Biden and Democrats to regain their footing.
text: Millions of newly minted college graduates are about to enter a scorching job market, but many are still held back by feelings of hopelessness and depression. Less than one in 10 Americans between 18 and 29 years old describe ours as a “healthy democracy.” Most are convinced that both political parties cater to elites over people like them and that our politics cannot meet the challenges of the times. More than anything, “happiness and stability” are what youth seek, but even that appears out of reach at a time when they’re readying to launch.

title: The Latest on Abortion Rights in the U.S.
description: Get caught up on the latest news about reproductive rights and the birth control.
text: Get caught up on the latest news about reproductive rights and the birth control.

title: Starbucks will cover travel expenses for employees seeking abortions.
description: In a memo on Monday, the company said it wanted to ensure that its employees had “access to quality health care.”
text: Starbucks announced on Monday that it would reimburse travel expenses for employees who need abortions and cannot get them within 100 miles of their homes, joining the small group of companies that have moved to protect employee abortion access as the Supreme Court appears likely to soon overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: The Mexican Model of Abortion Rights
description: After years of work by feminist activists, Mexico now finds itself ahead of the United States when it comes to access to abortion.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Rob Szypko, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Chelsea Daniel, Kaitlin Roberts, Lisa Tobin, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
text: When the Supreme Court decriminalized abortion with Roe v. Wade, it established the United States as a global leader on abortion rights, decades ahead of many other countries.

title: Spain Considers Bill to Give Period Leave to Women With Menstrual Pain
description: A draft law would allow women to stay home if they are diagnosed by a doctor. It would also extend abortion access, but it faces an arduous path through Parliament.
text: MADRID — The Spanish government on Tuesday approved a draft law that would make Spain the first European country to grant women days off work because of menstrual pain, as well as extend access to abortion.

title: Michigan Judge Suspends an Abortion Ban From 1931
description: The law is obsolete because of Roe v. Wade but still on the books. Abortion rights advocates are worried that a potential Supreme Court ruling overturning Roe will revive it.
text: A Michigan judge has pre-emptively blocked enforcement of a 1931 law that would ban abortions in almost all cases if the Supreme Court takes an expected step to overturn the constitutional right to abortion.

title: Men, Share Your Stories About Abortion
description: Have you been in the position of supporting or objecting to a woman’s decision to end a pregnancy?
text: The Times is looking for men based in the United States to share their stories about experiences with abortion. Have you been in the position of supporting or objecting to a woman’s decision to end a pregnancy? How did your personal experience shape the way you feel about abortion and abortion access today?

title: Justice Dept. Employees Urge Administration to Grant Leave for Out-of-State Abortions
description: The request for federal employees to be granted time off to travel out of state for the procedure comes as large companies are starting to make accommodations in the area.
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Department employees pressed the Biden administration on Wednesday to grant federal employees time off if they or their family members need to travel out of state to obtain abortions.

title: Abortion and America’s Polarized Politics
description: Readers discuss a Ross Douthat column that views Roe as an inflection point in our divisions. Also: A threat to democracy; diplomacy in Ukraine; don’t name gunmen.
text: To the Editor:

title: Oklahoma Legislature Passes Bill Banning Almost All Abortions
description: The legislation prohibits abortion from the moment of fertilization and relies on lawsuits from private citizens to enforce it. If the governor signs the bill, it would be the nation’s strictest measure, and take effect immediately.
authors: By Kate Zernike, Mitch Smith and Luke Vander Ploeg
text: [The Oklahoma governor signed a bill into law that bans most abortions. Follow for the latest news.]

title: As he runs in the G.O.P. primary for Georgia Senate, Herschel Walker says he wants a ban on abortion with no exceptions.
description: On Wednesday, Mr. Walker called for more money to promote adoption and to support single fathers and single mothers.
text: Herschel Walker, the former football star leading the race for the Republican nomination for a Georgia Senate seat, said that a ban on abortion should have no exceptions — presumably even for rape, incest or the health of the mother.

title: How Democrats Can Win the Morality Wars
description: First, they have to understand the deep philosophical differences underlying these conflicts.
text: I’m a fan of FiveThirtyEight, a website that looks at policy issues from a data-heavy perspective, but everyone publishes a clunker once in a while. In February, FiveThirtyEight ran a piece called “Why Democrats Keep Losing Culture Wars.” The core assertion was that Republicans prevail because a lot of Americans are ignorant about issues like abortion and school curriculum, and they believe the lies the right feeds them. The essay had a very heavy “deplorables are idiots” vibe.

title: A Moral Philosopher Helps Me Untangle the Questions Beneath the Abortion Debate
description: The scholar Kate Greasley examines ethical quandaries around life, personhood and bodily autonomy.
text: When Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion on Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization leaked a few weeks ago, it signaled that Roe v. Wade appears likely to be overturned in a matter of weeks. If Roe falls, questions about the right to abortion will re-enter the realm of electoral politics in a way they haven’t for 50 years.
