States will be solely in charge of determining whether abortion is permitted, under what conditions it should be permitted, and what the appropriate thresholds are for making those decisions.

title: When an Abortion Is Pro-Life
description: If God does not want us to perform abortions, why did he put me in a situation where I would have to do one?
text: This guest essay contains graphic descriptions of a doctor performing an abortion.

title: America Almost Took a Different Path Toward Abortion Rights
description: Roe v. Wade was never expected to be the case that made history.
text: For three days in January 1970, they filled the 13th floor of the federal courthouse in Manhattan, women of all ages crowded into a conference room, sitting on the floor, spilling into the hallway. Some brought friends or husbands. One nursed a baby. Another was a painter who also taught elementary school. A third had gone to Catholic school. They’d come to give testimony in the case of Abramowicz v. Lefkowitz, the first in the country to challenge a state’s strict abortion law on behalf of women.

title: A Pro-Life Doctor on Performing a Lifesaving Abortion
description: “If God does not want us to perform abortions, why did he put me in a situation where I would have to do one?”
text: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kate Greasley
description: A conversation with the abortion ethicist.
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kate Greasley. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

title: Warning Signs of a Future Mass Killer
description: Mental health evaluations, chat rooms and parents’ roles. Also: Republicans and shootings; Covid mandates; voters and democracy; Estonia and Russia; abortion funds.
text: To the Editor:

title: Some Abortion Opponents Make Economic Arguments. They’re In for a Fight.
description: A legal brief by 154 economists says overturning Roe v. Wade would financially harm women.
text: If you believe abortion is murder, its economic consequences are beside the point. Morality trumps all.

title: Archbishop Bars Pelosi From Communion Over Abortion Stance
description: Archbishop Salvatore J. Cordileone, who has repeatedly confronted the House speaker over her backing of abortion rights, said her stance was a “grave evil.”
authors: By Annie Karni and Ruth Graham
text: WASHINGTON — An ultraconservative archbishop in San Francisco said on Friday that Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California would not be permitted to receive communion in his archdiocese because of her support for abortion rights.

title: How My Father, Ronald Reagan, Grappled With Abortion
description: Even as his beliefs on abortion shaped global policy, he was never entirely at peace with the issue.
text: Like every offspring of a famous political figure, I frequently round a corner and slam straight into some aspect of my father’s legacy. I’ve not checked with other political offspring, but I’m guessing we all shuffle through the same questions: Do I speak out, try to offer a wider or more personal perspective? Or do I keep quiet, let the news cycle move on without me and shy away from questions?

title: A Conservative Lawyer’s New Target After Abortion: Affirmative Action
description: Jonathan F. Mitchell, who helped draft Texas’ six-week abortion ban, has turned his attention to Harvard’s race-conscious admissions program.
text: WASHINGTON — Jonathan F. Mitchell, the architect of the law that sharply curtailed abortions in Texas, filed a brief in the Supreme Court the other day. He has moved on to affirmative action.

title: The Mexico City Model of Abortion Care
description: Why the city may be a blueprint for progressive American states.
text: After the Mexican Supreme Court decriminalized abortion, the ground shook.

title: Why Many College Students Are Struggling
description: Readers discuss the current malaise among many college students. Also: The Oklahoma abortion ban; stopping gun violence; remote work and the climate.
text: To the Editor:

title: Does Being Denied an Abortion Harm Mental Health?
description: An examination of the most rigorous research to date.
text: Shortly after the Supreme Court draft opinion was leaked that indicated the possible overturning of Roe v. Wade, the American Psychological Association reaffirmed its opinion that restricting abortion was “likely to lead to mental health harms,” a growing concern as some states rush to pass laws that would prohibit abortion.

title: Some abortion-rights supporters in Georgia are voting for Kemp, who has sought strict limits on abortions.
text: POWDER SPRINGS, Ga. — Though Karen Davenport, a retired schoolteacher who typically votes Republican, pulled the lever for incumbent Gov. Brian Kemp in Georgia’s primary on Tuesday, she said she did not share all of his political ideals. For one, she doesn’t think the government, at any level, should have a say in whether women can get abortions.

title: Abortion Questions for Justice Alito and His Supreme Court Allies
description: Isn’t having to carry an unwanted pregnancy to term the same as forced labor?
text: Now that the Oklahoma State Legislature has voted to ban abortion from the moment of conception, I have a few questions for Justice Samuel Alito and any others who would join him in overturning Roe v. Wade:

title: How State Abortion Laws Could Change if Roe Is Overturned
description: The New York Times is tracking abortion laws in each state ahead of a Supreme Court decision that could overturn Roe v. Wade.
text: The New York Times is tracking abortion laws in each state ahead of a Supreme Court decision that could overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Who Decides the Right Way to Protest?
description: A debate on what it means to voice dissent, and how to tell whether it’s made a difference.
text: Two years ago, the murder of George Floyd sparked protests across America, gathering an estimated 15 million people into the streets during the summer of 2020. Since then, Americans of all political persuasions have taken to the streets to make their views known, on everything from mask mandates to abortion rights. But did protesting result in any real change? And looking back, where does that moment of collective outrage fit in the broader history of dissent in America?

title: Oklahoma Governor Signs Bill That Bans Most Abortions
description: The law prohibits abortion at the point of fertilization, and relies on civilian enforcement to sidestep Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Luke Vander Ploeg and Kate Zernike
text: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma signed a bill on Wednesday that bans nearly all abortions starting at fertilization. The new law, which takes effect immediately, is the most restrictive abortion ban in the country.

title: Men Have a Lot to Lose When Roe Falls
description: Men benefit from abortion. Why do we mostly study women?
text: Matt Lavallee was in college when he learned his girlfriend was pregnant. “The news scared me,” he said, acknowledging that an unintended pregnancy was an even more daunting prospect for his girlfriend. “But there was no question that abortion was the best option for us.”

title: Defining the Limits on Aiding Ukraine
description: Readers react to an editorial about the limits to confronting Russia over Ukraine. Also: Heart disease in women; Ronald Reagan’s stand on abortion.
text: To the Editor:

title: Turning Pregnant Women and Doctors Into Criminals
description: Readers discuss how women may be allowed to die to save a fetus and the challenges of policing illegal abortions. Also: The Haiti inquiry; election predictions.
text: To the Editor:

title: From Gun Laws to Abortion, 5 Issues for N.Y. Legislators as Session Ends
description: A move to raise the minimum age to buy AR-15-style weapons is among several hot-button issues still to be resolved in Albany before the session ends.
authors: By Grace Ashford and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
text: ALBANY, N.Y. — Money and lobbying hold enormous sway in the State Capitol, but there are few pressures like an old-fashioned deadline to get major legislation over the finish line.

title: Sex, Abortion and Feminism, as Seen From the Right
description: The socially conservative legal scholar Erika Bachiochi argues that abortion rights have stalled women’s progress toward equality.
text: For decades, the conservative position on abortion has been simple: Appoint justices who will overturn Roe V. Wade. That aspiration is now likely to become reality. The question of abortion rights will re-enter the realm of electoral politics in a way it hasn’t for 50 years. And that means Republicans will need to develop a new politics of abortion — a politics that may appeal not only to their anti-abortion base but to some of the many Americans who believe Roe should stand.

title: My Governor Can Pass Bad Abortion Laws. But I Won’t Enforce Them.
description: No matter what the law says, I’ll never prosecute a woman for getting an abortion. My fellow prosecutors need to step up and make the same promise.
text: Almost two and a half years ago, I took my oath of office as prosecutor, and swore to protect my community from those who broke the law. The real threat, I now realize, may stem from those who write the law.

title: New York Tightens Its Strict Gun Laws in Democratic Show of Force
description: State lawmakers passed a package of gun-safety bills, and approved measures to broaden abortion protections as their 2022 session drew to a close.
authors: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Grace Ashford
text: ALBANY, N.Y. — The top lines read like a checklist of priorities for national Democrats: Gun safety. Abortion. Voting rights.

title: New York Lawmakers Move to Counter Rightward Shift Elsewhere
description: The Democrats who control the State Legislature voted to restrict gun use, bolster voting rights, protect abortion service providers and aid public housing.
text: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at some of the major bills approved by the State Legislature in an end-of-the-session flurry. And we’ll see why Harvey Weinstein, perhaps the original #MeToo abuser, will be staying in prison.

title: The ‘Open Secret’ on Getting a Safe Abortion Before Roe v. Wade
description: Psychiatrists were once arbiters of abortion access. Will they resume that role post-Roe?
text: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, will psychiatrists resume their pre-Roe role as arbiters of abortion access? The law once compelled psychiatrists and pregnant women to perform dishonest rituals to get abortions. Will psychiatrists once again need to be complicit post-Roe?

title: Is America Having a Breakdown?
description: Responses to Michelle Goldberg’s column that said America may be broken beyond repair. Also: The art of translation; the abortion ban in Oklahoma.
text: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Can Win This Fall if They Make One Key Promise
description: To make the 2022 elections a referendum on Roe, Democrats have to put protecting Roe and abortion rights on the table.
text: Democrats hope to make November’s midterm elections a referendum on Roe v. Wade, the linchpin decision upholding abortion rights, which the Supreme Court is almost certain to strike down this summer. That strategy makes sense. Polls show that roughly two in three Americans oppose overturning Roe and almost 60 percent support passing a bill to set Roe’s protections in a federal law. What’s more, polls showed a rising number of voters listing abortion as their top midterm issue after news of Roe’s imminent demise leaked in the form of a draft court opinion published by Politico.

title: A Post-Roe America
description: We look at what abortion access would look like.
text: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade, more than 20 states — home to roughly half the country’s population — are likely to outlaw nearly all abortions. For women living in Mississippi, the closest place to receive a legal abortion might then be Illinois.

title: Sheryl Sandberg’s Advice for Working Women
description: Readers discuss what the departing Meta executive’s “lean in” philosophy meant to them. Also: Abortion; sources of morality; the popularity of “Top Gun.”
text: To the Editor:

title: Boomers and Older: Ways to View the Generation in Power
description: Readers respond to an essay about the older cohort in charge of the country. Also: Catholicism, abortion and the Supreme Court; Ukraine and hunger.
text: To the Editor:

title: 48 Hours in A Kansas Abortion Clinic: Longer Wait Times, Growing Fears
description: Recent abortion bans in Texas and Oklahoma are forcing many patients in the region to travel to Kansas.
authors: By Nicole Salazar, Victoria Simpson and Mariam Dwedar
text: Recent abortion bans in Texas and Oklahoma are forcing many patients in the region to travel to Kansas.

title: Is abortion illegal now?
text: Friday’s Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade leaves the future of abortion in the hands of each state. Just minutes after the court ruling was announced on Friday, Attorney General Eric Schmitt of Missouri certified the state’s trigger law to effectively ban all abortions.

title: Armed Man Traveled to Justice Kavanaugh’s Home to Kill Him, Officials Say
description: The man, Nicholas John Roske, 26, said he was upset about the shooting in Uvalde, Texas, and impending decisions on abortion and guns, a federal affidavit says.
authors: By Maria Cramer and Jesus Jiménez
text: A man armed with a pistol, a knife and other weapons was arrested near the Maryland home of Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh early Wednesday after he said he traveled from California to kill the Supreme Court justice, federal officials said.

title: A Vanishing Word in Abortion Debate: ‘Women’
description: Progressive groups and medical organizations have adopted inclusive language, which has led to terms like “pregnant people” and “chestfeeding.”
text: The American Civil Liberties Union, whose advocacy on reproductive rights is of more than a half-century vintage, recently tweeted its alarm about the precarious state of legal abortion:

title: Abortion Didn’t Feel Like an Option. Neither Did Motherhood.
description: At 19, Merritt Tierce found herself unexpectedly pregnant and facing what felt like an impossible choice.
text: If the Supreme Court overturns Roe v. Wade in the coming weeks, tens of millions of women will find themselves living in states where abortion is outlawed in almost all cases. And for some women, that will mean having children — without actually wanting them — because they are left with no choice.

title: The New Abortion Bans: Almost No Exceptions for Rape, Incest or Health
description: Most of the state abortion prohibitions that would go into effect if Roe v. Wade is overturned do not contain carve-outs that were once widely supported by abortion opponents.
text: In the years before Roe v. Wade, some states that had outlawed abortion began permitting it in limited circumstances: in cases of rape or incest, or to save the life or health of the woman.

title: ‘The Janes’ Review: Taking Matters Into Their Own Hands
description: This HBO documentary spotlights the women activists who banded together to form Jane, a clandestine group providing safe abortions in the years before Roe v. Wade.
text: “The Janes” is a straightforward, talking-heads documentary from HBO that provides a brief history of the Jane Collective, a clandestine abortion group working out of Chicago in the late 1960s and early ’70s.

title: Oklahoma’s Abortion Law Raises Questions About N.C.A.A.’s Softball World Series
description: The N.C.A.A. has restricted previous events in response to state lawmakers. It faces that test again in Oklahoma, where softball championships are a mainstay and a restrictive abortion ban recently became law.
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Last Saturday, like many days here in early June, was a softball fiesta. The 13,100-seat stadium — burnished and bulked up by a $27.5 million renovation that added a second deck — was teeming with young pony-tailed fans from Alva to Ardmore, partisans in Oklahoma, Oklahoma State or Texas colors, and softball aficionados who make the yearly sojourn to the Women’s College World Series.

title: Abortion Politics, Money and the Reshaping of the G.O.P.
description: In “Dollars for Life,” Mary Ziegler argues that, over the course of decades, the anti-abortion movement laid the groundwork for an insurgent candidate like Donald Trump.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Poland Shows the Risks for Women When Abortion Is Banned
description: Poland’s abortion ban has had many unintended consequences. One is that doctors are sometimes afraid to remove fetuses or administer cancer treatment to save women’s lives.
authors: By Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: The Politics of Abortion
description: Polls show that support for abortion rights is rising. Will that help Democrats this fall?
text: Regular readers of this newsletter may remember the thermostat theory of politics. It’s the idea, developed by the political scientist Christopher Wlezien, that public opinion often moves in the opposite direction as government policy.

title: In Missouri, Battles Over Birth Control Foreshadow a Post-Roe World
description: The demise of Roe v. Wade would make the need for effective birth control more urgent than ever. Yet many American women still have a hard time obtaining it.
text: Follow our live updates on the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: House Approves Supreme Court Security Bill, Sending It to Biden
description: A measure extending police protection to the immediate families of Supreme Court justices passed the House overwhelmingly.
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved legislation that would extend police protection to the immediate families of Supreme Court justices, clearing the bill for President Biden at a time of rising concern about threats to justices as a potentially momentous abortion ruling looms.

title: Some Clinics Aren’t Waiting for Roe Decision to Stop Abortions
description: Women can no longer get a legal abortion in two states.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: Follow our live updates on the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Abortions Increase in the U.S., Reversing a 30-Year Decline, Report Finds
description: A new survey of the nation’s abortion providers found increases in every region of the country from 2017 to 2020.
text: The number of abortions in the United States has increased, reversing what had been a three-decade decline, according to a new report.

title: Pregnancy Can Affect the Body Forever. Have Abortion Foes Reckoned With That?
description: Yes, if women are required to go through the ultimate stress test, their liberty is curtailed.
text: Lately, I’ve been thinking a lot about Alexandra of Denmark, Great Britain’s queen from 1901 to 1910. Called “Alix” by her loved ones, she was the wife of King Edward VII, the notoriously promiscuous son of Queen Victoria, called “the playboy prince” by the biographer Jane Ridley.

title: Abortion Bans With Mental Health Exceptions
description: Readers discuss the role that psychiatrists may have in determining access to abortions. Also: Trump and Jan. 6; younger gunmen; mariachis in Uvalde.
text: To the Editor:

title: Bracing for the End of Roe v. Wade, the White House Weighs Executive Actions
description: The Biden administration has been deluged with ideas to help mitigate a Supreme Court ruling expected to overturn abortion rights, but many come with legal risks.
text: Follow live updates on the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Synagogue Sues Florida, Saying Abortion Restrictions Violate Religious Freedoms
description: A South Florida congregation said that under Jewish law, abortion “is required if necessary to protect the health, mental or physical well-being” of a pregnant woman.
text: Religion, particularly the influence of Christian conservatives, has been at the heart of the anti-abortion movement and the push to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 ruling legalizing abortion throughout the United States.

title: I.V.F. Gave Me My Daughter. What Will Happen After Roe?
description: Extreme anti-abortion laws could hinder assisted reproductive technologies, too.
text: After I struggled to get pregnant for many years, my partner, Rob, and I finally had our daughter in August 2020, thanks to some alchemy of science and serendipity. We had gone into our in vitro fertilization experience wanting one child. But in those exhausting days after she was born — and in the many months since — the five leftover embryos from our I.V.F. cycle, frozen in liquid nitrogen, have called out to me.

title: Sure, Just Have the Baby
description: There are good reasons American women overwhelmingly choose having an abortion over giving up a child for adoption.
text: There’s a lot I don’t remember about giving birth to my first child. But I do remember 24 hours of back labor followed by two hours of pushing to no avail. I remember, through a high fever and the agony of exertion, my body shaking with hard chills when I heard the doctor say the words “emergency C-section.” I remember feeling a scalpel run along my midsection and screaming “Yes!” when asked if I was in pain and then “No” when asked if I would like to see my baby. No way did I want to meet my child for the first time under these circumstances.

title: With Roe Set to End, Many Women Worry About High-Risk Pregnancies
description: Most states likely to outlaw abortions allow for exceptions to save a mother’s life. But many women and doctors ask: Where will lawmakers draw the line?
text: Follow our live updates on the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Inside One Abortion Clinic, Signs of Nationwide Struggles
description: The Planned Parenthood clinic in Fort Myers, Fla., has seen an increase in patients arriving from Texas, even as it struggles to keep up with increasing restrictions in its own state.
authors: By Gabriela Bhaskar and Abby Goodnough
text: FORT MYERS, Fla. — At a Planned Parenthood health center on Florida’s Gulf Coast, new restrictions on who can get an abortion are shaking up routines and creating challenges for the clinic’s patients, doctors and nurses.

title: These 11 Moderate Voters See an America That Others Don’t
description: For its latest focus group, Times Opinion spoke with 11 middle-of-the-road voters about culture war issues: abortion, gun control and trans rights.
authors: By Patrick Healy and Adrian J. Rivera
text: For its latest focus group, Times Opinion spoke with 11 middle-of-the-road voters about culture war issues: abortion, gun control and trans rights.

title: Newsmax Debate Lends N.Y. Governor’s Race a Far-Right Glow
description: The four Republican candidates for governor of New York faced off in their third and final debate before the June 28 primary.
text: The four Republican candidates for governor of New York made their closing pitch to voters on Tuesday night, voicing devotion to President Trump and his policies, disdain for gun control and abortion, and worries about crime and immigration.

title: They Searched Online for Abortion Clinics. They Found Anti-Abortion Centers.
description: Using Google ads and the promise of free services, Human Coalition, a Texas nonprofit, intercepts women across the country who want to end their pregnancies and tries to stop them.
authors: By Emma Cott, Nilo Tabrizy, Aliza Aufrichtig, Rebecca Lieberman and Nailah Morgan
text: Using Google ads and the promise of free services, Human Coalition, a Texas nonprofit, intercepts women across the country who want to end their pregnancies and tries to stop them.

title: The Supreme Court Case That Could Doom U.S. Climate Goals
description: The government’s power to tackle pollution is not the only question at stake in a potentially far-reaching lawsuit.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Michael Simon Johnson, Carlos Prieto, Clare Toeniskoetter, Asthaa Chaturvedi, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
text: While coming rulings on abortion and guns have garnered lots of attention, the Supreme Court is also set to make another major decision in a less-publicized suit involving climate change.

title: How an Abortion Ban Trapped a Tourist on Malta
description: Andrea Prudente, an American, developed potentially life-threatening pregnancy complications while on the island. But abortion is illegal there.
text: Andrea Prudente, a 38-year-old photographer who lives near Seattle, and her partner, Jay Weeldreyer, expected their trip to Malta to be a “babymoon” where they could connect with each other while enjoying the Mediterranean sun and local sights.

title: There’s a Way to Outmaneuver the Supreme Court, and Maine Has Found It
description: The move in a religion case offers hope to those worried about the dominance of the court’s conservative majority.
text: What a week so far for conservatives. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court struck down a Maine law that prohibited religious private schools from receiving taxpayer dollars. On Thursday, it invalidated a New York State gun safety law limiting the public carry of firearms. And on Friday, it overturned Roe v. Wade. The outcome in these cases was not surprising. The court has ruled in favor of religious litigants in an overwhelming number of cases; the gun case’s outcome was clear from the oral argument before the justices in November; and the court’s draft abortion decision was leaked in May.

title: Abortion Pills Will Change a Post-Roe World
description: Medication abortion isn’t a magic solution to the likely end of Roe. But it can blunt the fallout.
authors: By Greer Donley, Rachel Rebouché and David S. Cohen
text: Update: On Friday the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion.

title: Crime, Taxes, Abortion: Where the 7 Candidates for N.Y. Governor Stand
description: Ahead of the state primary elections, Republican and Democratic candidates expound on the issues — and exactly where upstate New York begins.
text: In the primary races for governor of New York, the candidates in each party naturally have some common alliances but also some surprising differences.

title: In 6-to-3 Ruling, Supreme Court Ends Nearly 50 Years of Abortion Rights
description: The decision will lead to all but total bans on the procedure in about half of the states.
text: Follow the latest abortion news and the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: How State Abortion Laws Are Changing
description: About half the states are expected to ban or further restrict access to abortion.
authors: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Allison McCann
text: About half of states are expected to ban or further restrict access to abortion following the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, which for 50 years guaranteed the constitutional right to abortion.

title: The decision to overturn Roe clashes with the views of a majority of Americans.
text: Few issues are more politically fraught than abortion. So, it is notable that the decision by Republican-appointed justices to end a constitutional right to abortion conflicted with the views of a majority of Americans.

title: What did Planned Parenthood v. Casey say?
text: In Planned Parenthood v. Casey in 1992, the Supreme Court affirmed what it called the central holding of Roe v. Wade: that states may not prohibit abortions before fetal viability, the point when a fetus could survive outside the womb, which is now about 23 weeks.

title: Here are past cases that have upheld or chipped away at Roe v. Wade.
description: The legal case over a law that makes most abortions illegal after 15 weeks of pregnancy is by no means the first to challenge or chip away at Roe v. Wade.
text: The Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the case before the nation’s highest court on a restrictive Mississippi law, is the most consequential on women’s access to abortion since the court’s 1973 decision in Roe v. Wade.

title: ‘Shock and Dismay’ Over the Abortion Ruling
description: Most readers decry the Supreme Court’s decision to force many women to unwillingly endure “the risks and consequences of pregnancy.”
text: To the Editor:

title: Germany Ends Ban on Abortion Advertisement
description: The vote to scrap the law came on the same day that Roe v. Wade was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court.
text: BERLIN — German lawmakers voted on Friday to end a Nazi-era ban on the advertisement of abortion services, a measure that had effectively criminalized doctors who provided information about the procedure.

title: What are abortion trigger laws and which states have them?
description: Trigger laws will move to quickly outlaw abortions in 13 states. Some laws are expected to take effect almost immediately, while others are written to take effect about a month after the ruling.
authors: By Jesus Jiménez and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade and give individual states the choice of banning or allowing abortions will most immediately affect the 13 states that have trigger laws.

title: Politico’s Roe v. Wade scoop becomes law.
description: In May, Politico’s reporters published a draft opinion outlining the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Today, the high court made it official.
text: The Supreme Court made huge headlines on Friday with its decision to end the constitutional right to abortion. But the decision was also unusual because it was already known.

title: Roe’s Death Will Change American Democracy
description: The anti-abortion movement has won its decades-long effort to undo Roe. Now what?
text: The anti-abortion movement has long argued that reversing Roe v. Wade would strengthen American democracy. Roe, the argument goes, short-circuited a process of state-by-state debate and compromise, freezing the democratic process and imposing a single abortion solution on the nation. Undoing the constitutional right to abortion, then, is seen as a win for democracy — a first step in allowing each state to set its own policy.

title: How Abortion Bans Will Ripple Across America
description: With Roe overturned, the distances many women will need to travel for an abortion will increase drastically. See the range of scenarios.
authors: By Quoctrung Bui, Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: With Roe overturned, the distances many women will need to travel for an abortion will increase drastically. See the range of scenarios.

title: Here are the companies that will cover travel expenses for employee abortions.
description: A handful of companies have committed to helping their employees access abortion services.
authors: By Emma Goldberg, Lora Kelley and Emily Flitter
text: Here’s an updating list of companies that will cover travel expenses for employee abortions.

title: Gov. Hochul Calls Decision Overturning Roe ‘Repulsive at Every Level’
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul declared New York a “safe harbor” for those seeking abortions as advocates and lawmakers in the state moved to respond to the Supreme Court ruling.
authors: By Jeffery C. Mays, Michael Gold, Lola Fadulu and Hurubie Meko
text: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York responded on Friday morning to the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade by declaring her state a “safe harbor” for those seeking abortions and reaffirming her commitment to abortion rights.

title: Thomas’s concurring opinion raises questions about what rights might be next.
description: The same rationale could also be used to overturn cases establishing rights to contraception, same-sex consensual relations and same-sex marriage.
text: Justice Clarence Thomas, in his concurring opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, laid out a vision that prompted concerns about what other rights could disappear: The same rationale that the Supreme Court used to declare there was no right to abortion, he said, should also be used to overturn cases establishing rights to contraception, same-sex consensual relations and same-sex marriage.

title: Americans Celebrate and Mourn Abortion Decision as New Fights Loom
description: The Supreme Court sent the issue of abortion back to the states in an even more polarized era than when Roe v. Wade was introduced.
text: Within minutes of the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade on Friday, the attorney general in Missouri issued an opinion banning abortion in his state. Abortion clinics in several cities, including Montgomery, Ala., and Sioux Falls, S.D., shut down. But others in Illinois and Ohio kept seeing patients.

title: Pennsylvania’s race for governor takes on huge stakes for abortion rights.
description: If Doug Mastriano, the Republican nominee, beats his Democratic opponent, Josh Shapiro, he and the state’s G.O.P.-led legislature are all but certain to move to outlaw abortion.
text: Now that the Supreme Court has struck down Roe v. Wade, the most important election this year in America when it comes to abortion will be the contest for governor of Pennsylvania.

title: Garland says Justice Department will protect access to an abortion.
description: He also called on Congress to pass a federal law that protects the right to an abortion.
text: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland called the Supreme Court decision to strike down the right to an abortion “a devastating blow to reproductive freedom,” and he vowed to use the Justice Department’s authority to protect the right to the procedure.

title: ‘A Grievous Wrong Was Righted’: Anti-Abortion Activists Celebrate the End of Roe
description: This was the moment they had imagined for half a century, a dream many refused to believe was impossible.
text: The staff of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America waited in anticipation at its headquarters in northern Virginia on Friday morning, trying to refresh the Supreme Court website that would not load.

title: ‘This Is Not Over’: Biden Tries to Galvanize Voters After Abortion Ruling
description: “This decision must not be the final word,” President Biden said after the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion.
text: WASHINGTON — Calling the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade a “tragic error,” President Biden on Friday tried to galvanize voters ahead of the midterm elections and called on Americans to “make their voices heard.”

title: I Prayed and Protested to End Roe. What Comes Next?
description: What the overturning of Roe v. Wade means to abortion opponents like me.
text: Roe v. Wade’s reversal has elicited cries of anger and despair from those who feel a sense of dread for the future of women and the future of America.

title: Most U.S. abortions are already performed using pills. That share is likely to climb.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: Taking pills to end a pregnancy accounts for a majority of abortions in the United States, both legal and not. Now that the Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade, medication abortion will play a larger role, especially among women who lose access to abortion clinics.

title: Is it legal for women to travel out of state for an abortion?
description: There are no abortion bans that attempt to prosecute women who cross state lines to seek an abortion.
text: There are currently no abortion bans that attempt to prosecute women who cross state lines to seek an abortion.

title: How candidates competing in Tuesday’s primary elections are reacting to the Supreme Court’s decision.
description: Anti-abortion Republican candidates basked in the moment and Democrats anguished over the uncertain future of reproductive rights.
text: Follow our live updates on primary elections and results in Illinois, Colorado and New York.

title: DeSantis has already moved to restrict abortions in Florida.
description: The state was once a refuge for the procedure in the Southeast.
text: Florida, the nation’s third-most populous state, also has the third-highest abortion rate, after New York and Illinois. Friday’s Supreme Court ruling and recent actions by Republican state leaders are expected to soon change that.

title: Biden Slams Supreme Court for Its Ruling on Abortion
description: President Biden warned that the decision could jeopardize the health of millions of women in the United States and urged people to vote.
text: President Biden warned that the decision could jeopardize the health of millions of women in the United States and urged people to vote.

title: Dobbs, Named in Abortion Case Ending Roe, Had Little to Do With It
description: His name was affixed to the historic lawsuit after he became Mississippi’s chief health officer in 2018.
text: Dr. Thomas E. Dobbs III, the man whose name on Friday became synonymous with the Supreme Court decision to let states ban abortions, had almost nothing to do with the landmark case.

title: World leaders react to Roe ruling.
description: Several European leaders criticized the Supreme Court’s decision, which goes against a global trend, while the Vatican welcomed it.
text: It applies to a single country, but the U.S. Supreme Court ruling scrapping the constitutional right to abortion reverberated globally, drawing a wave of responses from world leaders, some of them heated — “horrific,” “a huge setback” — as denunciation outweighed praise.

title: West Coast governors commit to abortion rights firewall.
description: The commitment memo changed no laws in their states, which have been legislating for months to protect abortion rights in anticipation of the ruling.
text: SACRAMENTO — Vowing to make the West Coast a firewall for reproductive rights, the governors of California, Oregon and Washington on Friday announced a joint commitment to maintain access to abortion and contraception and to protect providers and patients from the legal reach of other states.

title: How women who support abortion rights are reacting to the news.
description: Women across the nation react with anger and fear. One says she feels the “nation is on fire.”
authors: By Austyn Gaffney, Douglas Morino, Tom Lawrence and Jimmie E. Gates
text: Our reporters are speaking with women across the United States as they react to Friday’s Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade. Here is a selection of what they have heard from women who support maintaining access to abortion.

title: Hochul Calls Supreme Court’s Abortion Ruling ‘Repulsive’
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York condemned the decision, saying extremism had “infiltrated the Supreme Court of the United States of America.”
text: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York condemned the decision, saying extremism had “infiltrated the Supreme Court of the United States of America.”

title: Democrats turn to donors after the abortion decision, and Republicans follow suit — but with a different message.
description: Democrats’ fund-raising blasts filled email boxes and social media feeds as they aimed to capitalize on the fear and alarm that many left-leaning voters felt.
text: Democrats in some of the most competitive races for Senate and governor this year instantly appealed to donors on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned 50 years of precedent on abortion rights.

title: Here are key passages from the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe.
description: Central to the decision is Justice Alito’s belief that the Constitution does not include a right to abortion.
text: The Supreme Court decision that overturned Roe v. Wade and ruled that states should be allowed to ban abortions was written by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. and joined by five other justices.

title: How women who oppose abortion are reacting to the court’s decision.
description: Abortion opponents said they were shedding happy tears and remembering those who regretted past abortions.
authors: By Kevin Williams, Jamie McGee and Carey Gillam
text: Our reporters are speaking with women across the United States as they react to Friday’s Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade. Here is a selection of what they have heard from women who oppose abortion.

title: Anti-Abortion Supporters Celebrate Supreme Court’s Ruling
description: Anti-abortion activists celebrated the court’s decision to reverse Roe v. Wade outside the Supreme Court and across the country.
authors: By The Associated Press and Reuters
text: Anti-abortion activists celebrated the court’s decision to reverse Roe v. Wade outside the Supreme Court and across the country.

title: The Ruling Overturning Roe Is an Insult to Women and the Judicial System
description: This is the start of a new era of conflict over abortion.
text: Even if we knew it was coming, the shock reverberates.

title: The Man Most Responsible for Ending Roe Worries That It Could Hurt His Party
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has privately told friends and advisers that a ruling overturning Roe v. Wade will be “bad for Republicans.”
authors: By Maggie Haberman and Michael C. Bender
text: The end of the landmark Roe v. Wade ruling was the culmination of decades of work by Republicans and social conservatives — one that came to pass only after a former Democrat from New York who had once supported abortion rights helped muscle through three Supreme Court justices.

title: Scene Outside Mississippi Abortion Clinic After Roe Is Overturned
description: Clinic escorts directed traffic outside the Jackson Women’s Health Organization as a small group of anti-abortion demonstrators gathered outside after the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade.
authors: By The Associated Press and Reuters
text: Clinic escorts directed traffic outside the Jackson Women’s Health Organization as a small group of anti-abortion demonstrators gathered outside after the Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade.

title: Athletes, Players Unions and Leagues Criticize Abortion Ruling
description: The commissioners of the N.B.A. and W.N.B.A. said in a joint statement that “women should be able to make their own decisions concerning their health and future.”
text: Megan Rapinoe, the outspoken star of the U.S. women’s soccer team, was among several professional athletes on Friday to criticize the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. She had not originally been scheduled to appear at a news conference ahead of the team’s friendly against Colombia but spent nearly 30 minutes addressing the ruling, which ends the constitutional right to an abortion.

title: ‘You Cannot Stop Abortions’: Four Writers On the End of Roe v. Wade
description: Michelle Goldberg, Lauren Kelley and Leah Libresco Sargeant join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss what comes next after Dobbs.
text: Michelle Goldberg, Lauren Kelley and Leah Libresco Sargeant join Lulu Garcia-Navarro to discuss what comes next after Dobbs.

title: Mad About Roe? Here’s What to Do Now.
description: I wrote the “Handbook for a Post-Roe America.” It’s time to put it into practice.
text: In February 2021, I uprooted my husband, three children and two cats from our longtime home to move across the country to a house we had only seen on FaceTime, in a city we only knew from college football. I did this because I believe that everyone who supports abortion rights must do what they’re able to to keep abortion accessible for those who have the least resources to get one.

title: Politicians React to Supreme Court’s Ruling on Abortion
description: Democratic leaders condemned the court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, while some Republican lawmakers celebrated the ruling.
authors: By The Associated Press and Reuters
text: Democratic leaders condemned the court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, while some Republican lawmakers celebrated the ruling.

title: Jim Obergefell and L.G.B.T.Q. groups warn that abortion ruling could impact other rights.
description: Advocates for L.G.B.T.Q. rights expressed dismay over Justice Clarence Thomas’s opinion concurring with the decision.
authors: By Jazmine Ulloa and Stephanie Lai
text: Advocates for L.G.B.T.Q. rights on Friday sounded the alarm over Justice Clarence Thomas’s concurring opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, calling it a potential assault on the legal doctrine protecting a wide array of Americans’ civil rights.

title: Meta clamps down on internal discussion of Roe v. Wade’s overturning.
authors: By Mike Isaac and Ryan Mac
text: Meta told its workers on Friday not to openly discuss the Supreme Court’s ruling eliminating the constitutional right to an abortion on wide-reaching communication channels inside the company, people with knowledge of the situation said.

title: Abortion funds raise millions in donations to help people seeking the procedure.
description: As of Friday afternoon, the National Network of Abortion Funds had received more than $3 million from about 33,000 new donations.
text: Abortion funds, the local organizations that provide financial and logistical support for people seeking abortions, have received millions of dollars in new funding after the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade on Friday.

title: Are abortion medications delivered by mail illegal?
description: The end of Roe v. Wade will make little immediate difference on access to medications, though legal experts say that could change as more trigger laws are certified.
text: It is still legal in most states to receive abortion medication by mail, which has been allowed since December 2021, when the Food and Drug Administration lifted a restriction that required patients to obtain the pills from a certified provider.

title: Companies Are More Vocal Than Ever on Social Issues. Not on Abortion.
description: The corporate response to the Supreme Court’s Friday decision was more muted, and the companies that did speak out mostly talked about their health care policies.
authors: By Emma Goldberg and Lora Kelley
text: Companies had more than a month to formulate a response to the end of federal abortion rights in the United States, if they didn’t weigh in immediately after a draft opinion was leaked in May.

title: How G.O.P. Support for Decriminalizing Abortion Faded Over Decades
description: Before the 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling, more Republicans than Democrats backed decriminalizing the procedure. But a political and religious coalition rose and took the party in a new direction.
text: Few can imagine it today, but on the eve of the Roe v. Wade ruling in 1973, more Republicans than Democrats supported decriminalizing abortion.

title: Friday’s ruling prompts confusion and closures at abortion clinics.
description: Doctors and clinic owners were calling lawyers and looking for guidance from state attorneys general.
authors: By Jack Healy and Campbell Robertson
text: The Supreme Court’s decision overturning the constitutional right to abortion unleashed waves of confusion, panic and resignation for doctors and women across the country as they tried to understand a legal landscape that was changing by the hour.

title: ‘It’s Become Real’: Abortion Decision Roils Midterms, Sending Fight to States
description: Democrats hope the fall of Roe v. Wade will jolt abortion rights supporters into action in midterm elections. But is it enough to turn voters’ attention away from inflation?
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — The Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday catapulted the explosive battle over abortion rights into the center of several marquee midterm races, turning the fight over key governor’s contests and coveted Senate seats into heated debates about personal freedom and public health.

title: Thousands Protest in New York After Supreme Court Overturns Roe v. Wade
description: Demonstrators in Union Square and Washington Square Park voiced their frustrations and fears about the Supreme Court decision.
authors: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Téa Kvetenadze and Lola Fadulu
text: Hours after the U.S. Supreme Court ruled to overturn Roe v. Wade on Friday, thousands gathered in New York City to voice their fears and anger over the historic decision to eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion.

title: ‘Abortion Is Just the Beginning’: Six Experts on the Decision Overturning Roe
description: These passages are key to understanding the Dobbs decision.
text: These passages are key to understanding the Dobbs decision.

title: Abortion Ruling Poses New Questions About How Far Supreme Court Will Go
description: The decision overruling Roe v. Wade exposed internal divisions among conservative justices about reconsidering other rights.
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday to end the constitutional right to abortion concluded one battle for now but immediately posed another far-reaching question: whether the judicial ground under rights in other personal matters, including contraception and same-sex marriage, is now also shaky.

title: Special Episode: Roe v. Wade Is Overturned
description: In a decision with sweeping implications, the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion. What comes next?
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Eric Krupke, Sydney Harper, Carlos Prieto, Lisa Chow, Marc Georges, Ben Calhoun, Dan Powell, Corey Schreppel and Marion Lozano
text: The Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, a ruling that eliminates women’s constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years. “Roe was egregiously wrong from the start,” Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. wrote on behalf of the majority, while President Biden has denounced the court’s action as the “realization of extreme ideology.”

title: The End of Roe Is Just the Beginning
description: An improbable anti-abortion triumph yields an uncertain political future.
text: By any reasonable political science theory, any normal supposition about how power works in our republic, this day should not have come.

title: Elizabeth Warren and Tina Smith: We’ve Seen What Will Happen Next to America’s Women
description: Roe is gone, but the fight has just begun.
authors: By Elizabeth Warren and Tina Smith
text: The Supreme Court has spoken: Roe is gone. But the Supreme Court doesn’t get the final say on abortion. The American people will have the last word through their representatives in Congress and the White House.

title: Century-Old State Laws Could Determine Where Abortion Is Legal
description: In Wisconsin, Michigan and other states, abortion bans that were long considered dormant could determine if access to the procedure survives the overturning of Roe.
text: Abortion has become or will soon become illegal in more than a dozen states whose legislatures had passed so-called trigger laws, allowing for bans shortly after the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade on Friday.

title: In New York, Anti-Abortion Centers Outnumber Abortion Clinics
description: Crisis pregnancy centers, which encourage women to give birth, prepare for a post-Roe world in a state that is considered a bastion of abortion rights.
authors: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Jeenah Moon
text: Patricia Clinton was walking up East 149th Street in the South Bronx one afternoon last fall, ruminating over her decision to end an unexpected pregnancy. She was five weeks along, already a single parent to two children, and her finances were unstable. She wasn’t sure if the father of her unborn child would remain in the picture and didn’t think she could handle feeding a third mouth on her own.

title: The Voices of Men Affected by Abortion
description: In light of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, advocates from all sides of the issue have called for men to be part of the conversation. The Times heard from hundreds who wanted to share their stories.

title: The End of Roe
description: The Supreme Court’s abortion ruling will transform American life and politics.
text: The Supreme Court has overturned the constitutional right to an abortion in America.

title: Abortion access is shifting rapidly one day after the overturning of Roe.
text: The consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning the right to abortion cascaded across the country on Saturday, as millions of Americans began to grapple with one of the swiftest, most expansive transformations to reproductive rights in 50 years.

title: For Conservative Christians, the End of Roe Was a Spiritual Victory
description: Many religious people who are opposed to abortion worked for decades to overturn Roe v. Wade. “It seems like an answer to prayer,” one said after the Supreme Court’s decision.
text: For nearly 50 years, conservative Christians marched, strategized and prayed. And then, on an ordinary Friday morning in June, the day they had dreamed of finally came.

title: Americans Face New Abortion Landscape in Wake of Roe Decision
description: Around the country, a patchwork of laws was taking hold amid protest and celebration.
text: A new and rapidly shifting reality took hold across America on Saturday as abortion, a basic legal right for nearly a half century, was outlawed in some states, and the initial bursts of elation and shock from the overturning of Roe v. Wade gave way to action.

title: Supreme Court Throws Abortion to an Unlevel State Playing Field
description: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade shifted the abortion fight to state legislatures, where gerrymandering has given Republicans an advantage.
authors: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
text: In his concurring opinion to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh struck a note of optimism that democracy and the will of the people would prevail, even on the agonizing issue of a woman’s right to end a pregnancy.

title: How Did Roe Fall? Before a Decisive Ruling, a Powerful Red Wave.
description: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.
text: The downfall of the constitutional right to abortion began 12 years ago, after Republicans swept state house elections and passed hundreds of restrictions.

title: Decades Ago, Alito Laid Out Methodical Strategy to Eventually Overrule Roe
description: A slow-burning hostility to constitutional abortion rights runs through the career of the author of the Supreme Court opinion overturning them.
text: WASHINGTON — In the spring of 1985, a 35-year-old lawyer in the Justice Department, Samuel A. Alito Jr., cautioned the Reagan administration against mounting a frontal assault on Roe v. Wade, the landmark ruling that declared a constitutional right to abortion. The Supreme Court was not ready to overturn it, he said, so urging it to do so could backfire.

title: Planned Parenthood of Utah has sued to block the state’s abortion ban.
description: The lawsuit argues that the state’s ban violates several provisions in the State Constitution, including the right to determine family composition and the right to equality between the sexes.
text: Planned Parenthood Association of Utah filed a lawsuit on Saturday seeking to block the state’s ban on abortion, which came into effect after the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: 34 Senate Democrats urge Biden to take action on abortion.
description: With little hope of legislative action following the Supreme Court’s ruling, lawmakers urged the president to take “bold action” to defend Americans’ reproductive rights.
text: WASHINGTON — A group of Senate Democrats sent a letter to President Biden on Saturday urging him to take “bold action” on abortion rights, a day after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the landmark case that legalized abortion nationwide.

title: Abortion Pills Take the Spotlight as States Impose Abortion Bans
description: Demand for medication abortion is surging, setting the stage for new legal battles.
text: In the hours after the Supreme Court released its decision overturning the legal right to abortion in the United States, nearly 100 requests for appointments flowed into Just the Pill, a nonprofit organization that arranges for patients to obtain abortion pills in several states.

title: The Dobbs Decision Isn’t Just About Abortion. It’s About Power.
description: The legal journalist Dahlia Lithwick breaks down the Dobbs decision and considers the “raw power” of the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority.
text: On Friday, a Supreme Court majority voted to overturn Roe v. Wade. Nearly all abortions are already banned in at least nine states, home to 7.2 million women of reproductive age. And it is likely that other bans and restrictions will follow. As the court’s three liberal justices put it in their dissenting opinion, “One result of today’s decision is certain: the curtailment of women’s rights, and of their status as free and equal citizens.”

title: As states ban abortion, demand for birth control and abortion pills is rising.
description: Some women are stockpiling birth control, emergency contraception and abortion pills in case legislation prevents them from accessing it in their home state.
text: Less than 48 hours after the Supreme Court said states could ban abortion, health care providers have noticed an increase in interest in birth control, emergency contraception and abortion pills.

title: Dobbs, Roe and the Myth of ‘Bodily Autonomy’
description: The end of Roe v. Wade is a reminder that we have human rights and human obligations.
text: “We hold that Roe and Casey must be overruled,” the Supreme Court declared on Friday in its majority opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization. It boggles the mind, really. The fight over abortion that has raged as long as I can remember has taken a decisive turn. The broad spectrum of emotions in reaction to this decision — from outrage to jubilation and everything in between — will be on full display for weeks and months to come. Our feelings about this decision matter. But it is also critical that we continue to examine and clarify the merits of the arguments about abortion.

title: California looks to enshrine abortion rights in state constitution.
description: The state constitutional amendment is the latest in a wave of abortion rights legislation that has swept states led by Democrats.
text: SACRAMENTO — California state lawmakers are expected as soon as Monday to put a state constitutional amendment on the ballot that would explicitly protect reproductive rights.

title: The Ruling Was Just the Beginning: Both Sides Mobilize Over Abortion
description: Lawyers, politicians and advocacy groups responded to Friday’s Supreme Court ruling with fresh plans for the fight over abortion rights.
text: Follow our live coverage on abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Pride March in New York Infused With New Sense of Urgency
description: The annual parade included joyous celebration, but the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling and the threat to gay rights cast an undeniable shadow.
authors: By Matthew Haag, Chelsia Rose Marcius and Lauren McCarthy
text: The festivities began on Sunday with a familiar feel: Revelers adorned in a palette of bright colors, waving rainbow flags and handmade signs, tossed confetti into the air as the roar of screams and bikers revving their motorcycle engines signaled the start of the annual New York City Pride March in Manhattan.

title: How Democrats and Republicans explained the Roe fallout on Sunday talk shows.
description: Democrats used the ruling to criticize Republicans as threats to women and their health care providers, while G.O.P. leaders stressed that states will continue to determine policy on the issue.
text: On the first weekend after the Supreme Court overturned nearly five decades of constitutional abortion rights, Democrats seized on the ruling to portray their Republican opponents as threats to women and their health care providers, while two sitting G.O.P. governors welcomed the decision, as they tried to emphasize that the matter is a local issue with more “debate” to be had.

title: Your Monday Briefing: The End of Roe
description: Plus Russia strikes Kyiv as G7 leaders meet and a Times investigation into China’s surveillance state.
text: The U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on Friday, ending the constitutional right to an abortion after almost 50 years. The decision, expected after a draft opinion leaked in May, sent a seismic social and political shock through American life.

title: The Final Days of Mississippi’s Last Abortion Clinic
description: The Jackson Women’s Health Organization was at the center of the case that overturned Roe v. Wade. Already, supporters are planning new ways to help women in one of the poorest spots in the nation get access to abortions.
text: Follow our live updates on abortion news and the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: N.Y.C. Pride Marchers ‘Nervous’ After Court’s Abortion Ruling
description: Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
text: Revelers at the annual New York City Pride March expressed concern about the future of gay rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

title: Under Court’s Shadow, N.Y. Governor Candidates Lob Final Pitches
description: Rulings on abortion and guns shape the final weekend of campaigning before Tuesday’s primary.
text: A pair of seismic rulings by the Supreme Court jolted the race for governor of New York on Sunday, as Democrats and Republicans made final pitches to an electorate that found itself at the center of renewed national debates over guns and abortion rights.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The end of Roe v. Wade.
text: A Supreme Court ruling on Friday that overturned the constitutional right to abortion has unleashed a frenzy of activity. Anti-abortion forces plan to push for near-total bans in every state in the U.S., while abortion rights groups have vowed to fight back in the courts and push the Biden administration to do more to protect abortion rights.

title: Abortion Ruling Casts Shadow on Pride Festivities
description: The annual Pride parade returned to the streets of Manhattan, but this year the mood was one of protest.
text: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the sense of urgency that the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling added to the annual gay pride parade. We’ll also get a look at a sculpture by Jean Dubuffet that was all but forgotten for decades.

title: In Florida, California and Beyond: Both Sides Mobilize Over Abortion
description: On Monday, plaintiffs will ask a judge to block Florida’s law banning abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy. It is set to take effect on Friday.
text: Follow our live updates on abortion news and the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: The Supreme Court’s Fighting Words
description: Dobbs and Bruen reveal the sweeping terribleness of the current court’s reasoning.
authors: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
text: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. We’ve had two monumental Supreme Court decisions over the last week, on guns and abortion. Maybe it isn’t a fair question, but which of them scares, dismays, enrages or makes you want to bang your head against the wall more?

title: Here’s how companies are reacting to the Supreme Court decision on abortion.
text: Even as more companies have become outspoken on social causes, the reaction by corporate America on Friday after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade was relatively muted.

title: Inside Four Abortion Clinics the Day Roe Ended
description: We hear from clinic doctors and staff members about what Friday was like for them.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Diana Nguyen, Rob Szypko, Marc Georges, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
text: This episode contains strong language and mentions sexual assault.

title: What’s Next for California After Roe’s Reversal
description: About 10,600 more people are expected to come to California for abortion care each year, according to a U.C.L.A. report.
text: LOS ANGELES — Standing in front of a display of wire hangers at a protest downtown on Friday, hours after the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade, Gloria Allred told the crowd about an illegal abortion that almost killed her.

title: We Asked Our Readers for Their Abortion Stories. This Is What They Said.
description: The reality of abortion is nuanced, and the emotions involved are often unpredictable.
text: The reality of abortion is nuanced, and the emotions involved are often unpredictable.

title: Abortion Rights Groups Take Up the Fight in the States
description: Abortion rights advocates filed lawsuits to halt or delay bans on abortion in some states, with judges in Louisiana and Utah temporarily blocking new laws.
authors: By Shawn Hubler and Mitch Smith
text: SACRAMENTO — The battle over abortion shifted to the states on Monday as a weekend of furious protest and prayerful thanksgiving in the wake of the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade reversal gave way to a coast-to-coast wave of lawsuits, legislation and pitched political fights.

title: Georgia awaits a court ruling on a six-week abortion ban.
description: The state passed one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country in 2019. But it has never been enforced, pending court decisions.
text: In 2019, Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia signed one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the country, effectively outlawing the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy. But the measure has never been enforced. That could soon change.

title: Florida health care providers urge a judge to block the state’s new abortion ban.
description: They argued that a ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy would violate the state constitution.
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Health care providers argued before a Florida judge on Monday that the state’s new ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy violates the state constitution, and urged the court to block its enforcement.

title: These Companies Will Cover Travel Expenses for Employee Abortions
description: Dozens of companies have committed to helping their employees get access to reproductive care.
text: After the Supreme Court’s ruling on Friday that ended federal abortion rights, several companies released statements reaffirming their commitment to helping employees gain access to health care services they may not be able to obtain in their state.

title: A Louisiana judge temporarily blocks enforcement of the state’s ‘trigger law.’
description: The judge’s order allows clinics to continue providing abortion services for now.
text: At least one of Louisiana’s three remaining abortion clinics said it would resume performing the procedure after a judge on Monday temporarily blocked enforcement of the state’s abortion “trigger laws.”

title: America Before and After Roe
description: Three women lived through a time without Roe, and the early years after it. Their experiences working for abortion rights mimic the fight that continues today.
text: Catherine Starr was 17 when she attended her first demonstration to push for abortion rights outside City Hall in St. Louis. It was May 24, 1973. Just a few months earlier, the Supreme Court had ruled on Roe v. Wade.

title: After Dobbs: What Can Be Done?
description: Readers suggest compromise legislation, offshore abortion clinics, expanding the Supreme Court and more. Also: Justices Thomas and Kavanaugh; Mike Pence; bathing suits.
text: To the Editor:

title: When an Abortion Story Is Told as a Caper, Thriller or Farce
description: As Roe falls, new works including a documentary, a feature film and a comedy show disrupt the taboos and clichés around abortion.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Ocasio-Cortez wants two justices impeached for ‘lying under oath.’
description: The representative called for a House investigation into whether the justices, Neil Gorsuch and Brett M. Kavanaugh, were dishonest when discussing Roe v. Wade during confirmation hearings.
text: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is calling for a House investigation into whether two Supreme Court justices who voted to overturn Roe v. Wade should be impeached for lying at their confirmation hearings about their views of the landmark abortion-rights case.

title: What is the difference between Plan B and the abortion pill?
description: Both medications come in pill form and are often confused for each other. Here’s how they differ.
text: In the wake of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, some women are evaluating their options for reproductive health care. Many are stocking up on morning-after pills, which are used to prevent a pregnancy from occurring within days after unprotected sex; while others are wondering how the ruling will affect their access to abortion pills, which can be used to terminate early pregnancies.

title: Companies Scramble to Work Out Policies Related to Employee Abortions
description: Some have offered to cover travel and other expenses for employees, and are working to ease worker fears about safety and confidentiality.
text: There is no clear blueprint for corporate engagement on abortion. After numerous companies came forward to announce that they would cover travel expenses for their employees to get abortions, executives have had to move swiftly to both sort out the mechanics of those policies and explain them to a work force concerned about confidentiality and safety.

title: A Rhode Island candidate was charged after a video showed him punching an opponent at an abortion protest.
description: Jeann Lugo, a Republican and off-duty police officer, was suspended by the Providence Police Department after striking Jennifer Rourke, a Democrat, the authorities said.
text: Soon after a video appeared to capture a Republican State Senate candidate and off-duty police officer punching his Democratic opponent, a woman, at an abortion protest in Rhode Island, he was arrested and charged — and he withdrew from the race.

title: California lawmakers place a constitutional amendment protecting abortion rights on the fall ballot.
description: The amendment would explicitly protect reproductive rights in the state.
text: SACRAMENTO — California state lawmakers on Monday put a state constitutional amendment on the ballot that would explicitly protect reproductive rights, moving swiftly on the first business day after the Supreme Court reversed Roe v. Wade.

title: A Couple’s Long Journey in the Anti-Abortion Movement
description: As the fall of Roe v. Wade rocked the country, Carrie and Roger Severino celebrated the realization of decades of work that has been complicated in recent years by health challenges.
text: In the early 2000s, Harvard Right to Life, the university’s chapter of a student organization that opposes abortion, had T-shirts made that say, “Working for the Class of ’25” on the back. Another shirt from that era reads: “Smile! Your mom chose life.”

title: Lessons From the Terrible Triumph of the Anti-Abortion Movement
description: What pro-choice activists can learn from their enemies.
text: In the grief-choked days since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, I’ve been haunted by a moment from the new documentary “Battleground.” Much of the film, which recently premiered at the Tribeca Film Festival, follows female leaders of the anti-abortion movement, including Marjorie Dannenfelser, president of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America, and Kristan Hawkins, president of Students for Life of America. These aren’t the people regularly standing outside of abortion clinics harassing patients. They are, rather, savvy lobbyists and organizers, and the documentary is in part a window into how they won.

title: When Brazil Banned Abortion Pills, Women Turned to Drug Traffickers
description: With Roe v. Wade overturned, states banning abortion are looking to prevent the distribution of abortion medication. Brazil shows the possible consequences.
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Last November, Xaiana, a 23-year-old college student in northern Brazil, began exchanging text messages with a drug dealer in the south of the country. Following the dealer’s instructions, she transferred 1,500 reais ($285), her living expenses for several months. Then, she waited three agonizing weeks for the arrival in the mail of a blister pack of eight unmarked white pills.

title: The New U.S. Abortion Map
description: What access to the procedure now looks like across America.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Sydney Harper, Eric Krupke, M.J. Davis Lin, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
text: In the days since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, states have rushed to either ban, restrict or protect abortion.

title: ‘Deeply Concerned’: 6 College Presidents on the Abortion Ruling
description: Six college presidents react to the overturning of Roe v. Wade. Also: A Supreme Court ruling on religion; Vladimir Putin’s designs; a Democratic strategy.
text: To the Editor:

title: State Battles Are Defining the Shifting Abortion Landscape
description: An absolute abortion ban that Texas wrote before Roe v. Wade is on hold while a long-ago ban in Wisconsin reaches the courts. A previously blocked six-week ban in Tennessee has taken effect.
authors: By Neelam Bohra and Shawn Hubler
text: A state-by-state legal battle in the wake of the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling widened on Tuesday as a judge in Texas temporarily blocked a statewide abortion ban, a federal court let Tennessee tighten existing restrictions, Iowa Republicans said they would ask courts to clear the way for a ban from the moment fetal cardiac activity could be detected, and Wisconsin Democrats announced they were filing suit to halt the resurrection of abortion laws dating to the 19th century.

title: Biden’s Health Secretary: ‘No Magic Bullet’ for Preserving Abortion Access
description: With the White House under pressure to push back on the Supreme Court’s abortion ruling, the health secretary unveiled steps aimed at preserving access to abortion.
authors: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Charlie Savage
text: WASHINGTON — As Democrats and reproductive rights advocates clamored for President Biden to forcefully counter the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade, his health secretary, Xavier Becerra, stepped up to a lectern here on Tuesday to list the steps his department would take to preserve and expand access to abortion.

title: What Is Ectopic Pregnancy?
description: Some women and health care providers have concerns about how this rare but life-threatening pregnancy complication will be treated now that Roe v. Wade has been overturned.
text: In the wake of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, which eliminated the constitutional right to abortion access, women and health care providers nationwide are asking how the ruling will affect reproductive health care more broadly.

title: For Many Women, Roe Was About More Than Abortion. It Was About Freedom.
description: After the reversal of Roe v. Wade, some women are reconsidering their plans, including where they live, and wondering how best to channel their anger.
text: CHICAGO — Countless women wept. Some spent the weekend burning white-hot with rage, commiserating with friends and mothers and sisters. Many were fearful, recognizing the feeling of a freedom being taken away and thinking to themselves: This could only get worse.

title: This Is What a Post-Roe Abortion Looks Like
description: Self-managed abortion is not a substitute for having full reproductive rights. But it’s one of the best tools we have right now.
authors: By Ora DeKornfeld, Emily Holzknecht and Jonah M. Kessel
text: Self-managed abortion is not a substitute for having full reproductive rights. But it’s one of the best tools we have right now.

title: Illinois Abortion Clinics Prepare for Rush of Patients After Roe
description: The 67 clinics operating in neighboring states could stop offering abortions or close altogether, sending thousands more patients to Illinois.
text: The 67 clinics operating in neighboring states could stop offering abortions or close altogether, sending thousands more patients to Illinois.

title: This Is What a Post-Roe Abortion Looks Like
description: Self-managed abortion is not a substitute for having full reproductive rights. But it’s one of the best tools we have right now.
authors: By Ora DeKornfeld, Emily Holzknecht and Jonah M. Kessel
text: This is the true story of a 27-year-old Texas woman and her abortion.

title: When Reproductive Choice Is a Family Value
description: What it’s like to be a second-generation director of a North Carolina abortion clinic.
text: Calla Hales said she wore her bulletproof vest to work on Saturday for the first time in a long time. Hales is the executive director of A Preferred Women’s Health Center, a clinic that provides abortion care in Charlotte, N.C., and has branches in Raleigh, N.C.; Augusta, Ga.; and Atlanta. She’s always worried about her safety, because of the endless stream of threats that abortion providers get. But when I talked to her last week, Hales was dubious about how useful the vest is: It doesn’t cover her entire body so she knows it won’t necessarily save her life.

title: Payment Data Could Become Evidence of Abortion, Now Illegal in Some States
description: Financial companies collect a lot of payment data from customers. Prosecutors could subpoena those records for evidence of abortion, legal experts say.
authors: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
text: Digital payments are the default for millions of women of childbearing age. So what will their credit and debit card issuers and financial app providers do when prosecutors seek their transaction data during abortion investigations?

title: Pelosi Received Communion at Vatican After Meeting With Pope
description: The sacrament has become a political issue, with conservative American bishops like House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s own priest, who has said he will deny her the sacrament until she stops publicly supporting abortion rights.
text: ROME — U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, an avid defender of abortion rights, met privately with Pope Francis on Wednesday and received communion from a priest during a papal Mass at St. Peter’s Basilica, according to an attendee.

title: First Amendment Confrontation May Loom in Post-Roe Fight
description: Without a federal right to abortion, questions about how states can regulate speech about it suddenly become much murkier.
text: The Supreme Court declared clearly last week that there is no federal right to abortion. But how the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization affects the right to talk about abortion remains far from settled, teeing up what legal experts said was a looming confrontation over whether the First Amendment allows censoring speech about a medical procedure that will become illegal in much of the country.

title: As Big Business Is Accused of Becoming ‘Woke,’ Small Business Is Looking to Go Its Own Way
