description: There’s now a more conservative alternative to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.
text: Big Business and the Republican Party used to be as close as Tweedledum and Tweedledee, but not anymore. On social issues such as abortion and race, the Republican Party has moved to the right while many big corporations have shifted left in an effort to please their diverse mix of employees and customers. Many companies embraced Black Lives Matter. Now a number are promising to cover travel expenses for employees who need to go to another state to get an abortion.

title: How Zeldin’s Anti-Abortion Stance May Affect the N.Y. Governor’s Race
description: Representative Lee Zeldin, the Republican nominee for governor, said the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade was a victory for family, life and the Constitution.
text: The confetti was still falling at her Democratic primary victory party Tuesday night when Gov. Kathy Hochul rolled out a general election warning: If her Republican opponent wins in November, he could follow the Supreme Court’s lead and curtail New Yorkers’ abortion rights.

title: In States Banning Abortion, a Growing Rift Over Enforcement
description: A reluctance by some liberal district attorneys to bring criminal charges against abortion providers is already complicating the legal landscape in some states.
authors: By J. David Goodman and Jack Healy
text: HOUSTON — Deep rifts have emerged among the hundreds of elected district attorneys who will be charged with enforcing the expanding restrictions on abortion, creating a Balkanized new legal system within states that are banning the procedure.

title: The Lightning Rod Issue That Looms Over the Governor’s Race
description: Lee Zeldin, the Republican candidate, is anti-abortion, while Gov. Kathy Hochul is a strong backer of abortion rights.
text: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at how the abortion issue divides the two major-party candidates for governor. We’ll also find out why dolphins are making a comeback in New York Harbor.

title: Deleting Your Period Tracker Won’t Protect You
description: Tweets telling women to do that went viral after Roe v. Wade was overturned, but experts say other digital data are more likely to reveal an illegal abortion.
text: In May 1972, the Chicago police raided a high-rise apartment where a group called the Jane Collective was providing abortions. It was the year before the Supreme Court’s Roe v. Wade decision gave women the constitutional right to decide whether to give birth, and abortion was a criminal offense in Illinois.

title: A Powerful Court
description: In other advanced democracies, the courts are more restrained.
text: By now, most of us are used to U.S. Supreme Court rulings that bring big changes to American life — on abortion, guns, same-sex marriage and more. This morning may bring another sweeping ruling, on climate change.

title: Reconsidering Privacy Risks After Roe
description: Many women are worried that their data might be used against them — whether it’s period tracking apps, digital receipts or other information collected by companies.
authors: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
text: In the post-Roe era, when abortion may be illegal in much of the country, many women are worried that their data might be used against them — whether it’s digital receipts, period tracking apps or the vast trove of personal information collected and disseminated every day by tech companies large and small.

title: Biden, Chiding Court, Endorses Ending Filibuster to Codify Abortion Rights
description: The president called the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade “destabilizing’’ and said Congress needed to act to codify it into law.
authors: By Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
text: MADRID — President Biden on Thursday condemned what he called the “outrageous behavior” of the Supreme Court in overturning Roe v. Wade and said for the first time that he supported ending the filibuster to protect a woman’s right to an abortion and a broader constitutional right to privacy.

title: Media companies expand health coverage after the Supreme Court abortion ruling.
description: News organizations join other businesses that will reimburse employees who need to travel to access reproductive health care.
text: Since the Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion, some media companies have wrestled with a complex issue: how to balance their news coverage with the desire to expand their policies to protect reproductive health care for their employees.

title: Florida Judge Will Temporarily Block 15-Week Abortion Ban
description: The ban, passed by Republican lawmakers and signed by Gov. Ron DeSantis, is scheduled to take effect on Friday.
text: MIAMI — A law banning abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy violates privacy protections in the Florida Constitution, a state judge ruled on Thursday, a day before the new restrictions were to take effect.

title: Post-Roe, Her Facebook Group Went Viral
description: Veronica Risinger made a little online spot for neighbors to share information on abortion. Then 30,000 people joined.
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade on Friday, Veronica Risinger started what she thought would be a tiny Facebook group for her neighbors in Kansas City., Mo., to share resources for people seeking abortions.

title: Abortion on the Ballot: ‘Remember, You Are Alone in the Voting Booth’
description: Voters, Republican and Democratic, discuss the politics of abortion. Also: Gerrymandering; the Ukraine war; “stolen” elections; a constitutional convention.
text: To the Editor:

title: Is the Right to Same-Sex Marriage Next?
description: Why the Supreme Court should not overturn the right to same-sex marriage.
text: While the Supreme Court’s opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization is already catastrophic in its effects on reproductive rights and the equal treatment of women in this country, it has also led to speculation that the court’s conservative supermajority is just getting started in rolling back fundamental rights. To be sure, Justice Samuel Alito’s majority opinion is at pains to say that “nothing in this opinion should be understood to cast doubt on precedents that do not concern abortion.” Yet that statement rings false.

title: The Single Best Guide I’ve Heard to the Supreme Court’s Rightward Shift
description: The legal scholar Kate Shaw walks me through the Supreme Court’s decades-long conservative counterrevolution.
text: In the past few weeks alone, the Supreme Court has delivered a firestorm of conservative legal victories. States now have far less leeway to restrict gun permits. The right to abortion is no longer constitutionally protected. The Environmental Protection Agency has been kneecapped in its ability to regulate carbon emissions, and by extension, all executive branch agencies will see their power significantly diminished.

title: America’s Post-Roe Chaos Is Here
description: The reality of criminalized abortion is going to shock people.
text: It’s chaos out there.

title: What Makes a Fetus a Person?
description: The unborn child’s state of existential dependence upon its mother, not its autonomy, makes it especially entitled to care, nurture and legal protection.
text: Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization has returned the issue of abortion to legislatures. There, pro-lifers will work to ensure that unborn children in every jurisdiction are protected by law. Though individual states can (and already have) sought to protect the most vulnerable human beings through ordinary legislation, constitutional protection of unborn children as equal “persons” under the law remains the movement’s ultimate — if elusive — goal.

title: Who Will Help Care for Texas’ Post-Roe Babies?
description: Even some anti-abortion adherents say Texas is failing families left impoverished by its war against abortion.
authors: By Elizabeth Williamson and Erin Schaff
text: ARGYLE, Texas — Two days after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, a 27-year-old woman delivered her fourth child, a boy she named Cason. Born after his mother fled from domestic abuse and was denied an abortion, he is among the first of many post-Roe babies expected in Texas.

title: An Abortion Rights Champion of the 1970s on Life Before and After Roe
description: Fifty years ago, Nancy Stearns, a lawyer, was on the front lines of the battle to secure legal access to terminations for American women.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Clare Toeniskoetter, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell, Corey Schreppel and Chris Wood
text: A little over 50 years ago, Nancy Stearns, a young lawyer, was presenting a case in New York with a bold legal assertion: that the right to abortion was fundamental to equal rights for women.

title: A Transformative Term at the Most Conservative Supreme Court in Nearly a Century
description: The blockbuster decisions — on abortion, guns, religion and climate — told part of the story. But the court’s abrupt rightward shift ran through its entire docket.
authors: By Adam Liptak and Alicia Parlapiano
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court moved relentlessly to the right in its first full term with a six-justice conservative majority, issuing far-reaching decisions that will transform American life. It eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, recognized a Second Amendment right to carry guns outside the home, made it harder to address climate change and expanded the role of religion in public life.

title: New York Moves to Enshrine Abortion Rights in State Constitution
description: The Equal Rights Amendment prohibits discrimination against anyone based on race, ethnicity, national origin, disability or sex — specifically sexual orientation, gender identity and expression, and pregnancy.
text: ALBANY, N.Y. — The New York State Legislature on Friday passed a measure that, if fully enacted, would enshrine in the State Constitution the right to seek an abortion and access contraception.

title: In Louisiana, Abortion Clinics Stay Open on Borrowed Time
description: On July 8, a judge will consider whether an abortion ban can go forward. Until then, a Shreveport facility intends to serve as many women as possible.
text: On July 8, a judge will consider whether an abortion ban can go forward. Until then, a Shreveport facility intends to serve as many women as possible.

title: Will Companies Help Their Employees Get Abortions?
description: There’s no ducking this fight.
text: Like it or not, business owners are being sucked into the fight over abortion. Now that the Supreme Court has ended the federal protection of abortion rights, the battle has moved on to whether companies will help their employees get abortions in any way, including by reimbursing them for expenses to travel out of state to obtain a legal procedure.

title: What’s happening in the states? Here’s the latest on which abortion laws are in effect and which are blocked.
description: Eight states have now outlawed abortion, including Texas, which allowed a 1925 law to go into effect on Friday night.
text: A tug of war over the future of abortion access is playing out in courts across the United States after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, adding to a legal landscape defined by uncertainty, confusion and rapid change.

title: Inside the Extreme Effort to Punish Women for Abortion
description: Abortion “abolitionists” are the outer edge of the anti-abortion movement. They’re looking to gain followers after the decision to overturn Roe, unsettling mainstream anti-abortion groups.
text: Hours after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last week, a man with a wiry, squared-off beard and a metal cross around his neck celebrated with his team at a Brazilian steakhouse. He pulled out his phone to livestream to his followers.

title: Google Says It Will Delete Location Data When Users Visit Abortion Clinics
description: Under pressure from employees and supporters of reproductive rights, the company announced privacy changes for the post-Roe era.
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google said on Friday that it would delete abortion clinic visits from the location history of its users, in the company’s first effort to address how it will handle sensitive data in the wake of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade.

title: N.Y. Lawmakers Respond on Guns and Abortion After Supreme Court Rulings
description: Lawmakers passed measures that would prohibit concealed weapons in many public places, as well as an amendment that would initiate the process of enshrining the right to abortion in the State Constitution.
authors: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Nicholas Fandos
text: A week after the Supreme Court issued monumental rulings loosening restrictions on carrying guns and overturning the constitutional right to abortion, New York enacted sweeping measures designed to blunt the decisions’ effects.

title: What Is the ‘Abortion Abolitionist’ Movement?
description: How a fringe faction has started to gain steam post Roe.
text: How a fringe faction has started to gain steam post Roe.

title: The Federal Government Subsidizes Abortions. Will That Last?
description: Individuals can often use health insurance or flexible spending accounts to pay for abortions or deduct the cost on tax returns. Congress might weigh in.
authors: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
text: In the United States, you can get a tax deduction for your abortion if your overall health care expenses are high enough. That didn’t change with the Supreme Court’s ruling last week.

title: When Where You Work Determines if You Can Get an Abortion
description: After the Dobbs v. Jackson decision, many women are discovering that their employer can shape major decisions in their lives even more than it did a week ago.
text: When Breanna Dietrich was 18 and working at a restaurant in West Virginia, she got pregnant. The father was a man she knew she wouldn’t marry. She considered getting an abortion. But the nearest clinic was four hours away and she couldn’t afford to take off work — so she had the baby girl.

title: Seeing Norma: The Conflicted Life of the Woman at the Center of Roe v. Wade
description: Norma McCorvey, the plaintiff in the case that made abortion legal, struggled with her role. Her personal papers offer insight into her life, her thinking — and her continued relevance.
text: Norma McCorvey, the Jane Roe at the center of Roe v. Wade, was an imperfect plaintiff.

title: Spurred by the Supreme Court, a Nation Divides Along a Red-Blue Axis
description: On abortion, climate change, guns and much more, two Americas — one liberal, one conservative — are moving in opposite directions.
text: Pressed by Supreme Court decisions diminishing rights that liberals hold dear and expanding those cherished by conservatives, the United States appears to be drifting apart into separate nations, with diametrically opposed social, environmental and health policies.

title: Texas Supreme Court Lifts Freeze on Abortion Ban
description: The decision, overturning a lower court ruling that had temporarily blocked the ban, allowed a 1925 law to take effect.
text: The Texas Supreme Court allowed a 1925 law banning abortion to take effect late on Friday night, overturning a lower court ruling that had temporarily blocked it.

title: An Anti-Abortion Victory, but ‘at What Price’?
description: Readers react to a column by Ross Douthat and a guest essay by an anti-abortion advocate.
text: To the Editor:

title: Gridlock in Congress Has Amplified the Power of the Supreme Court
description: What was once a dialogue between the branches has become almost entirely one-sided, with the justices accumulating clout at lawmakers’ expense.
text: WASHINGTON — On the last day of a turbulent term that included rulings on what the Constitution has to say about abortion, guns and religion, the Supreme Court issued another sort of decision, one that turned on the words of the Clean Air Act.

title: The Long Path to Reclaim Abortion Rights
description: The Supreme Court decision to reverse Roe, far from settling the matter, instead has launched court and political battles across the states likely to go on for years.
text: Attempting to recover from their staggering loss in the Supreme Court, abortion rights groups have mounted a multilevel legal and political attack aimed at blocking and reversing abortion bans in courts and at ballot boxes across the country.

title: Supreme Court Marshal Asks Officials to End Protests at Justices’ Homes
description: One official criticized the request, saying that the federal government was primarily responsible for ensuring the safety of justices and their families.
text: WASHINGTON — The chief security officer of the Supreme Court has asked that Virginia and Maryland officials enforce laws that would prohibit protests outside the homes of justices after weeks of demonstrations favoring abortion rights.

title: ‘The Pro-Life Generation’: Young Women Fight Against Abortion Rights
description: Many American women mourned the Supreme Court decision to overturn Roe, but for others it is a moment of triumph and a matter of human rights.
text: DALLAS — The rollback of abortion rights has been received by many American women with a sense of shock and fear, and warnings about an ominous decline in women’s status as full citizens.

title: The Persistent Myth That Restricting Abortion Rights Won’t Affect the Rich
description: The notion that rich women will be fine, regardless of what the law says, is probably comforting to some. But it is simply not true.
text: If there’s one assumption about abortion rights that’s accepted across the ideological spectrum, it’s this: The Supreme Court’s reversal of Roe v. Wade will mostly affect the poor; rich women will still have access to abortions when they need them.

title: Abortion Laws Around the World
description: The U.S. Supreme Court’s ruling on abortion quickly led to bans in at least eight states, a shift toward criminalization that runs counter to recent easings in countries that had longstanding bans.
text: The Supreme Court’s elimination of the constitutional right to abortion, after nearly a half-century, has made the United States one of the few countries actively strengthening abortion restrictions.

title: America the Imperfect, on the Fourth of July
description: Reflections on America, in response to a column by Pamela Paul. Also: School safety; Microsoft and unions; abortion pills; God and miscarriages.
text: To the Editor:

title: The Culture War That More Christians Should Be Fighting
description: If we don’t talk about economic justice, we are advancing an emaciated view of Christian political engagement.
text: Let’s talk about the culture war we should be fighting. When we think of what’s important to the “religious right” or to “white evangelicals,” the focus tends to be on social issues: abortion, the role of religion in public life, conflicts around sexual orientation and gender identity, and lately, controversy over critical race theory.

title: Abortion, Like Prohibition, Has a Clear Racial Dimension
description: How long before this unpopular repression also loses favor and falls into decline?
text: Last week, David Frum wrote a fascinating article for The Atlantic comparing our current abortion battle to Prohibition, another contentious issue that bitterly divided the nation. After a long, “titanic” struggle, the temperance movement succeeded in imposing a nationwide ban on alcohol — only to have it decline and collapse 13 years later.

title: Quotation of the Day: Strategic Shift in Bid to Regain Abortion Rights
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 4, 2022.
text: “We’re in a chess game and we haven’t gotten checkmate. We’re doing check, check, check, check. Unfortunately, we’re doing check, check, check with pregnant people and their families’ lives.”

title: In a Post-Roe World, We Can Avoid Pitting Mothers Against Babies
description: Especially in hard cases like ectopic pregnancy, we can offer more love and material support to mothers and children.
text: Now that the Supreme Court has overturned Roe v. Wade, states face a new reality about where to draw the line in pregnancy for when abortion is permitted. In these debates, ectopic pregnancy is a key issue.

title: Where the Risks of Pregnancy Meet Abortion Laws and Health Care
description: Even before the wave of abortion bans, medical treatment and advice for pregnancy has largely focused on fetal safety over the mother’s.
text: As the United States has grappled with the unfolding consequences of the Supreme Court’s decision overruling Roe v. Wade, one question lurks between the lines of court opinions and news stories alike: Why are the risks of pregnancy so rarely discussed anywhere, even though that information is relevant not just to individual decisions but to policies about abortion, pregnancy, and health care for women?

title: Will the Abortion Debate Keep Moderate Women in the Democrats’ Camp?
description: Worried about inflation and dissatisfied with President Biden, many moderate women have been drifting away from Democrats. Now the party hopes the fight for abortion rights will drive them back.
text: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — As Gov. Gretchen Whitmer prepared to kick off a round-table discussion about abortion rights at a brewery recently, Alisha Meneely sat at one corner of the table, feeling politically abandoned.

title: Infertility Patients and Doctors Fear Abortion Bans Could Restrict I.V.F.
description: The new state bans don’t explicitly cover embryos created outside the womb, but legal experts say overturning Roe could make it easier to place controls on genetic testing, storage and disposal of them.
text: Anna Nibley Baker, a mother of four in Salt Lake City, is reasonably certain that she and her husband are done building their family. Yet for eight years, since the birth of her last child, conceived through in vitro fertilization, she has thought tenderly of the couple’s three remaining embryos, frozen and stored at a university clinic.

title: Next Front Line in the Abortion Wars: State Supreme Courts
description: Court challenges to sweeping rollbacks of abortion rights must go through state supreme courts, many of which have been shaped by years of conservative activism.
text: WASHINGTON — Fresh from the political thicket of the United States Supreme Court, the struggle over abortion is now moving to venues that are poised to become the next front line in the country’s partisan warfare: state supreme courts.

title: Americans Are Losing Their Right to Not Conform
description: The freedom to define oneself has deep roots in the American traditions of pluralism and independence.
text: On June 24 the Supreme Court laid waste to Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey on the grounds that the right to an abortion is not enumerated in the Constitution and is not deeply rooted in the history and traditions of the United States. As many commentators have noted, similar objections could be lodged against precedents like Griswold v. Connecticut, Lawrence v. Texas and Obergefell v. Hodges, which recognize constitutional protections for contraception, sex and marriage.

title: Roe Is Dead. How Will Democrats and the G.O.P. Evolve Without It?
description: Michelle Goldberg and Ross Douthat on what comes next for Democrats and Republicans.
text: For nearly 50 years, the issue of abortion has driven voters of all persuasions to the polls. But now that Roe v. Wade has been overturned and the question of reproductive rights has been returned to the states, America’s political parties are going to have to figure out how to metabolize that energy in the years ahead. To discuss what comes next for Democrats and Republicans alike, host Jane Coaston is joined by Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg. As colleagues, they’ve been debating abortion with each other, on this podcast and in the pages of the paper, for years.

title: China Offers Women Perks for Having Babies. Single Moms Don’t Qualify.
description: Beijing is giving incentives to stem a demographic crisis, but its control over childbirth and its suppression of women’s rights are making it difficult for some aspiring parents to start a family.
text: When Chan Zhang heard about the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, she was baffled that Americans were still arguing over abortion rights.

title: The Latest on Abortion in the States
description: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down Roe v. Wade, there has been a flurry of activity in the states as officials move to prohibit or expand abortion access.
text: In the aftermath of the Supreme Court striking down Roe v. Wade, there has been a flurry of activity in the states as officials move to prohibit or expand abortion access.

title: An Anti-Abortion Campaigner on the Movement’s Historic Win
description: James Bopp, chief lawyer for the National Right to Life Committee, says that overturning Roe v. Wade is only the halfway point.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachel Quester, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Jessica Cheung, Stella Tan, Lisa Chow, Liz O. Baylen, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
text: After Roe v. Wade was decided in 1973, a group of conservative lawyers embarked on what would become a decades-long mission to reverse the ruling.

title: Match Group suspends some political donations after abortion ruling.
description: The operator of Tinder, Hinge and other dating sites said it would no longer give money to groups representing Republican and Democratic attorneys general.
text: Facing scrutiny for donations to the Republican Attorneys General Association, whose members supported the overturning of Roe v. Wade, Match Group says it will suspend further contributions to the association as well as the Democratic Attorneys General Association.

title: After Roe, South Carolina Considers More Restrictions on Abortion
description: The state legislature was the first to step into a post-Roe world, clearing the path for full bans in other conservative states.
authors: By Richard Fausset and Ava Sasani
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Nearly two weeks after the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion established by Roe v. Wade, South Carolina lawmakers became the first to consider more restrictive legislation.

title: Democrats Can Win if They Embrace the Politics of Fear
description: The right learned to use fear as a political weapon. Now Democrats must beat them at their own game.
text: When it comes to abortion rights, the Democrats need to lean into the politics of fear.

title: With Roe Overturned, Austin’s Loss Could Be Brooklyn’s Gain
description: Cities around the South have challenged the supremacy of coastal supercities, drawing a steady flow of creative young people. Will new abortion bans put an end to that?
text: Imagine that you are a young woman setting out on your adult life in the United States of America in 2022. College is behind you; fulfilling personal and professional ambitions in a stimulating place is meant to come next. Ten or 20 years ago, depending on your interests, you might have moved, as if by reflex, to New York or Chicago, to Los Angeles or San Francisco. But those cities have become only more punishingly expensive. The average rental price of an apartment in Brooklyn is now $3,500, up 12 percent over last year, when we were still lingering in the misguided belief that the pandemic had perhaps changed the city irrevocably toward the softer and more accessible. (In Manhattan, the figure jumped 32 percent to $4,800.)

title: Covering a Pre- and Post-Roe World
description: Margot Sanger-Katz, a domestic correspondent who writes about health care for The Upshot, shares how previous reporting helped readers understand the future of abortion access in the United States.
text: In July 2019, The Upshot, an arm of The New York Times that focuses on data-driven journalism, published the article “Where Roe v. Wade Has the Biggest Effect.” Written by the journalists Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Quoctrung Bui, the article examined what would happen if Roe v. Wade was to be overturned — Where would the number of legal abortions fall? What might happen in states with so-called trigger laws, which would ban abortion almost immediately? Using research, it estimated what could happen under various scenarios, and with maps, displayed what at that point was an alternate reality.

title: Under Pressure, Biden Issues Executive Order on Abortion
description: After the Supreme Court’s ruling, some of the president’s supporters have wanted him to push harder to protect abortion access. But details about what his new order will do remain unclear.
authors: By Michael D. Shear and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
text: WASHINGTON — Under pressure to do more to respond to the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, President Biden issued an executive order on Friday designed to ensure access to abortion medication and emergency contraception while preparing for legal fights to come.

title: What’s Next for Abortion Rights in New York?
description: Before Roe v. Wade, New York City was a haven for women from across the country. Decades later, a new generation of advocates has vowed that it will remain so.
authors: By Karen Zraick and Hurubie Meko
text: New York has long been at the forefront of the push for abortion access. The state legalized the procedure three years before the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973. Thousands of women flooded in from other states, soon outnumbering the number of New York residents getting abortions.

title: Clergy’s Call for an Assault Weapons Ban
description: Clergy and spiritual leaders in upstate New York issue a plea for gun control. Also: Learning from Britain; abortion travel; dividing America; museums.
text: To the Editor:

title: Biden Signs Executive Order to Protect Abortion Access
description: President Biden issued an order aiming to protect access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, but details on how those goals would be accomplished were not outlined.
text: President Biden issued an order aiming to protect access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, but details on how those goals would be accomplished were not outlined.

title: What the Biden Administration Could Do Now to Protect Abortion Rights
description: The most urgent step the federal government can take is to ensure access to medication abortion.
text: Barely two weeks have passed since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, and already chaos reigns. Several states are moving to ban abortion almost completely, abortion-rights proponents are challenging those bans in court and in some cases, judges have been asked to issue injunctions that could, for a time, prevent the bans from going into effect.

title: Louisiana Judge Allows Abortion Ban to Take Effect
description: The fast-changing status in the state is emblematic of the chaotic national landscape that has unfolded in the two weeks since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Ava Sasani and Kate Zernike
text: A judge in Louisiana allowed state laws banning nearly all abortions to take effect on Friday, lifting an earlier court decision that had temporarily blocked them.

title: How Mexico’s Top Justice, Raised Catholic, Became an Abortion Rights Champion
description: Influenced by feminists close to him, the chief of the country’s Supreme Court helped pave the way for decriminalization of the procedure.
text: MEXICO CITY — When the chief justice of Mexico’s Supreme Court began voting in favor of abortion rights, his toughest opponents were the people closest to him.

title: The End of Roe Doesn’t Need to Bring an Increase in Maternal Mortality
description: Many of Europe’s abortion laws are stricter than many Americans may realize, but maternal health outcomes in Europe are much better.
text: It has been argued repeatedly that without access to abortion, the health of women will suffer and women will die. This fear is expressed overtly by the three dissenting justices in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the decision that overturned Roe v. Wade last month. They cite experts who say that “a ban on abortions increases maternal mortality by 21 percent.”

title: More Than 1,000 Protesters at White House Call on Biden to Protect Abortion Rights
description: The rally on Saturday, in which some demonstrators risked arrest, reflected activists’ growing frustration with the administration.
authors: By Stephanie Lai and Ava Sasani
text: WASHINGTON — One day after President Biden issued an executive order designed to ensure access to abortion medication and emergency contraception, more than a thousand protesters gathered in front of the White House, with hundreds risking arrest by sitting at the building’s gates, to urge Mr. Biden to do more.

title: A Ruling From Outside the Court: ‘Shame’ on the Justices
description: It’s the readers’ turn to judge ... the Supreme Court’s recently ended term. Also: Anti-abortion activists; banning AR-15s; Australian slang.
text: To the Editor:

title: Is Society Finally Ready for Male Birth Control?
description: We are developing new hormonal contraceptives for men. Post-Roe, our work is more critical than ever.
authors: By Stephanie Page and John Amory
text: Over 40 percent of the six million annual pregnancies in the United States are unplanned, according to the latest data available, and about one in five pregnancies ends in abortion. With the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade, and the resulting loss of access to safe abortion care for millions of Americans, it is more critical than ever to prevent unplanned pregnancies. The use of an effective method of contraception is the best way to do so.

title: Even if Republicans Outlaw Abortion, Americans Will Soon Rebel
description: Prohibition couldn’t even last 14 years. Will an abortion ban last that long?
text: A movement that seeks to compel Americans to live according to a stringent moral code may be most vulnerable when it succeeds.

title: Hochul’s Vow to Fix Albany’s Culture Finds an Unexpected Foe: Herself
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she would usher in a “new era of transparency.” But critics, including the state comptroller’s office, said she has failed to do so.
text: ALBANY — In the last days of the 2022 legislative session, as the State Capitol was abuzz with frenzied pushes to strengthen gun control, abortion rights and environmental regulations, New York lawmakers received a jolting email.

title: F.D.A. to Weigh Over-the-Counter Sale of Contraceptive Pills
description: The first U.S. application for sale of a nonprescription birth control pill has taken on new meaning after the Supreme Court decision ending the constitutional right to abortion.
authors: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Kate Kelly
text: WASHINGTON — More than 60 years after the approval of oral contraceptives revolutionized women’s sexual health, the Food and Drug Administration has received its first application for a birth control pill sold over the counter — just as the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has put access to contraception more squarely at the heart of the clash over reproductive rights.

title: States With Abortion Bans Risk Losing Their Economic Edge
description: The Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade has prompted Democratic governors to pitch their states as better alternatives for business.
text: As a group of conservative states enacted severe abortion restrictions last year, Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois sent letters to a handful of corporate executives with close ties to Texas.

title: The Right to Travel in a Post-Roe World
description: In a concurring opinion last month, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh said the Constitution did not allow states to stop women from traveling to get abortions. But the issue is more complicated than that.
text: WASHINGTON — Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh signed the recent majority opinion that overruled Roe v. Wade. He also issued a 12-page concurring opinion, writing only for himself. He wanted to discuss, he wrote, “the future implications” of the decision.

title: On Abortion Laws, It All Goes Back to 2010
description: How a “red wave” led to restrictions at the state level that, in most cases, do not reflect the majority opinion of the states’ own citizens.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Rikki Novetsky, Mooj Zadie, Sydney Harper, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Patricia Willens, Marion Lozano and Dan Powell
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, the court’s conservative majority argued it was simply handing the question of abortion to the states and their voters to decide for themselves.

title: How California Is Preparing for a Surge in Out-of-State Abortion Patients
description: The state is shoring up resources to be the nation’s abortion refuge.

title: Toxic and Ineffective: Experts Warn Against ‘Herbal Abortion’ Remedies on TikTok
description: Amid the fear and confusion around abortion options across the country, some on social media have suggested taking herbs. But experts urge caution.
text: If you were scrolling through TikTok in the days after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June, you might be forgiven for thinking that you could give yourself an abortion by walking over to Whole Foods and eating a handful of parsley.

title: Chief Judge Resigns at Crucial Time for New York’s Top Court
description: Judge Janet DiFiore, whose legacy includes a sweeping opinion on gerrymandering, will leave at the end of August after more than six years on the court.
authors: By Jesse McKinley and Benjamin Weiser
text: Janet DiFiore, the chief judge of the New York Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, says she will step down at the end of August, even as lawmakers in Albany consider stronger laws on guns and abortion, measures at the heart of a national debate whose legality could be determined by the state judiciary.

title: Democrats Schedule Votes on Abortion Access, but Lack a Legislative Path
description: Democrats in Congress are under pressure to act after the Supreme Court’s decision. But with Republicans and at least one Democrat opposed in the Senate, the measures are all but certain to fail.
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats in Congress, under pressure to take quick action in response to the Supreme Court’s decision striking down abortion rights, are planning to hold votes this week on legislation that seeks to preserve access to abortions in the post-Roe v. Wade era.

title: The Democrats Need to Start Playing Offense
description: Declaring a national day for abortion rights would send a strong message.
text: Over the past few weeks, I’ve received several messages from readers and friends about the need for hopeful alternatives in my work. This request, I believe, is a response to my main preoccupations in this space: homelessness, nursing homes, protests and the increasing failure of Democrats to reach working-class voters, especially immigrants. It’s true that my forecast for each of these issues is rather bleak, but I understand why readers might want some alternatives.

title: What Will Post-Roe Medical Care Look Like? A Times Event.
description: The Opinion podcast host Lulu Garcia-Navarro explores the future of reproductive health care in a virtual event on July 21.
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion, medical providers were faced with a complex patchwork of state-level abortion bans and prohibitions. In Arizona, medical workers wondered if a century-old law banning almost all abortions and punishing providers with prison time meant that they should stop the procedures. In Wisconsin, a district attorney said he would not prosecute abortion cases after an 1849 state law banning them took effect.

title: Why Overturning Roe Will Unleash a Legal Storm for the Supreme Court
description: Battles over laws related to abortion, like criminalizing out-of-state travel for the procedure, will intensify in the legal system.
text: While laying waste to 50 years of abortion jurisprudence, the Supreme Court — or at least four of the five members of the new hard-right majority — took pains to reassure the country that it had executed an isolated hit on an “egregiously wrong” precedent that would not reverberate in other areas of constitutional law.

title: A Culture Warrior Goes Quiet: DeSantis Dodges Questions on Abortion Plans
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida faces political pressure from Republicans to further curb abortions — and risks to his re-election campaign and any presidential aspirations if he goes too far.
authors: By Maggie Haberman, Patricia Mazzei and Michael C. Bender
text: When the Supreme Court erased the constitutional right to an abortion last month, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was among the many Republicans who celebrated. “The prayers of millions have been answered,” he tweeted.

title: Abortion Insurance Coverage Is Now Much More Complicated
description: In the wake of the Supreme Court ruling, abortion benefits will depend even more on where a woman lives and who provides her insurance.
text: Even before the constitutional right to an abortion was struck down last month, health insurance coverage for it was spotty. Abortion benefits largely depended on where a woman lived or whom she worked for.

title: Can You Drive Alone in the H.O.V. Lane if You’re Pregnant? A Post-Roe Quandary.
description: A woman in Texas said that, under the state’s abortion ban, she and her fetus qualified for the car pool lane. The argument could go well beyond driving.
text: A fundamental question in the abortion debate — when does a person’s life begin? — raises issues that extend far into the reaches of everyday life.

title: Louisiana Judge Allows Abortions to Become Legal Again
description: For the second time, a judge temporarily blocked the state’s trigger bans, which went into effect after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
text: Abortions became legal again in Louisiana on Tuesday after a Baton Rouge judge granted a temporary restraining order blocking the state’s abortion bans from being enforced.

title: Poll Shows Tight Race for Control of Congress as Class Divide Widens
description: Nonwhite and working-class Democrats worry more about the economy, while white college graduates focus more on issues like abortion rights and guns.
text: With President Biden’s approval rating mired in the 30s and with nearly 80 percent of voters saying the country is heading in the wrong direction, all the ingredients seem to be in place for a Republican sweep in the November midterm elections.

title: Please Laugh About My Abortion With Me
description: Amid the grief over Roe v. Wade, comedy can be a coping mechanism.
text: On Friday evening, June 24, I arrived at the Cherry Lane Theater in Manhattan having already traveled between outrage, exhaustion and despair. Roe v. Wade was overturned that morning, and I was about to perform my comedy show “Oh God, a Show About Abortion.” I performed the show after the draft of the Supreme Court decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization leaked, and the mood in the theater then was somber; an edgier joke, one that normally elicits reluctant bursts of laughter, earned groans.

title: In a Post-Roe World, the Future of Digital Privacy Looks Even Grimmer
description: The sheer amount of tech tools and knowledge required to discreetly seek an abortion underlines how wide open we are to surveillance.
authors: By Natasha Singer and Brian X. Chen
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: To Fight Book Banning, Support Librarians
description: Librarians respond to book bans. Also: The Jan. 6 hearing; a Supreme Court test; anti-abortion states; homelessness in California; acting for change locally.
text: To the Editor:

title: A Rhode Island State Senator Wants You to #TwerkFor Justice
description: Tiara Mack’s TikTok video of her twerking at the beach went viral. Now, she is using that momentum to bring awareness to her political platform.
authors: By Sadiba Hasan and Anna Grace Lee
text: When news broke of the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade in June, State Senator Tiara Mack, Democrat of Rhode Island, decided to try a new way of raising awareness for abortion access: She created a TikTok account.

title: Where Does the Fight Over Abortion Rights Go After Roe?
description: The politics of abortion are only intensifying as states set about creating their own legal regimes.
text: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.

title: Suspect Is Arrested in Ohio After Rape of 10-Year-Old Girl
description: The case became a flash point in the abortion debate after the young victim was forced to travel out of state for the procedure.
text: An Ohio man has been arrested and charged with the rape of a 10-year-old girl, whose travel across state lines to receive an abortion captured national attention.

title: U.S. Tells Pharmacists Not to Withhold Pills That Can Cause Abortion
description: New Biden administration guidance warned that failing to dispense such drugs “may be discriminating” on the basis of sex or disability, citing other conditions that they can treat.
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration warned the nation’s 60,000 retail pharmacies on Wednesday that they risk violating federal civil rights law if they refuse to fill prescriptions for pills that can induce abortion — the second time this week that it has used its executive authority to set up showdowns with states where abortion is now illegal.

title: ‘That’s Between Them and God.’ 12 Pro-Life Voters on Abortion in America.
description: Twelve abortion opponents discuss the end of Roe.
authors: By Vanessa Mobley and Adrian J. Rivera
text: Twelve abortion opponents discuss the end of Roe.

title: 10 Pro-Choice Voters on Who’s to Blame for the End of Roe
description: Ten abortion rights supporters discuss the new American reproductive landscape.
authors: By Lauren Kelley and Adrian J. Rivera
text: Ten abortion rights supporters discuss the new American reproductive landscape.

title: For a Woman in a Wheelchair, Abortion Access Was One More Challenge
description: Roxanne Schiebergen, a writer and actress, has become skilled at navigating New York City since she was a student at N.Y.U. Then came an unexpected pregnancy.
text: Roxanne Schiebergen, a 30-year-old writer and actress who lives in New York, was in the bathroom of her Midtown apartment when she received a text from a close friend one day in May. The text included a screenshot of a marketing flyer promoting a “Bans Off Our Bodies” rally sponsored in part by Planned Parenthood. The photo in the ad showed four women — and the woman at the center was in a wheelchair.

title: Young Voters Are Fed Up With Their (Much) Older Leaders
description: Led by politicians often three times their age, many voters under 30 are hungry for new blood and new ideas.
authors: By Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
text: Alexandra Chadwick went to the polls in 2020 with the single goal of ousting Donald J. Trump. A 22-year-old first-time voter, she saw Joseph R. Biden Jr. as more of a safeguard than an inspiring political figure, someone who could stave off threats to abortion access, gun control and climate policy.

title: For New York’s Anti-Abortion Veterans, Roe’s Fall Is Not a Full Victory
description: Checking in with activists from sanctuary states who have spent more than 50 years fighting abortion.
text: For local veterans of the anti-abortion movement, the Supreme Court’s June 24 decision reversing Roe v. Wade came with a sobering reminder: In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, nothing had changed.

title: ‘Emboldening and Humbling’: Gasping at the Wonders of the Universe
description: Readers reach for the poetic, awe-struck by the photos from the James Webb Space Telescope. Also: Abortion and men; Ukraine coverage; government regulations.
text: To the Editor:

title: Texas Sues Biden Administration Over Access to Emergency Medical Abortions
description: Recent administrative guidance to hospitals said doctors could perform abortions in emergency situations if complications posed a threat to the health or life of the mother.
authors: By J. David Goodman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
text: HOUSTON — Days after the Biden administration moved to ensure access to abortion in certain emergency situations, Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas on Thursday filed a lawsuit challenging the federal guidance, saying it would “force abortions” in hospitals in the state.

title: A 10-Year-Old Endures the Predictable Result of an Abortion Ban
description: Why is the right in denial about what their laws do?
text: Not long after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, an Indiana obstetrician and gynecologist named Caitlin Bernard told The Indianapolis Star about a call she’d gotten from a doctor in Ohio. The Ohio doctor had a 10-year-old patient who was six weeks and three days pregnant. An Ohio law banning abortion after fetal cardiac activity can be detected — usually around the sixth week of pregnancy — had just gone into effect, so the girl needed to cross state lines for care. The report, being illustrative of the ghoulish impact of abortion prohibitions, went viral, and Joe Biden mentioned it in a speech.

title: Facts Were Sparse on an Abortion Case. But That Didn’t Stop the Attacks.
description: The story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio became the focus of a heated political debate that played out in the news media.
text: For nearly two weeks, the story of a 10-year-old Ohio girl who was raped and crossed state lines to get an abortion became a flash point in the national abortion debate. President Biden and other Democrats argued that it showed the harm resulting from the Supreme Court’s overturning of Roe v. Wade.

title: Doctor Informed State of 10-Year-Old Girl’s Abortion
description: A document obtained by The New York Times shows that the Indiana obstetrician reported the child’s abortion to the state.
authors: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ava Sasani
text: A lawyer for the Indiana obstetrician who has drawn national attention for providing abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim said on Thursday that the doctor had taken “every appropriate and proper action” in the case — including filing necessary forms to report the abortion with state authorities, contrary to the assertions of Indiana’s attorney general.

title: From Mexico to the U.S., an Underground Abortion Pill Network
description: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
authors: By Paula Mónaco Felipe, Miguel Tovar, Souleyman Messalti, Caroline Kim and Brent McDonald
text: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.

title: Dr. Caitlin Bernard Was Meant to Write This With Me Before She Was Attacked for Doing Her Job
description: It’s terrifying to be a doctor in post-Roe America.
text: Earlier this week I was preparing to write a guest essay with my colleague Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an OB-GYN here in Indiana. We wanted to write about the chilling effect that the overturning of Roe v. Wade has had on medicine in our state and around the country in just a few short weeks. But then Dr. Bernard became a target of a national smear campaign for speaking out about her 10-year-old patient, a rape victim from Ohio who needed an abortion and had to travel to Indiana to receive one, given the restrictions in her home state.

title: Republicans Are Already Threatening the Right to Travel
description: Dobbs has them all fired up.
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, it did more than just supercharge the assault on the right to have an abortion. It also opened up a corresponding attack on the right to travel.

title: Should Trump Be Indicted?
description: Readers argue that Donald Trump should be indicted and discuss why his base still supports him. Also: Manchin vs. Biden’s plans; a 10-year-old rape victim; abortion travel.
text: To the Editor:

title: House Passes Two Bills Seeking to Ensure Access to Abortion
description: Neither piece of legislation has the votes to advance in the Senate, but Democrats intend them to draw clear lines on the issue for the midterm elections.
text: WASHINGTON — The House on Friday passed two bills aiming at ensuring access to abortion in the post-Roe era, as Democrats seek to draw clear distinctions with Republicans on the issue heading into the midterm election campaign.

title: Using Comedy to Push for Abortion Rights
description: Lizz Winstead, the “Daily Show” co-creator, has marshaled her contacts in the standup world to help supporters turn protest into action.
text: “Things are awesome — never better!” joked Lizz Winstead, the comedian, producer and abortion rights activist. “Sleeping well; no diarrhea. Things are awesome.”

title: Mexican Activists Answer Calls for Abortion Pills From the U.S.
description: As more U.S. states move to criminalize abortion, activists in Mexico have been inundated with calls from women seeking abortion medication. Our cameras went inside their distribution effort.
authors: By Brent McDonald, Paula Mónaco Felipe, Caroline Kim, Souleyman Messalti and Miguel Tovar
text: In the weeks since the U.S. Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, the phones and social media accounts of abortion rights activists in Mexico have been inundated with desperate requests for abortion pills from people in the U.S.

title: Biden Drops Plan to Name Anti-Abortion Lawyer Backed by McConnell as Judge
description: The White House quietly agreed with the Senate Republican leader to nominate Chad Meredith for a federal judgeship, but opposition from his fellow Kentuckian Rand Paul scuttled the deal.
text: WASHINGTON — The White House is abandoning plans to nominate a Kentucky lawyer who opposes abortion rights and is backed by Senator Mitch McConnell to a federal court seat, citing opposition from Senator Rand Paul, Mr. McConnell’s home-state colleague.

title: Corrections: July 16, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 16, 2022.
text: An article on Friday about the story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio who crossed state lines to get an abortion and became a flash point in the national abortion debate misstated Bill O’Reilly’s connection to The First, a conservative media outlet. He is a host for the outlet, not the owner.

title: Irish Eyes Aren’t Smiling
description: A nation once in the grip of religious extremism sadly watches America’s lurch to the right on abortion.
text: GALWAY, Ireland — I came to Ireland four years ago to cover the searing story of the Scarlet Letter in the Emerald Isle.

title: What New Abortion Bans Mean for the Youngest Patients
description: One 10-year-old became the focus of debate, but more than 1,000 girls under 15 seek abortions each year. “How are we going to help the pregnant kids?”
authors: By Dana Goldstein and Ava Sasani
text: She was just 10 years old, so young that many people were horrified when they heard it, and others refused to believe it. But the ordeal of the child rape victim in Ohio who had to cross state lines for an abortion, and the ugly political fight that followed, have highlighted two uncomfortable facts: Such pregnancies are not as rare as people think, and new abortion bans are likely to have a pronounced impact on the youngest pregnant girls.

title: What Will Happen if Doctors Defy the Law to Provide Abortions?
description: Those who withhold care get conscience protections. What about those who want to provide it?
text: Days after Texas banned most abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy in September 2021, Dr. Alan Braid disclosed that he had “provided an abortion to a woman, who though still in her first trimester, was beyond the state’s new limit.” Dr. Braid wrote in a Washington Post opinion piece that when he was a medical resident before Roe v. Wade, he had seen “teenagers die from illegal abortions. One I will never forget. When she came into the ER, her vaginal cavity was packed with rags. She died a few days later from massive organ failure, caused by a septic infection.” Dr. Braid resolved, “I can’t just sit back and watch us return to 1972.”

title: They Had Miscarriages, and New Abortion Laws Obstructed Treatment
description: Surgical procedures and medication for miscarriages are identical to those for abortion, and some patients report delayed or denied miscarriage care because doctors and pharmacists fear running afoul of abortion bans.
text: Last year, a 35-year-old woman named Amanda, who lives in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, had a miscarriage in the first trimester of her pregnancy. At a large hospital, a doctor performed a surgical procedure often used as a safe and quick method to remove tissue from a failed pregnancy.

title: Quotation of the Day: When Miscarriages Collide With Abortion Law
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 18, 2022.
text: “I couldn’t help but cry in front of all the people at Walgreens because I felt like I was being treated like a bad person for picking up a medication to prevent an infection.”

title: I Went to the State Where the First Big Fight Over Abortion Is On. Here’s What I Saw.
description: Kansas stands as the first big post-Roe political test for abortion. It’s an intense, complicated fight, with the odds stacked against reproductive-rights supporters.
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. — When Sharon Brown answered the door of her modest town home on a recent Saturday, she was a little rude at first to the two young women standing before her, Yazmin Bruno-Valdez and Melanie Haas. They introduced themselves as volunteers with Kansans for Constitutional Freedom, a group that sounds conservative but is fighting to preserve abortion rights in the state. They were knocking on doors in Wyandotte County, one of the state’s bluer pockets, urging voters to oppose an amendment to the Kansas Constitution that would pave the way for tighter abortion restrictions, even a total ban. Ms. Bruno-Valdez offered a “Vote no” flyer explaining the measure, but Ms. Brown misunderstood which side the women were on. Rocking black fuzzy slippers and a hot pink robe, she made a disgusted face and waved the volunteers away. “I believe in abortion,” she said, moving to shut her door.

title: Democrats Navigate Nuanced Views on Abortion Among Black Voters
description: Faced with a streak of conservatism about abortion among some Black Americans, a vital constituency for President Biden, Democrats are framing the issue as part of a broader civil rights struggle.
text: As she and other faith leaders sat last month with Vice President Kamala Harris to discuss the implications of the Supreme Court overturning Roe v. Wade, the Rev. Najuma Smith-Pollard, a pastor at a Black church in Los Angeles, reflected on the complex feelings in her community about abortion.

title: What Pregnancy and Childbirth Do to the Bodies of Young Girls
description: An Ohio 10-year-old’s recent abortion has generated fierce debate. Doctors in countries where pregnancy is common in adolescents say the toll of childbirth on young bodies is brutal.
text: After the account of a 10-year-old Ohio girl crossing state lines to get an abortion drew national attention last week, some prominent abortion opponents suggested the child should have carried her pregnancy to term.

title: Doug Mastriano called climate change ‘pop science.’ That video, and others, vanished from his social media.
description: More than a dozen Facebook videos posted by the Republican nominee for Pennsylvania governor espousing far-right positions have disappeared as the state senator shifts to the general election.
text: The videos were a sort-of virtual ride-along with Doug Mastriano as he crisscrossed Pennsylvania in the governor’s race, regaling viewers with his far-right musings about climate change, abortion and critics within his own party.

title: The Anti-Abortion Movement’s Contempt for Women Is Worse Than I Imagined
description: Some Republicans reject even lifesaving abortions.
text: It’s getting hard to keep track of all the stories of women being denied care for miscarriages and otherwise having their lives endangered because of state abortion bans.

title: Some Students Want Colleges to Provide the Abortion Pill. Schools Are Resisting.
description: Even in states that protect abortion rights, colleges are proceeding with caution.
authors: By Anemona Hartocollis and Stephanie Saul
text: Many colleges pride themselves on providing a range of sexual and reproductive health services for their students, including birth control, screenings for sexually transmitted diseases and even insurance coverage to terminate a pregnancy.

title: Abortion Provider Prepares Defamation Suit Against Indiana Attorney General
description: The doctor in the case of a 10-year-old rape victim says the attorney general acted with “reckless disregard of the truth.” A spokesman calls the claims “baseless.”
authors: By Ava Sasani and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
text: An Indianapolis doctor who provided abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim is preparing to sue Attorney General Todd Rokita of Indiana for defamation after he said he would investigate her actions in the case, according to a statement released on Tuesday by her lawyer.

title: Michigan Coach Jim Harbaugh Speaks at Anti-Abortion Event
description: The remarks by Harbaugh, who was quoted as saying, “I believe in having the courage to let the unborn be born,” run counter to those expressed by the university’s interim president.
text: Jim Harbaugh, the University of Michigan’s head football coach, professed his anti-abortion views at a fund-raising event this week, becoming one of the first prominent sports figures to speak out against abortion since Roe v. Wade was overturned.

title: How Abortion Bans Are Restricting Miscarriage Care
description: The reversal of Roe v. Wade has caused some doctors to worry that recommending certain procedures might have legal repercussions.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Mooj Zadie, Rob Szypko, Clare Toeniskoetter, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
text: Across the United States, Republicans emboldened by the overturning of Roe v. Wade are passing laws intended to stop medical staff from providing an abortion.

title: Women Face Risks as Doctors Struggle With Medical Exceptions on Abortion
description: Of the 13 states with trigger bans, all make exceptions for abortions to save the life of the mother. But what defines a medical emergency?
authors: By J. David Goodman and Azeen Ghorayshi
text: HOUSTON — Dr. Amanda Horton, an obstetrician who specializes in high-risk pregnancies, had been counseling pregnant patients at a small hospital in rural Texas last month when a woman arrived in crisis: It was only 17 weeks into her pregnancy and her water had broken.

title: Where Abortion Is on the Ballot
description: The outcome of November’s elections will affect abortion access for millions of Americans. Activists on both sides are focused on races up and down the ballot.
authors: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker, Jason Kao and Marco Hernandez
text: The outcome of November’s elections will affect abortion access for millions of Americans. Activists on both sides are focused on races up and down the ballot.

title: After Roe, Sex Ed Is Even More Vital
description: Reducing unwanted pregnancies starts with teaching children and teenagers.
authors: By Eva Goldfarb and Lisa Lieberman
text: Religious-right political groups that have spent decades dismantling abortion rights in much of the country have been gunning for sex education for just as long. Their dangerous and cynical efforts now appear under the guise of “parental rights” and “school transparency” on the floors of state legislatures and at school board meetings.

title: Georgia’s 6-Week Abortion Ban Begins Immediately After Court Ruling
description: A federal appeals court said the law, which was signed in 2019 but quickly halted for violating Roe v. Wade, could go into effect.
text: A federal appeals court panel immediately allowed a Georgia law that bans abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy to go into effect on Wednesday, ending a yearslong battle over one of the country’s most restrictive laws.

title: Stacey Abrams aims to put abortion at the center of the Georgia governor’s race.
description: After a court ruling put the state’s six-week abortion ban back into effect, Ms. Abrams said that while economic struggles would come and go, “this law is permanent.”
text: ATLANTA — Stacey Abrams, the Democratic nominee for governor of Georgia, is racing to turn abortion rights supporters’ frustrations and fears into electoral gains for her party after a court ruling reinstated the state’s six-week ban on the procedure.

title: A Plea From More Than 100 Medical Professionals: Boycott Anti-Abortion States
description: Doctors urge avoiding states that restrict abortion. Also: The bystander and the shooting; climate change; G.O.P. disinformation; crisis hotlines; overpopulation.
text: To the Editor:

title: YouTube will take down ‘unsafe’ abortion how-to videos.
description: The video service said it would take a closer look at the abortion content on its platform.
text: YouTube said on Thursday that it would ban content that gave viewers instructions for “unsafe abortion methods,” ramping up efforts to police health care content in a post-Roe era.

title: Religious Doctrine, Not the Constitution, Drove the Dobbs Decision
description: Women have become refugees fleeing their home states for reproductive health care that a month ago was theirs by right.
text: My own way of keeping track of a Supreme Court term is to log each of the term’s decisions on a chart labeled by category: criminal law, administrative law, speech, federalism and so on. For this past term, one of my charts was, of course, labeled “abortion,” and naturally that’s where I recorded Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, the decision that overturned Roe v. Wade.

title: After Roe, Republicans Sharpen Attacks on Gay and Transgender Rights
description: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, anti-gay rhetoric and calls to roll back L.G.B.T.Q. rights have grown bolder among Republican elected officials and candidates.
text: Days after the Supreme Court overturned the right to abortion, Michigan’s Republican candidates for governor were asked if it was also time to roll back constitutional protections for gay rights.

title: Newsom Raises His Profile With Hardball Tactics, Starting With a Gun Bill
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California signed legislation that would provide a minimum $10,000 award to residents who successfully sue makers of illegal guns.
text: SACRAMENTO — On a Saturday night in December, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California was so frustrated by a Supreme Court decision allowing Texas residents to sue abortion providers that he went straight to social media to call for legislation allowing private citizens to enforce his own state’s gun laws.

title: Interstate Abortion Travel Is Already Straining Parts of the System
description: Even in some states where abortion remains legal, wait times for appointments are long because of increased demand.
authors: By Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Josh Katz
text: The reversal of Roe v. Wade did not affect the legal status of abortion in New Mexico, where seven clinics are still operating. But that does not mean an abortion is easy to obtain there.

title: After Recent Turmoil, the Race for Texas Governor Is Tightening
description: A series of tragedies and challenges have soured the mood of Texans and made the governor’s race perhaps the most competitive since the 1990s.
text: SUGAR LAND, Texas — One of the deadliest school shootings in U.S. history. The revival of a 1920s ban on abortion. The country’s worst episode of migrant death in recent memory. And an electrical grid, which failed during bitter cold, now straining under soaring heat.

title: From ‘Dirty Dancing’ to ‘Scandal,’ On-Screen Abortion Stories Carry Sway
description: Abortion is common and safe, but you might not know it from watching TV or movies.
text: In the weeks since the fall of Roe v. Wade, people have supported abortion access and rights in many ways, including spreading information about abortion pills and defending brave doctors. My contribution has been thinking about TV and movies.

title: ‘Everybody Is Dug In’: Kansans Fiercely Debate the First Post-Roe Vote on Abortion
description: The Aug. 2 ballot question will decide whether the State Constitution will allow legislators to ban or further restrict the procedure.
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Kansas voters will decide next week whether to remove protections of abortion rights from their State Constitution, providing the first electoral test of Americans’ attitudes on the issue since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

title: The Next Abortion Fight: Mailing Pills
description: More than half of U.S. abortions are conducted using pills. How will that change as red states ban the medication?
authors: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
text: With Roe v. Wade overturned, many of the most intense battles over abortion access will involve the mailing of pills into Republican-run states.

title: What to Know About California’s Head-Turning Gun Control Law
description: The state’s legislation is modeled after a Texas abortion law that went into effect last year.
text: By one measure, Californians are about 25 percent less likely to die in mass shootings compared with residents of other states. Our state’s low rate of gun deaths is at least in part because of our strict firearm laws, experts say.

title: How Roe’s Demise Could Safeguard Gay Marriage
description: A bill to protect marriage equality might now, improbably, become law.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Will Reid, Sydney Harper, Diana Nguyen, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
text: After Roe v. Wade was overturned, Democrats introduced a bill to prevent the right to gay marriage from meeting the same fate as the right to abortion.

title: Biden Is Facing Crisis After Crisis. But Are They Emergencies?
description: President Biden is under pressure — often from his own allies — to declare national emergencies on issues like climate and abortion that are roiling American culture.
text: WASHINGTON — In a time of political and economic turmoil, just what, exactly, counts as a national emergency?

title: With Roe Gone, Republicans Quarrel Over How Far to Push Abortion Bans
description: An effort in Indiana to pass an abortion ban with exceptions has exposed rifts among conservatives on how to legislate in a post-Roe world.
authors: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Abortion opponents, especially in conservative states, had hoped to swiftly pass a new wave of restrictions after Roe v. Wade was overturned. But so far, most Republican lawmakers have moved cautiously or done nothing at all, even in statehouses where they hold overwhelming majorities.

title: Swing Voters, Struggling With Their Options, Scramble Traditional Political Coalitions
description: Democrats are on the defensive with vital political constituencies rattled by inflation. But amid concerns over abortion rights and democracy, Republicans still have problems in the highly educated suburbs.
text: ROCKY RIVER, Ohio — A few weeks before Ohio’s Senate primaries, Kristen Bentz stood outside a grocery store in suburban Cleveland, feeling torn about the race.

title: States With Abortion Bans Are Among Least Supportive for Mothers and Children
description: They tend to have the weakest social services and the worst results in several categories of health and well-being.
authors: By Emily Badger, Margot Sanger-Katz, Claire Cain Miller and Eve Washington
text: In Mississippi, which brought the abortion case that ended Roe v. Wade before the Supreme Court, Gov. Tate Reeves vowed that the state would now “take every step necessary to support mothers and children.”

title: An Indiana Doctor Speaks Out on Abortion, and Pays a Price
description: Dr. Caitlin Bernard, who provided an abortion to a 10-year-old, says doctors shouldn’t be silent. But she finds herself at the center of a post-Roe clash shaking the medical community.
authors: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ava Sasani
text: Three weeks before the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an Indianapolis obstetrician-gynecologist, donned her white lab coat, put her infant daughter into a front-pack baby carrier and joined a few colleagues who marched to the State Capitol, hoping to deliver a letter to Gov. Eric Holcomb.

title: ‘A Balance’ Review: Critical Distance
description: Yujiro Harumoto’s slow-build morality tale puts an ambitious documentary maker in an uncomfortable position as her life begins to resemble her films.
text: About an hour into Yujiro Harumoto’s knotty and suspenseful morality tale “A Balance,” Yuko (Kumi Takiuchi), a documentary director, argues with an abortion doctor (Ryo Ikeda) that “What’s moral isn’t always what’s best.” It’s a platitude that has already been tested for Yuko, whose life has become suddenly very complicated. But that test is only beginning.

title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Is in Denial
description: It can’t defend the world it has made.
text: It is always painful to grapple with realities that contravene your most deeply held beliefs.

title: A Polish Priest’s War Against Abortion Focuses on Helping Single Mothers
description: The Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk sees little effect on women’s decisions whether to have a child from a 29-year abortion ban. What may matter more is support for women who choose to have a child.
authors: By Katrin Bennhold and Monika Pronczuk
text: SZCZECIN, Poland — Abortion has been banned in Poland for 29 years, but that has done little to prevent women from finding access to the procedure, leaving the Rev. Tomasz Kancelarczyk a busy man.

title: New Risks Facing Doctors and Their Pregnant Patients
description: Readers discuss how new abortion laws will affect treatment of miscarriages and life-threatening pregnancies.
text: To the Editor:

title: Kansas Abortion Vote Tests Political Energy in Post-Roe America
description: On Tuesday, Kansans will decide whether to pass a constitutional amendment that could lead to far-reaching abortion restrictions or an outright ban on the procedure.
text: OLATHE, Kan. — In the final days before Kansans decide whether to remove abortion rights protections from their State Constitution, the politically competitive Kansas City suburbs have become hotbeds of activism.

title: Leave My Disability Out of Your Anti-Abortion Propaganda
description: The dignity of disabled lives and a woman’s right to choose are two separate issues.
text: Thirty years ago, when my mother was pregnant, an ultrasound revealed troubling abnormalities: the fetus’s organs were misarranged. This condition, she was told by her doctor, correlated with a wide variety of disabilities that could cause the baby to die at birth. The doctor told my mother that she could seek an abortion. She wanted her to know her options.

title: A New Yorker’s Opposition to Abortion Clouds Her House Re-Election Bid
description: Representative Nicole Malliotakis, the city’s lone Republican House member, has tried to maintain some distance from the Supreme Court ruling on abortion.
text: As the lone Republican in the New York City congressional delegation, Representative Nicole Malliotakis has adopted certain stances that would make her an understandable outlier in a deeply Democratic city.

title: The Abortion Decision, Haunted by Brown v. Board of Education
description: The justices cited the landmark 1954 decision banning segregation in public schools 23 times, debating its meaning and methods.
text: WASHINGTON — In the Supreme Court decision that eliminated the constitutional right to abortion, the justices engaged in an extended debate over the meaning and legacy of Brown v. Board of Education, the 1954 decision that said the Constitution does not permit racial segregation in public schools.

title: ‘They’re Just Going to Let Me Die?’ One Woman’s Abortion Odyssey
description: Madison Underwood was thrilled to learn she was pregnant. But when a rare defect in the developing fetus threatened her life, she was thrust into post-Roe chaos.
text: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Madison Underwood was lying on the ultrasound table, nearly 19 weeks pregnant, when the doctor came in to say her abortion had been canceled.

title: Bipartisan Abortion-Rights Bill Sets Up a Midterm Debate
description: Four senators, two Democrats and two Republicans, joined forces to introduce legislation to guarantee abortion access after Roe v. Wade was overturned. But the bill has little chance of advancing.
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators released a bill on Monday that would create a federal baseline for abortion access, the first bipartisan legislative effort on the issue since the Supreme Court struck down the Roe v. Wade ruling that established abortion rights nationwide.

title: Why Do We Talk About Miscarriage Differently From Abortion?
description: Pregnancy loss and reproductive rights are not at odds.
authors: By Greer Donley and Jill Wieber Lens
text: The demise of Roe v. Wade is causing harms that extend well beyond abortion patients. In places where abortion is heavily restricted, women with ectopic pregnancies and those experiencing inevitable miscarriages have reported delays in care that have risked their health, life and future fertility. Some have struggled to get medications to treat miscarriage because those drugs are also used for abortion.

title: Justice Dept. Sues Idaho Over Its Abortion Restrictions
description: The Biden administration filed its first new litigation to protect access to abortion since the Supreme Court ruling in June that ended the constitutional right to terminate pregnancies.
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration sued Idaho on Tuesday over a strict state abortion law set to take effect this month that the Justice Department said would inhibit emergency room doctors from performing abortions that are necessary to stabilize the health of women facing medical emergencies.

title: Millions in Advertising Help Shape Closely Watched Abortion Vote in Kansas
description: Voters are considering amending the state Constitution in the country’s first electoral test case on abortion since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade.
text: Follow live updates on Kansas election results.

title: Several primaries are being decided Tuesday. Here’s when we might know results.
description: Pour a cup of coffee if you need to — this could go late.
