text: Results from Tuesday’s elections are some of the most hotly anticipated of the midterm season, with two battleground states among the five hosting major primary contests, a spate of Trump-backed election deniers seeking their party’s nominations and the first post-Roe vote on abortion happening in Kansas.

title: Kansas Votes to Preserve Abortion Rights Protections in Its Constitution
description: In the first election test after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, voters overwhelmingly rejected an amendment that would have allowed legislators to enact abortion restrictions.
authors: By Mitch Smith and Katie Glueck
text: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Kansas voters resoundingly decided against removing the right to abortion from the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press, a major victory for the abortion rights movement in one of America’s reliably conservative states.

title: Here’s how abortion rights supporters won in conservative Kansas.
description: Turnout was high for a referendum that drew national attention.
authors: By Maggie Astor and Nate Cohn
text: Supporters of abortion rights won a huge and surprising victory on Tuesday in one of the most conservative states in the country, with Kansas voters resoundingly rejecting a constitutional amendment that would have let state legislators ban or significantly restrict abortion.

title: Results from primaries in Arizona, Michigan, Kansas, Missouri and Washington.
description: Kansans defeated a constitutional amendment that would have enabled abortion restrictions, Missouri Republicans breathed a sigh of relief over their Senate nominee, and more results.
text: Voters in five states with major primary contests went to the polls on Tuesday. Here’s a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses so far.

title: Voters in Kansas Celebrate Preservation of Abortion Rights
description: In the first election test after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Kansas voters decided against removing the right to abortion from the State Constitution.
text: In the first election test after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Kansas voters decided against removing the right to abortion from the State Constitution.

title: Five Takeaways From Tuesday’s Elections
description: Voters in deep-red Kansas delivered a loud warning shot to Republicans, and Arizona Republicans nominated a 2020 conspiracy theorist to be the state’s top election official.
authors: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
text: While Donald J. Trump’s wing of the Republican Party flexed its muscle in primaries across the country on Tuesday, a remarkable victory for abortion rights in Kansas, coupled with a couple of defeats for Trump-styled candidates, suggest this year’s midterms are a trickier environment for uncompromising conservatives than Republicans once believed.

title: Biden Issues Executive Order on Abortion Access, Calling for More Study
description: The order is short on specifics, directing federal officials to consider how to help those traveling out of state for abortions.
text: WASHINGTON — Since even before the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade, Democrats have pressured President Biden to take action to protect abortion rights.

title: Kansas Abortion Amendment Election Results
description: See full results and maps from the Kansas primary elections.
text: See full results and maps from the Kansas primary elections.

title: Why the Defense of Abortion in Kansas Is So Powerful
description: In many ways, across state and even party lines, voters did it together.
text: TOPEKA, Kan. — Lines of Kansas voters, resolute in the August sun and 100-degree heat, stretched beyond the doors of polling sites and wrapped around buildings on Tuesday to cast ballots in a primary election. A few suffered heat exhaustion. Firefighters passed out bottles of water.

title: Pelosi in Taiwan: Sharp Views All Around
description: The House speaker’s visit is reviewed, pro and con. Also: The Kansas abortion vote; OB-GYNs; coal miners; rich and poor friends; single-issue voters.
text: To the Editor:

title: Yes, Kansas Is Conservative. It’s Also Complicated.
description: The state’s politics have never been as simple as the common narrative conveys. Tuesday’s vote on an abortion amendment is an example of its unpredictability.
text: In the popular imagination, Kansas is synonymous with modern American conservatism, and not without reason. It has voted Republican in every presidential election for more than 50 years and hasn’t elected a Democrat to the Senate since 1932.

title: Where Trump Counties in Kansas Chose to Preserve Abortion Rights
description: Most of the counties that rejected an amendment to remove abortion rights from the state’s Constitution on Tuesday also voted Republican in the 2020 presidential race.
authors: By Keith Collins and Allison McCann
text: Most of the counties that rejected an amendment to remove abortion rights from the state’s Constitution on Tuesday also voted Republican in the 2020 presidential race.

title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Needs Minority Rule
description: Both democracy and choice triumph in Kansas.
text: One side effect of Roe v. Wade was that it allowed the anti-abortion movement to pretend to be on the side of democracy. True, the decision was popular, and majorities since the 1970s have wanted to see abortion legal in at least some circumstances. But Roe prevented duly elected state governments from passing abortion restrictions that were in some cases also popular with their constituents. The goal of the anti-abortion movement was and remains national prohibition. Its language called for returning the matter to the state voters.

title: In Kansas, Support for Abortion Rights Didn’t Just Come From the Usual Places
description: Rural Republicans joined suburban Democrats to create huge turnout and a broad coalition that voted to preserve abortion rights by a fat margin.
authors: By Mitch Smith, Lauren Fox and Elizabeth Dias
text: PRAIRIE VILLAGE, Kan. — DeAnn Hupe Seib is a fiscally conservative, churchgoing Republican from rural Kansas. When faced with a ballot question about whether abortion rights ought to be removed from her state’s constitution, she voted no. So did her home, Jefferson County, which favored Donald J. Trump by a 32-point margin in 2020.

title: ‘Your Bedroom Is on the Ballot’: How Democrats See Abortion Politics After Kansas
description: After a broad victory in a deep-red state, Democrats are vowing to elevate the fight over abortion rights in midterm races across the country.
authors: By Katie Glueck and Shane Goldmacher
text: A decisive vote to defend abortion rights in deeply conservative Kansas reverberated across the midterm campaign landscape on Wednesday, galvanizing Democrats and underscoring for Republicans the risks of overreaching on one of the most emotionally charged matters in American politics.

title: Newsom Asks Hollywood to Stop Filming in Conservative States
description: The California governor says film companies should “walk the walk” on abortion rights and L.G.B.T.Q. protections by leaving states such as Georgia and Oklahoma.
text: SACRAMENTO — Widening his attack on Republican states for their positions on guns, civil rights and abortion, Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Wednesday called on Hollywood to “walk the walk” on liberal values by bringing back their film and television productions from states such as Georgia and Oklahoma.

title: Trevor Noah Celebrates a Shocking Victory for Abortion Rights in Kansas
description: “Congratulations, Kansas. It’s moments like these I wish I knew which one of these states you were,” Noah joked on Wednesday.
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Kansas Result Suggests 4 Out of 5 States Would Back Abortion Rights in Similar Vote
description: The referendum in a reliably Republican state shows which party has the most energy on the issue.
text: There was every reason to expect a close election.

title: How to Interpret the Kansas Referendum on Abortion
description: Voters in the conservative state roundly rejected a measure that would have added a constitutional prohibition.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Clare Toeniskoetter, Jessica Cheung, Rachelle Bonja, Lisa Chow, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
text: This episode contains mention of sexual assault.

title: Defying the Supreme Court
description: The Kansas abortion vote and the congressional push on same-sex marriage show how progressives can confront the Supreme Court.
text: The Supreme Court has lately looked like the most powerful part of the federal government, with the final word on abortion, gun laws, climate policy, voting rights and more.

title: DeSantis Suspends Tampa Prosecutor Who Vowed Not to Criminalize Abortion
description: The stance of Andrew H. Warren, the elected state attorney of Hillsborough County, was reflected by several other prosecutors across the country.
text: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida suspended the top prosecutor in Tampa on Thursday, accusing him of incompetence and neglect of duty for vowing not to prosecute those who seek or provide abortions.

title: Georgia Abortion Law Says a Fetus Is Tax Deductible
description: The state’s “fetal personhood” provision now includes a $3,000 tax exemption starting at around six weeks of pregnancy.
text: Georgia’s abortion ban counts a fetus as a person. And now, so does its tax code.

title: Republicans Begin Adjusting to a Fierce Abortion Backlash
description: After Kansans voted to preserve abortion access, Republicans who once said the economy reigns supreme are acknowledging the issue will be a centerpiece in the fall campaigns.
authors: By Jonathan Weisman and Katie Glueck
text: Republican candidates, facing a stark reality check from Kansas voters, are softening their once-uncompromising stands against abortion as they move toward the general election, recognizing that strict bans are unpopular and that the issue may be a major driver in the fall campaigns.

title: What I’m reading
description: The seismic shifts of the 1960s are still reverberating in the Democratic Party.
text: I’ve written a lot lately about America in the 1960s  and the way that the backlash to civil rights paved the way for the modern Republican Party’s hard-line positions on gun control and abortion bans. But I haven’t spent as much time looking at what happened within the Democratic Party that enabled that seismic shift to happen. So this week I’ve been remedying that with a giant stack of vacation reading:

title: Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
description: This week, the late-night hosts discussed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan, a surprising abortion-rights win in Kansas and Brittney Griner’s sentencing in Russia.
text: This week, the late-night hosts discussed House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan, a surprising abortion-rights win in Kansas and Brittney Griner’s sentencing in Russia.

title: Indiana Governor Signs First Post-Roe Abortion Ban, With Limited Exceptions
description: The law passed despite dividing Republicans. Some of them said the measure was too restrictive; others objected to limited exceptions for rape and incest.
authors: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Indiana lawmakers passed and the governor signed a near-total ban on abortion on Friday, overcoming division among Republicans and protests from Democrats to become the first state to draw up and approve sweeping new limits on the procedure since Roe v. Wade was struck down in June.

title: Republicans Should Pay a Political Price for Abortion Bans
description: Kansas voters point the way for Democrats.
text: The right to an abortion is protected in the Kansas State Constitution and on Tuesday, a decisive majority of voters kept it there. Fifty-nine percent of Kansans who went to the polls voted to reject a constitutional amendment that would have opened the door to full abortion bans of the kind that exist in neighboring states like Missouri and Oklahoma.

title: Major Indiana Employers Criticize State’s New Abortion Law
description: The drug company Eli Lilly said it “will be forced” to look outside the state for employment growth. The engine maker Cummins said the law will “impede our ability to attract and retain top talent.”
text: On Friday, the governor of Indiana signed into law a near-total abortion ban, making the state the first to approve sweeping new restrictions since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.

title: The New Politics of Abortion
description: The pro-life movement needs to learn the art of the possible.
text: Some liberals seemed genuinely surprised by the results of the Kansas referendum on abortion. A reliably Republican state, a sweeping pro-choice victory. Who could have foreseen it?

title: Biden Is an Uneasy Champion on Abortion. Can He Lead the Fight in Post-Roe America?
description: A practicing Catholic, President Biden has long sought a middle ground on abortion. But activists see the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade as a sign that Democrats have tiptoed too carefully around the issue.
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision to end the constitutional right to an abortion in the United States after nearly 50 years has set in motion a generational struggle over Republican efforts to ban the procedure in states across the country.

title: Some Women ‘Self-Manage’ Abortions as Access Recedes
description: Information and medications needed to end a pregnancy are increasingly available outside the health care system.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Martha Plimpton’s Favorite Things: Pamela Adlon, the Tate Modern, Abortion Rights
description: The star of Amazon Freevee’s new comedy, “Sprung,” also confesses her public radio addiction and shows off her Edward Gorey tattoo.
text: In a perfect world, Martha Plimpton typically has three to six months before shooting to get into character.

title: On Republican turf, a Minnesota Democrat is highlighting his stance on abortion rights.
description: The Democrat Jeff Ettinger, running in a special election for a House seat in southern Minnesota, is in favor of passing legislation that would codify Roe v. Wade into federal law.
text: A week after voters in deep-red Kansas lined up behind abortion rights, a Minnesota Democrat is hoping his special election on Tuesday offers evidence that his party can use the issue to its advantage — even in Republican areas.

title: Your Blue State Won’t Save You: Why State Politics Is National Politics
description: Zack Beauchamp and Nicole Hemmer on why state-level politics is more important than ever.
text: Last week, Kansans voted in overwhelming numbers to protect abortion rights in their State Constitution — the first instance since the overruling of Roe v. Wade in which voters have been able to weigh in on the issue directly. But local battles aren’t just limited to abortion. There’s guns. There’s school curriculums. Most crucially, there’s voting rights. As national politics becomes increasingly polarized, how we live is going to be decided by local legislation. It’s time we step into the state houses and see what’s happening there.

title: How a New Class of Republicans Could Push America to the Right
description: Beyond elections and voting issues, these Trump-aligned candidates could shape the country’s policies on abortion, climate change, same-sex marriage and much more.
text: Much of the attention paid to Donald Trump’s favorite candidates running in the midterms has focused — rightly! — on their support for relitigating the 2020 election. (Which, for those still unsure, was not stolen.)

title: ‘Chaos and Confusion’ in States Where Abortion Is On Again, Off Again
description: For providers and patients, legal challenges to state abortion bans have meant navigating a situation in which the procedure may be allowed one day and banned the next.
text: For providers and patients, legal challenges to state abortion bans have meant navigating a situation in which the procedure may be allowed one day and banned the next.

title: Alito’s Call to Arms to Secure Religious Liberty
description: The challenge, he says, is to convince people who are not religious that religion is  worth special protection.
text: Barely a month after handing down the majority opinion that erased the right to abortion, Justice Samuel Alito traveled to Rome to give a keynote address at a “religious liberty summit” convened by the Religious Liberty Initiative of the University of Notre Dame’s law school. As the video that Notre Dame posted of the bearded justice delivering his remarks made clear, this was a victory lap.

title: Pregnant at 16
description: How the experiences of two women led them to opposite sides of the abortion fight.
authors: By Lynsea Garrison, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Anita Badejo, Ben Calhoun, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Chris Wood and Corey Schreppel
text: This episode contains strong language and descriptions of an abortion.

title: Merrick Garland ‘Rose to the Occasion’
description: Readers discuss the attorney general’s decision to break his silence. Also: A student’s plea on abortion rights; jobs and the economy.
text: To the Editor:

title: Will Abortion Issue Sway Voters’ Choices? N.Y. House Race Poses Test.
description: An Aug. 23 special election to replace a Democrat, Antonio Delgado, could help answer one of the biggest questions of the midterms.
text: CHATHAM, N.Y. — In New York’s Hudson Valley, ubiquitous lawn signs underscore how an upcoming special election for an open House seat has taken on outsize implications.

title: Idaho Supreme Court Rules That Strict Abortion Ban Can Take Effect
description: In a late Friday ruling, the state’s highest court said that a ban could begin at the end of the month while legal challenges are reviewed.
text: Idaho’s near-total ban on abortion can go into effect at the end of August while legal challenges to the restrictions are reviewed, the Idaho Supreme Court said in a ruling late Friday.

title: Why Abortion Has Become a Centerpiece of Democratic TV Ads in 2022
description: Since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Democrats have spent nearly eight times as much on abortion-related ads as Republicans have.
authors: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
text: In Michigan, Democrats took aim at the Republican nominee for governor almost immediately after the primary with a television ad highlighting her opposition to abortion, without exceptions for rape or incest.

title: After Roe v. Wade Reversal, Readers Flock to Publications Aimed at Women
description: The surge of readers has buoyed a part of the digital media world that has gradually declined in recent years.
text: In the weeks since the Supreme Court reversed Roe v. Wade, overturning the right to abortion after almost 50 years, the consequences have quickly rippled through American life. States have banned abortion or restricted access. Individual stories about the real-life impacts have become national headlines. Concerns have flared about what the decision means for other civil rights.

title: A Campaign Tactic by Democrats: Smart? Risky? Unethical?
description: Readers debate the party’s strategy of supporting far-right G.O.P. candidates it thinks it can beat. Also: Covid and schools; Ukraine’s students; Kansas and abortion.
text: To the Editor:

title: Al Franken Becomes First Former U.S. Senator to Host ‘Jimmy Kimmel Live’
description: “But tonight is not about politics, it’s about comedy and having fun,” he said. “So, who’s here from out of state to get an abortion?”
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: A Mother, a Daughter and an Unusual Abortion Prosecution in Nebraska
description: Private Facebook messages are key evidence in a rare case that has stoked fears and inflamed debate over abortion restrictions.
authors: By Shaila Dewan and Sheera Frenkel
text: The mother sent a Facebook message to her daughter days before the teenager’s abortion, the police say. “Hey we can get the show on the road the stuff came in,” she wrote in April, adding, “The 1 pill stops the hormones and then you gotta wait 24 hour 2 take the other.”

title: My Abortion at 11 Wasn’t a Choice. It Was My Life.
description: If I had been forced to give birth as a child, my life would not have been my own.
text: I predict that my 17-year-old daughter will become a doctor. When my husband told her about a neuroscientist and nutritionist he met while producing a documentary, she said, “That sounds like the job for me.” She knows everything about the gut microbiome, dopamine and herniated discs. She does not look away at times when others might — like when my mother unexpectedly texted me pictures of a cyst she had removed from the back of her head, sitting in a bloody specimen cup. “That’s exactly what I would do,” my daughter said. “You have to show people.”

title: In Mississippi, a Post-Roe Question: What Will Republicans Do to Help New Mothers?
description: The state that spurred the overturning of abortion rights is among 17 that have not adopted a new option to extend new mothers’ Medicaid coverage for a year.
text: JACKSON, Miss. — Like low-income pregnant women around the country, nearly every patient at the Sisters in Birth clinic here is covered by Medicaid, the public health insurance program for the poor. But they face the prospect of losing the coverage two months after their babies are born, when they are still at high risk of complications that could lead to serious illness — or even death.

title: In Deep Red Texas, Beto O’Rourke Takes On Guns and Abortion
description: “I can’t win this with Democrats alone,” Mr. O’Rourke said during a 49-day drive across Texas that has included deeply Republican towns.
text: WHITESBORO, Texas — As supporters of Beto O’Rourke, the Democratic candidate for Texas governor, emerged from a crowded campaign event in a quaint, conservative bastion north of Dallas, Treva Sanges was there to protest them.

title: Walmart Expands Employee Abortion Coverage and Will Include Travel Expenses
description: The Arkansas-based retailer, the country’s largest employer, said its health plans would cover abortions in specific cases and related travel expenses.
text: Walmart, the country’s largest private employer, with over 1.6 million workers in the United States, said on Friday it would expand the coverage of abortions and related travel expenses in its health care plans.

title: ‘I’m Carrying This Baby Just to Bury It’: The Struggle to Decode Abortion Laws
description: At a Louisiana hospital, concerns about complying with new abortion bans in post-Roe America left a pregnant woman with a devastating diagnosis, but not an abortion.
authors: By Ava Sasani and Emily Cochrane
text: Nancy Davis says that when she learned this month that the fetus she was carrying had a rare and fatal condition, she and her partner were devastated.

title: Group Seeks to Block Abortion Vote in Michigan, Citing Typography
description: The effort is aimed at keeping a constitutional amendment to guarantee abortion rights off the ballot. A voting access measure is also being challenged.
text: Conservative groups in Michigan filed challenges this week to efforts to put two constitutional amendments on the ballot in November, one that would guarantee abortion rights and the other that would expand voting access.

title: Stacey Abrams’s Personal Evolution on Abortion Rights
description: The Georgia Democrat, a child of Methodist preachers, once identified as an abortion foe. Now, she is putting her defense of abortion rights — and the story of her conversion — at the center of her campaign for governor.
text: DUBLIN, Ga. — On the day that a leaked draft opinion suggested the Supreme Court was poised to overturn Roe v. Wade, Stacey Abrams addressed the abortion rights group Emily’s List and preached about abortion rights with “the zeal of the converted.”

title: Is a Fetus a Person? An Anti-Abortion Strategy Says Yes.
description: Fetal personhood, which confers legal rights from conception, is an effort to push beyond abortion bans and classify the procedure as murder. In Georgia, it also means a $3,000 tax credit.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: A partial recount in Kansas affirms a vote over abortion rights.
description: The state’s voters overwhelmingly rejected an anti-abortion constitutional amendment earlier this month.
text: A hand recount in nine Kansas counties affirmed the overwhelming rejection of an anti-abortion constitutional amendment by the state’s voters on Aug. 2.

title: 5 Issues to Watch in New York’s Primary
description: Several contentious races have stirred up intraparty fighting, with ramifications for Washington and how abortion politics will play out during the fall elections.
text: One of the most acrimonious congressional primary seasons New York has seen in living memory will move into the hands of voters on Tuesday. The results could shake the foundations of power in Washington.

title: Is It OK That My Co-Worker Keeps Her Anti-Abortion Views on the Down Low?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on withholding the truth when it may hurt you professionally.
text: Nearly nine years ago, I befriended a woman at work who, as I learned over the years of our now strong friendship, is staunchly pro-life. For her, the argument is both scientific and religious: Life starts at conception, and abortion is murder (no exceptions). She is morally consistent, though, in also being against the death penalty and in seeking out stronger social programs for families, like paid parental leave. We no longer work together, but we remain close friends and frequently discuss our views on abortion (I am pro-choice). Having a stronger understanding of one pro-life ideology has, I feel, expanded my thinking. I believe she is a good person who cares about the world immensely.

title: The Effort to Punish Women for Having Abortions
description: An extreme wing of the anti-abortion movement wants to criminalize the procedure as homicide.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Stella Tan, Rikki Novetsky, Luke Vander Ploeg, Marc Georges, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Marion Lozano
text: Even as the anti-abortion movement celebrates victories at the Supreme Court and in many states across the country, there is debate about where to go next.

title: Nadler Routs Maloney in Marquee Showdown of Bruising New York Primaries
description: In one of two closely watched races in the Hudson Valley, a Democratic county executive won a House special election by focusing his campaign on abortion.
text: Representative Jerrold Nadler, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, handily defeated his longtime congressional neighbor, Carolyn B. Maloney, in a bruising three-way primary battle on Tuesday that was preordained to end one of the powerful Democrats’ political careers.

title: Democrat Pat Ryan Wins in House Race That Turned on Abortion
description: Mr. Ryan, a county executive, defeated Marc Molinaro, a Republican, in the Hudson Valley special election.
text: HUDSON, N.Y. — Pat Ryan, a Democratic county executive in New York’s Hudson Valley, has won a special House election on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, in a contest that was seen as a potential test of the impact that the recent Supreme Court decision on abortion might have on the midterm elections.

title: What are the effects of new ‘trigger’ bans in Tennessee, Idaho and Texas?
description: The laws place new restrictions on access to abortion for millions of women and in some cases add punishments for doctors who perform the procedures.
text: Tennessee, Idaho and Texas began enforcing so-called trigger laws on Thursday, placing new restrictions on access to abortion for millions of women and in some cases adding punishments for doctors who perform the procedures.

title: Democrats Sense a Shift in the Political Winds, but It May Not Be Enough
description: A series of strong special election showings, culminating in a New York win, have buoyed Democratic confidence, but a daunting map may still cost them the House.
text: Energized abortion-rights voters. Donald J. Trump back in the spotlight. Stronger-than-expected special elections, including a surprising win early Wednesday in New York.

title: N.Y. Special Election Shows Power of Abortion Debate to Move Democrats
description: Pat Ryan, a Democrat, warns against “pulling our punches” on abortion and other issues during the midterm elections.
text: Within an hour of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade in June, Pat Ryan, a combat veteran, released an ad for his congressional campaign, stressing his support for abortion rights. After Kansans overwhelmingly voted to defend abortion protections this month, Mr. Ryan cast his upcoming race as the next major test of the issue’s power.

title: Judge Halts Part of Idaho’s Abortion Ban, Saying It Violates Health Law
description: The preliminary injunction was a limited but significant victory for the Biden administration after the Justice Department sued Idaho this month.
text: A federal judge in Idaho blocked part of the state’s strict abortion ban on Wednesday, delivering a limited but significant victory to the Biden administration, which has tried to use its limited power to protect reproductive rights since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.

title: After Roe’s End, Women Surged in Signing Up to Vote in Some States
description: The rise is particularly notable in states where abortion rights are at risk.
authors: By Francesca Paris and Nate Cohn
text: The rise is particularly notable in states where abortion rights are at risk.

title: Ads Begin in Texas Governor Race, With O’Rourke’s Highlighting Abortion
description: Last week, Gov. Greg Abbott released a first ad and, on Thursday, Beto O’Rourke, the former El Paso congressman and perennial Democratic hopeful, countered with two of his own.
text: HOUSTON — With early voting now two months away, the ad competition has begun in the race for Texas governor. Last week, Gov. Greg Abbott released a first ad and, on Thursday, Beto O’Rourke, the former El Paso congressman and perennial Democratic hopeful, countered with two of his own.

title: The Liberal Justice Who Warned Against an Activist Supreme Court
description: “Democratic Justice,” Brad Snyder’s comprehensive biography of Felix Frankfurter, aims to reassess the complicated legacy of the judge and political adviser.
text: In his concurring opinion in the Dobbs abortion case, which overturned Roe v. Wade, Chief Justice John Roberts invoked the wisdom of “a thoughtful member of this court” — namely, Felix Frankfurter. Like Frankfurter, who served as a justice from 1939 to 1962, Roberts argued that the Supreme Court should preserve its legitimacy by respecting precedents, deciding cases narrowly rather than broadly, and in most cases deferring to the democratic political process rather than second-guessing Congress and state legislatures.

title: Ron DeSantis’s Florida
description: How the Republican governor is turning the swing state into a right-wing laboratory.
text: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, who appears to be preparing to run for president in 2024, has achieved a national platform by leaning into cultural battles. He signed laws limiting what teachers can teach about race, sexual orientation and gender identity, and he recently suspended an elected prosecutor who said he would refuse to enforce the state’s anti-abortion laws.

title: F.T.C. sues over tracking data that could expose visits to abortion clinics.
description: Federal regulators said the sale of geolocation information on tens of millions of smartphones could expose people’s visits to private places.
text: Smartphone location tracking, a multibillion-dollar business in the United States, can reveal intimate details about Americans’ daily routines — including where they go for medical treatments, religious services or mental health counseling.

title: U.N. Race Panel Sounds the Alarm on Abortion Access in the U.S.
description: The influential committee called on the Biden administration to safeguard access for minorities and to address a host of issues on race relations.
text: GENEVA — An influential United Nations panel that examined the state of race relations in the United States called on the Biden administration on Tuesday to address a host of concerns, including imperiled abortion access for minorities, curbs on voting rights and the country’s “increasingly militarized approach” to immigration.

title: The Next Step in the Anti-Abortion Playbook Is Becoming Clear
description: Despite clear political headwinds, the movement has embraced a push for fetal personhood.
text: Two months after the fall of Roe v. Wade, abortion has been banned or severely restricted in at least 14 states, energizing leaders of the anti-abortion movement but also activating voters who are opposed to many of these measures. With so much at stake in the next few election cycles — and women’s lives hanging in the balance — both sides of this fight are strategizing their next moves.

title: Michigan Board Says Abortion Referendum Should Not Go to Voters
description: Abortion rights supporters gathered more than 750,000 signatures, but the petitions they circulated had formatting problems.
text: A state board in Michigan refused on Wednesday to place an abortion rights referendum on the November ballot because of a dispute over word spacing on the petition, an embarrassing blow to abortion rights supporters who had gathered more than 750,000 signatures.

title: As Republicans Turn to Fall Races, Their Sites Downplay Trump and Abortion
description: At least 10 Republican candidates in competitive races have updated their websites to minimize their ties to the former president or to adjust their stances on abortion.
text: For months, the campaign website for Adam Laxalt, the Republican Senate nominee in Nevada, greeted visitors with a huge banner exalting his endorsement from former President Donald J. Trump in all capital letters. Now, that information is nowhere on his home page.

title: Abortion rights loom larger in investment decisions.
description: After the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Alinea, an investing app geared toward young adults, saw a new focus on companies that support reproductive health.
text: In recent years, funds focused in investments that have a social impact have emerged to bet on start-ups advancing reproductive health and innovation. After the Supreme Court decision in June to overturn the constitutional right to an abortion, individual investors turned their attention to reproductive health care.

title: Prosecute Trump, Despite the Risks?
description: Readers react to an editorial urging an indictment to show that he “is not above the law.” Also: Abortion and data privacy; Moderna’s suit; children’s mental health.

title: Abortion Pill Providers Experiment With Ways to Broaden Access
description: These new efforts, which test the legal boundaries, have sprung up since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and many states restricted abortion.
text: As bans and restrictions proliferate across the country, abortion pill providers are pushing the envelope of regulations and laws to meet the surging demand for medication abortion in post-Roe America.

title: Chile Votes on Constitution That Would Enshrine Record Number of Rights
description: In a single ballot on Sunday, Chileans will decide on abortion, universal health care, rights for nature and a record expansion of constitutional rights.
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Voters in Chile on Sunday could transform what has long been one of Latin America’s most conservative countries into one of the world’s most left-leaning societies.

title: Quotation of the Day: Pressing Limits to Ease Delivery of Abortion Pill
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 4, 2022.
text: “We just don’t have a road map about how to provide medication abortion post-Roe, so it’s all being created right now.”

title: Chile Says ‘No’ to Left-Leaning Constitution After 3 Years of Debate
description: The rejected constitution would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enshrined more than 100 constitutional rights, a global record.
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — For the past three years, Chileans have fought over a path forward for their country in the form of a new constitution, written entirely from scratch, that would transform their society and grant more rights than any national charter before it.

title: Abortion and Trump Are Giving Democrats a Shot
description: This may be a year when politics gets flipped on its head.
text: Forget Hot Girl Summer. We just came off Hot Primary Summer, which featured fewer tequila shots than the Megan Thee Stallion-inspired original — unless, maybe, you were partying with Dr. Oz — but still packed way more drama than you’d expect in a midterm election cycle.

title: With Voters From Both Parties Energized, Campaigns Begin Fall Sprint
description: Republicans are focusing on pocketbook issues, and Democrats are emphasizing abortion rights, as Labor Day marks the start of the midterm elections’ final stretch.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
text: For two decades, midterm elections have served as a vehicle for voter discontent, a chance for Americans to punish the president, shake up a statehouse and express their anger with the party in power by costing them congressional seats and governor’s mansions.

title: Chileans Reject Left-Leaning Constitution
description: After three years of debate, Chileans voted against a new constitution that would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enacted more than 100 rights.
authors: By The Associated Press and Reuters
text: After three years of debate, Chileans voted against a new constitution that would have legalized abortion, adopted universal health care and enacted more than 100 rights.

title: Michigan Voters Will Decide Abortion Rights Question, Court Says
description: A state board had previously said the issue could not appear on the ballot because of word spacing problems on the petitions.
authors: By Mitch Smith and Julie Bosman
text: The Michigan Supreme Court said Thursday that voters would decide in November whether to add protections for abortion rights to the State Constitution, reversing the decision of a state board that had not allowed the proposal onto the ballot because of typographical problems on petition forms.

title: After Long Brawl, South Carolina Senate Approves More Abortion Restrictions
description: Legislators failed to advance a total ban on abortion, instead adding more restrictions to an existing law. The G.O.P. split over exceptions for rape and incest.
text: The South Carolina Senate voted Thursday night to tighten abortion restrictions but failed to pass a total ban after a heated debate revealed the ongoing struggle among Republicans to define a cohesive post-Roe strategy.

title: First Kansas, Next Michigan and Beyond as Abortion Ballot Measures Spread
description: Democrats are hoping ballot measures on abortion rights will drive up voter turnout. They’re looking to Michigan as a test run.
authors: By Jonathan Weisman and Nick Corasaniti
text: The inclusion of an abortion-rights referendum on Michigan’s November ballot has given Democrats hope for a wave of enthusiastic voter turnout on Election Day as the movement to allow voters to decide the issue directly sweeps outward from the first state that did so, Kansas.

title: ‘Do No Harm’: OB-GYNs Weigh the Legal Impact of Abortion Bans
description: As anti-abortion laws take effect across the country, doctors treating patients with high-risk pregnancies are facing difficult decisions — and legal risks — over their standards of care.
authors: By Nilo Tabrizy, Kassie Bracken, Mark Boyer and Mariam Dwedar
text: As anti-abortion laws take effect across the country, doctors treating patients with high-risk pregnancies are facing difficult decisions — and legal risks — over their standards of care.

title: Medical Impact of Roe Reversal Goes Well Beyond Abortion Clinics, Doctors Say
description: State abortion bans carry narrow but sometimes vague exceptions, and years of prison time. That’s forcing doctors to think like lawyers, and hospitals to create new protocols.
text: In Wisconsin, a group of doctors and lawyers is trying to come up with guidelines on how to comply with a newly revived 173-year-old law that prohibits abortion except to save the life of a pregnant woman. They face the daunting task of defining all the emergencies and conditions that might result in a pregnant woman’s death, and the fact that doctors could be punished with six years in prison if a prosecutor disagrees that abortion was necessary.

title: After Decades of Silence, Art About Abortion (Cautiously) Enters the Establishment
description: An art taboo is falling, from the Whitney Museum to the Armory Show to blue-chip galleries. Yet artists acknowledge self-censorship on the topic.
text: In recent years, a fashion for painting the human figure has preoccupied the art world, with an emphasis on race, gender and other urgent social issues. Yet another pressing topic in America has been curiously absent from art: abortion, which became all the more timely when the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June.

title: Graham Proposes 15-Week Abortion Ban, Splitting Republicans
description: The South Carolina senator’s bill was an effort to find a politically palatable position for his party before the midterm elections, in which abortion rights are expected to be a potent issue.
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina introduced legislation on Tuesday that would institute a federal ban on abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, reigniting debate on an issue that Republicans have worked to confront before midterm elections in which abortion rights have become a potent issue.

title: How a Proposed 15-Week Abortion Ban Compares With State Laws
description: A proposed federal ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy would stop short of some states’ limits on the procedure but would upend the longtime standard in most others.
authors: By Eleanor Lutz and Allison McCann
text: A proposed federal ban on abortion after 15 weeks of pregnancy would stop short of some states’ limits on the procedure but would upend the longtime standard in most others.

title: West Virginia Passes Strict Abortion Ban
description: The bill, which has some exceptions for rape, incest and the life of the mother, will go into effect immediately if the governor signs it.
text: West Virginia on Tuesday became the latest state to pass a near-total ban on abortion, with the two chambers of the Legislature reaching a compromise after deadlocking on the terms earlier this summer.

title: What a High-Risk Pregnancy Looks Like After Dobbs
description: The photographer Stephanie Sinclair captured the newly unsettled world inside the Cleveland Clinic, where Ohio’s abortion laws have drastically changed maternal care.
authors: By Stephanie Sinclair and Jaime Lowe
text: Pregnancy can be dangerous — occasionally fatal — for both women and the fetuses they hope to deliver. Fetal conditions, like a nonviable twin that threatens the health of its sibling, can also imperil the mother. So can disorders like cancer, heart disease, kidney dysfunction, diabetes and lupus. Even something as straightforward as age — becoming pregnant when younger than 17 or older than 35 — or carrying twins or having a history of multiple miscarriages can put women and pregnancies in jeopardy. That’s why so many obstetricians regard the ability to terminate a pregnancy as essential: Doctors need access to abortion procedures to be able to provide care and save lives.

title: Republicans Struggle to Unite Party Around National Abortion Restrictions
description: A new proposal was intended to align Republicans on abortion policy before the midterm elections. It only exposed divisions.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
text: For weeks, anti-abortion activists and their Republican allies have been quietly seeking to rally their party around a single platform on abortion, hoping to settle divisions and blunt political damage from an issue with growing potency in the midterm elections.

title: How Fierce Primaries, Abortion and Inflation Transformed the 2022 Map
description: Democrats enter the final sprint to November more optimistic than expected, especially in the race for the Senate. But Republicans remain bullish that they can sweep into a House majority.
text: A grueling primary season riven by Republican infighting and the interventions of former President Donald J. Trump finally ended on Tuesday with a slate of G.O.P. candidates that has raised Democratic hopes of preserving Senate control and a political atmosphere that has changed strikingly over the past six months.

title: What Conflicted Americans Fear Most From an Abortion Ban
description: How the necessity and complexity of life-of-the-mother exceptions is shaping the post-Roe debate.
text: In addition to granting new political hope to Democrats, the Supreme Court decision overturning Roe v. Wade has clarified the ground of public argument about abortion. As abortion-rights supporters have pressed their sudden political momentum, three pro-choice arguments have loomed particularly large: an argument about abortion in life-threatening circumstances; an argument about the unique physical costs of pregnancy in general; and an argument for the virtues of the Roe-era cultural status quo.

title: Lindsey Graham’s Unbelievably Cruel Abortion Ban
description: Either he doesn’t know how pregnancy works, or he doesn’t care.
text: At the end of Senator Lindsey Graham’s news conference on Tuesday proposing a national ban on abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, a woman named Ashbey Beasley stood up and asked him a question inspired by her own excruciating loss.

title: Ohio Judge Temporarily Suspends Abortion Ban
description: Abortion was illegal after six weeks of pregnancy, but a judge put the law on hold after abortion rights advocates sued the state.
text: An Ohio judge on Wednesday temporarily blocked the state’s ban on abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, saying that the right to abortion is protected under the state’s Constitution.

title: Could a National Abortion Ban Save Republicans?
description: An effort by Senator Lindsey Graham to mend a rift in his party seems to have backfired.
authors: By Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Luke Vander Ploeg, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Patricia Willens, Chelsea Daniel, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
text: With the midterm elections a few weeks away, Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, forwarded a plan to save his party from the growing backlash over abortion.

title: Republican Efforts to Ban or Restrict Abortions
description: Readers react to an article about divisions within the G.O.P. over abortion. Also: Lawmakers’ stock trades; the monarchy’s role; the Juul settlement.
text: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Buoyed by Abortion and Trump, Times/Siena Poll Finds
description: President Biden’s approval rating has climbed to 42 percent, and the number of Americans who believe the country is on the right track has doubled but remains low.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Nate Cohn
text: Even as they struggle to persuade voters that they should be trusted on the economy, Democrats remain unexpectedly competitive in the battle for Congress as the sprint to November’s midterm election begins, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found.

title: Did Fauci Lead America Astray on Covid?
description: Responses to an essay that criticized Anthony Fauci’s handling of the pandemic. Also: Migrants as props; abortion rights; David Milch; theater’s lessons.
text: To the Editor:

title: This Time, It’s Republicans on the Defensive on Social Issues
description: Republican missteps have helped to spotlight the party’s divisions on abortion and same-sex marriage, two issues on which their base is out of step with the general public.
text: WASHINGTON — Republicans have perfected the art of keeping the heat on Democrats on the searing social issues of the day, but this election year, it seems to be Republicans who are getting scorched.

title: Abortion Helps Realign Puerto Rico’s Politics, Giving Conservatives an Opening
description: Long-dominant political parties are losing power to new ones, including one trying to limit abortion in one of the few U.S. jurisdictions where it remains unrestricted.
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Three years ago, after Puerto Rico’s legislature narrowly defeated new abortion restrictions, the cardiologist and pastor Dr. César Vázquez Muñiz founded a new political party whose mission, he vowed, would include “defending life.”

title: Inflation Remains Voters’ Top Concern. Can Republicans Keep Their Focus?
description: Democrats and Republicans are running parallel campaigns, with one party emphasizing abortion and democracy, the other inflation and the economy — and both talking past each other.
text: Zach Nunn, an Iowa Republican challenging one of the House’s most vulnerable Democrats, had been talking for months about rising prices when a Texas congressman two weeks ago invited him to visit the Mexican border — to see the fentanyl confiscated, hear tales of dying migrants and witness overwhelmed border agents.

title: Democracy Challenged
description: Representative government faces its most serious threats in decades.
text: This is an election year unlike any we’ve experienced in recent decades. Not only do candidates of both major parties in the United States have starkly different views on the pressing issues of the day, including climate change, war, taxes, abortion, education, gender and sexual identity, immigration, crime and the role of government in American life. They also disagree on democracy itself, especially one of its essential pillars — willingness to accept defeat at the polls.

title: Republican Governors to Migrants: Go Away
description: “Govs. Greg Abbott and Ron DeSantis are using asylum seekers as political tools,” a reader writes. Also: President Biden and the pandemic; abortion prosecutors; arms for Ukraine.
text: To the Editor:

title: For Churches, Abortion Politics Is a Double-Edged Sword
description: Ireland and Poland went in entirely opposite directions on abortion. Why?
text: For the past several years, as I have struggled to put the escalating tumult of global abortion politics into some sort of order inside my own mind, I have returned over and over to two events.

title: Judge Temporarily Suspends Indiana Abortion Ban
description: The state prohibition had been in effect for only a week, and now abortions are legal again while a court fight goes forward.
text: An Indiana judge temporarily halted the state’s ban on most abortions on Thursday, a week after the law took effect.

title: Trump’s ‘Magical Powers’ of Declassification
description: Readers discuss declassification “by thinking” and an appellate court ruling. Also: Censorship, left and right; gay marriage; development aid; abortion art.
text: To the Editor:

title: As Cable News Focused on Queen, Democratic Political Donations Slipped
description: With less coverage of politics, the usual September rush of donations slowed. “It feels almost like we have to start over,” a Democratic fund-raiser said.
text: When the Republican Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina introduced a bill this month to ban abortions nationwide after 15 weeks, Democratic fund-raisers expected it to dominate news outlets like MSNBC, bringing small-dollar donations for candidates.

title: Arizona Judge Reinstates Strict Abortion Ban From 1864
description: A 15-week abortion ban passed this year will take effect on Saturday. But the attorney general has argued that the near-total ban from the 19th century should take precedence.
text: A judge on Friday ruled that a near-total abortion ban written before Arizona became a state must be enforced, throwing abortion access into question one day before the start of a 15-week ban that passed the Legislature this year.

title: Women’s Lives Put at Risk Under State Abortion Bans
description: Readers discuss a column by Ross Douthat about how ban exceptions would work.
text: To the Editor:

title: Better Ways for Us to Argue and Disagree
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about employing debate techniques. Also: Abortion laws; the Russia-Ukraine war; migrants welcome; Broadway today.
text: To the Editor:

title: Mastriano Said in 2019 That His Bill Would Treat Abortions as Murder
description: As a Pennsylvania senator, Doug Mastriano, now running for governor, pushed a bill to limit abortion. He indicated that women violating it should be treated as murderers.
text: Doug Mastriano, the far-right Republican nominee for governor in Pennsylvania, indicated in 2019 that women should be charged with murder if they violated a proposed abortion ban, a comment that Democrats on Tuesday highlighted as another example of Mr. Mastriano’s embrace of policies that are well outside the political mainstream.

title: What It Costs to Get an Abortion Now
description: With the procedure banned in 14 states, patients face added expenses for travel, lodging and child care. More of them are turning to charities for help.
text: With the procedure banned in 14 states, patients face added expenses for travel, lodging and child care. More of them are turning to charities for help.

title: G.O.P. Senate Candidate Strains to Win Over Arizona Independents
description: Blake Masters appears to be struggling among independent voters, who make up about a third of the state’s electorate. In interviews, more than one called him a “flip-flopper.”
text: PHOENIX — Blake Masters, the Republican nominee for Senate in Arizona, has brightened the music and tone of his television ads. He has erased from his website some of his most emphatically right-wing stances on immigration, abortion and the lie that the 2020 election was stolen.

title: In House Fight for N.Y. Suburbs, Will Abortion Turn Tide for Democrats?
description: Several competitive House races on Long Island have become fertile ground for candidates to test out common Republican and Democratic campaign themes.
text: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y. — A year ago, Republicans staged an uprising in the Long Island suburbs, winning a slew of races by zeroing in on public safety and suggesting that Democrats had allowed violent crime to fester.

title: ‘Good Businessman and Terrible Criminal’ Seeks Pot License
description: New York State is giving preference to those who have served time for marijuana offenses as it issues dispensary licenses.
text: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at people who were punished for drug offenses and are now applying to open retail cannabis dispensaries in New York State. We’ll also look at Gov. Kathy Hochul’s widening lead in her bid for her first full term, along with Democrats’ efforts to focus on abortion in House races in the suburbs.

title: In Tight Arizona Governor’s Race, a Democrat Looks to Abortion to Win
description: Katie Hobbs has struggled to compete against Republican Kari Lake, who is running on border security and election fraud conspiracy theories.
authors: By Jack Healy and Jazmine Ulloa
text: PHOENIX — Here was a debate that Katie Hobbs wanted to have.

title: ‘From the Hood to the Holler’ Review: A Race to Galvanize the Poor
description: A new documentary revisits the former Kentucky state representative Charles Booker’s 2020 campaign to unseat Mitch McConnell in the Senate.
text: At a hearing in 2019 for a vote on a bill that would restrict abortion access in Kentucky, Charles Booker, a state representative at the time, gave an impassioned speech about abortion rights, criticizing politicians who had compared the medical procedure to lynching. When the speaker of the Assembly tried to silence him, Booker yelled, “My life matters, too, speaker,” as an older white man screamed at him to “sit down.”

title: California and Gov. Gavin Newsom Hold the Blue Line
description: With bill signing finished, new laws will protect transgender children and abortion patients, and reflect Newsom’s national stance.
text: With what had to be the weariest left hand in California, Gov. Gavin Newsom on Friday signed the last of nearly 1,000 bills he approved this year.

title: Spanberger’s New Ad Attacks Her Opponent’s Abortion Stance
description: Representative Abigail Spanberger, Democrat of Virginia, is running against Yesli Vega, a Republican who has falsely suggested that pregnancy from rape may be unlikely.
text: Representative Abigail Spanberger, a Virginia Democrat locked in a competitive battle for re-election, is releasing a new ad that laces into her opponent’s stance on abortion rights, told from the perspective of a rape survivor.

title: In an Uphill Battle to Hold the House, Democrats Bet on Abortion Rights
description: Vulnerable Democrats in competitive districts have leaned into preserving abortion rights as a closing argument for their campaigns, buoyed by internal polls that show it has moved voters their way.
text: EAGAN, Minn. — Before dozens of volunteers fanned out through the Twin Cities suburbs to knock on voters’ doors on a recent sunny Saturday afternoon, Representative Angie Craig, Democrat of Minnesota, gathered them in a campaign office in a strip mall here to make sure they remembered a specific message.

title: Herschel Walker Paid for Girlfriend’s Abortion, Report Says
description: Mr. Walker called the report a lie, after The Daily Beast, which has also broken news about Mr. Walker’s out-of-wedlock children, reported that a former girlfriend had the procedure in 2009.
text: ATLANTA — Herschel Walker, the Republican nominee for U.S. Senate in Georgia and an avowed abortion opponent, paid for his then-girlfriend to have an abortion in 2009, according to a report published Monday in The Daily Beast. Mr. Walker called the claim “a flat-out lie.”

title: Risking Everything to Offer Abortions Across State Lines
description: Doctors and midwives in blue states are working to get abortion pills into red states — setting the stage for a historic legal clash.
text: When Linda Prine learned she was pregnant in 1970, she was a first-year college student in Wisconsin, where abortion was largely illegal. The doctor who gave her the news saw the look on Prine’s face and handed her a slip of paper with a phone number. Prine waited until other students in her dorm left for class to call from a phone in the hallway. The woman she spoke to gave her the names of psychiatrists and told her to persuade them that she would be suicidal if she were to have a baby. Prine followed the instructions and was able to get an appointment for an abortion at the university hospital.

title: Another Momentous Term for the Supreme Court
description: The justices have already set the United States on a more conservative course. Significant coming cases could continue the trend.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Diana Nguyen, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rob Szypko, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
text: The last Supreme Court term was a blockbuster. The justices made a number of landmark rulings, including in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, which ended 50 years of the constitutional right to abortion in the United States.

title: In Speedy Embrace of Herschel Walker, Republicans Make Familiar Political Bargain
description: While the Georgia Senate candidate denied a report that he paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, his Republican allies looked past the claims toward November.
authors: By Shane Goldmacher, Maya King and Lisa Lerer
text: Herschel Walker walked into the First Baptist Church of Atlanta on Tuesday with his Senate campaign in turmoil. A day earlier, an ex-girlfriend said he had paid for her to have an abortion, despite his public opposition to the procedure. His son slammed him on social media as a liar.

title: White House Unveils New Measures to Protect Abortion Access
description: President Biden urged voters to make their voices heard to preserve reproductive rights.
text: WASHINGTON — President Biden unveiled new measures on Tuesday to protect access to abortion, 100 days after the Supreme Court ended the constitutional right to terminate a pregnancy, and called on Americans to pressure Congress to pass legislation that would ensure abortion is legal across the United States.

title: LePage Stumbles on Abortion Questioning in Maine Governor’s Debate
description: After the end of Roe v. Wade, Republicans have struggled to hone a message on abortion, and Paul LePage, a former governor, was repeatedly pressed on the issue by Gov. Janet Mills on Tuesday.
authors: By Alyce McFadden and Michael C. Bender
text: Republicans’ struggles to find an effective abortion message this campaign season manifested themselves on Tuesday on a debate stage in the Maine governor’s race, as former Gov. Paul LePage repeatedly stumbled over a question about how he would handle the issue if voters returned him to office.

title: Stephen Colbert Pens Get-Well Card to Herschel Walker
description: Colbert did not mince words in his greeting to the Senate candidate, who denied paying for a former girlfriend’s abortion, as was reported by The Daily Beast.
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Are You ‘Third-Party-Curious’? Andrew Yang and David Jolly Would Like a Word.
description: Two co-founders of the Forward Party on how the two-party system fails American voters.
text: For years, hopeful reformers have touted the promise of third parties as an antidote to our political polarization. But when so many of the issues that voters care about most — like abortion, or climate change, or guns — are also the most divisive, can any third party actually bring voters together under a big tent? Or will it just fracture the electorate further?

title: What Do the Physical Costs of Pregnancy Mean for the Abortion Debate?
description: On the argument that pregnancy’s trauma justifies abortion rights.
text: “My pregnancies were not separate from me,” writes Charlotte Shane in the latest issue of Harper’s Magazine. “The growth would be impossible without my organic matter; nothing about it occurred without incorporating the material of me.” And this awareness of pregnancy’s power of physical coercion, its “protracted invasion, debilitation and deadly hazard,” brought with it a certain moral knowledge: The realization that she was pregnant “came with the understanding that I had the right not to be.”

title: How Did ‘Access Hollywood’ Become a G.O.P. Pep Talk?
description: Republicans have turned an episode of humiliation into a source of inspiration.
text: I wasn’t surprised in the least by an allegation this week that Herschel Walker, who has advocated a no-exceptions ban on abortions, once paid for a girlfriend to have one. Walker has adamantly denied the claim, which appeared in an article in The Daily Beast, and The Times hasn’t confirmed it. But if true, it’s hardly the first example of Republican hypocrisy along these lines. And his background has been an inexhaustible mine for opposition research. There’s dirt everywhere you dig.

title: G.O.P. Governor Candidate in Kansas Walks Abortion Tightrope in a Debate
description: The candidate, Derek Schmidt, is challenging Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, in a changed political landscape two months after Kansas voters rejected an anti-abortion constitutional amendment.
text: As Republicans on the ballot this fall navigate treacherous terrain on abortion, Derek Schmidt, the party’s nominee for governor in Kansas, said in a debate on Wednesday that officials would “have to respect” the decision voters made in August to preserve abortion rights in the state.

title: Gov. Brian Kemp Tiptoes Past Uproar Over Herschel Walker Abortion Report
description: Since a report in The Daily Beast said Mr. Walker, the Republican Senate candidate in Georgia, paid for an abortion in 2009, Mr. Kemp has offered no specific support nor condemnation.
text: ATLANTA — Gov. Brian Kemp of Georgia has been running a steady, drama-free campaign for re-election since he dispatched with his Trump-backed primary challenger in May. While screaming headlines and stumbles have dogged Herschel Walker’s Senate bid, Mr. Kemp has kept his head down and his mouth shut about his fellow Republican.

title: Woman Who Said Walker Paid for Abortion Is Also Mother of His Child, Report Says
description: New reporting from The Daily Beast appears to undercut Herschel Walker’s defense that he didn’t know the woman’s identity.
text: ATLANTA — The woman who told The Daily Beast on Monday that Herschel Walker had paid for her abortion in 2009 told the outlet on Wednesday that she was the mother of one of his children, undercutting his defense that he did not know her identity.

title: Barnard College Plans to Offer Abortion Pills on Campus
description: It is one of many colleges and universities deliberating over how to respond to the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
text: Barnard, the private women’s college in New York City, will begin offering abortion pills on campus next year, college officials announced Thursday.

title: ‘Battleground’ Review: A Look at the Anti-Abortion Movement
description: Months after Roe v. Wade was overturned, this documentary provides, if nothing else, a glimpse into the minds of the mobilized minority leading the anti-abortion charge.
text: Cynthia Lowen’s straightforward documentary “Battleground” follows three prominent anti-abortion campaigners in the few years leading up to 2022, when the Supreme Court ruled to overturn Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision protecting a woman’s right to an abortion.

title: Herschel Walker Sidesteps Abortion Issue at Georgia Campaign Stop
description: He has repeatedly denied a claim that he paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, and he avoided journalists’ questions in his first public appearance since the claim was reported.
authors: By Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
text: WADLEY, Ga. — Herschel Walker, the Republican candidate for U.S. Senate in Georgia, drove to a lumber yard on Thursday in this tiny town 150 miles east of Atlanta for his first public event since he was accused of paying for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion. But there was no getting away from the claim that threatens to upend his political aspirations.

title: Five Takeaways From the Arizona Senate Debate
description: Mark Kelly and Blake Masters fought over familiar ground, including abortion, the border and the 2020 election, as they were pressed to clarify their positions.
authors: By Jennifer Medina and Jack Healy
text: Check out how our reporter analysis unfolded live during the Arizona Senate debate.

title: An Abortion Ban With Unexpected Consequences for Older Mothers
description: Older women are more likely to carry fetuses with genetic disorders that often can’t be detected until 15 weeks of pregnancy, beyond the limit set in a Senate proposal.
text: When Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, proposed a national ban on abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy, the bill sparked controversy across the political spectrum. But few spoke of its potential impact on the growing number of women who are having children in their 30s.

title: In Illinois Governor’s Debate, Bailey Tries to Put Pritzker on Defensive
description: Even so, State Senator Darren Bailey, a far-right legislator, found himself having to explain his past statements comparing abortion to the Holocaust during the debate with Gov. J.B. Pritzker.
text: It is no secret that Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois has presidential ambitions. This year he has traveled to New Hampshire, used his billions to finance fellow Democratic candidates in critical states and made himself a national figure in the fight for abortion rights and gun control.

title: David Beckwith, Who Scooped the Supreme Court on Roe, Dies at 79
description: His article on the landmark abortion-rights ruling gained renewed attention this year after a draft of the opinion overturning that decision was leaked.
text: David Beckwith, who scored a scoop for Time magazine in 1973 when he reported the Supreme Court’s landmark Roe v. Wade abortion-rights ruling hours before it was officially announced, a feat that gained new attention this year after a draft of the court’s opinion overturning Roe was leaked in advance, died on Sunday at his home in Austin, Texas. He was 79.

title: Herschel Walker Urged Woman to Have a 2nd Abortion, She Says
description: The Georgia Senate candidate’s ex-girlfriend says he wanted her to terminate a pregnancy in 2011. She chose to have their son instead.
authors: By Maya King, Lisa Lerer and Jonah E. Bromwich
text: ATLANTA — A woman who has said Herschel Walker, the Republican Senate nominee in Georgia, paid for her abortion in 2009 told The New York Times that he urged her to terminate a second pregnancy two years later. They ended their relationship after she refused.

title: Judges in Ohio and Arizona Temporarily Block States’ Abortion Bans
description: The decisions offered a window into which legal arguments might be working in the broader strategy to re-establish abortion rights through state courts.
text: Abortion rights supporters won two temporary victories on Friday when judges in Ohio and Arizona suspended state laws banning the procedures.

title: Jill Biden, Rebuking ‘Extremist Republicans,’ Discusses Friend’s Abortion
description: The first lady said she had once helped a friend recover from an abortion before there was a constitutional right to the procedure. “Women will not let this country go backwards,” she said.
text: Jill Biden, the first lady, said on Friday that she had once helped a friend recover from an abortion before there was a constitutional right to the procedure, evoking the issue in deeply personal terms at a political fund-raiser as she warned of further restrictions from “extremist Republicans.”

title: Arizona Governor Candidates Speak, and More Campaign News From the Sunday Shows
description: Katie Hobbs and Kari Lake were interviewed back-to-back on CBS, Stacey Abrams spoke on Fox News and Republicans stuck with Herschel Walker despite reports that he had paid for an abortion.
text: There will be no debates in one of the most competitive governor’s races in the country — between Katie Hobbs, the Democratic secretary of state of Arizona, and Kari Lake, a former TV news anchor endorsed by Donald J. Trump — because Ms. Hobbs has refused to participate, arguing that Ms. Lake would create a “circus.”

title: ‘Saved by Grace’: Evangelicals Find a Way Forward With Herschel Walker
description: The embattled G.O.P. candidate reportedly paid for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion, but conservatives have learned to tolerate the behavior of those who advance their cause.
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Abortion Is Motivating Voters, but Republicans Would Rather Change the Subject
description: G.O.P. candidates have been changing their positions, erasing sections about abortion from their websites and trying to focus on topics like inflation, crime and immigration.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Katie Glueck
text: In Wisconsin, Tim Michels, a Republican running for governor, promised activists that he would never “flip-flop” on his support for an 1849 law that bans abortion except when a woman’s life is threatened. Less than three weeks later, he changed his stance.

title: A Republican Burden
description: Banning abortion is weighing on the party.
text: For years, abortion was a straightforward rallying cry for Republicans, a way to identify with the cultural politics of their core supporters in one word: pro-life.

title: In a Georgia Race Rife With Controversy, Warnock Is a Study in Restraint
description: As claims about Herschel Walker pile up, Senator Raphael Warnock has stuck with his strategy of bipartisan outreach, relying on ads to slam his opponent.
text: ATLANTA — A stream of jaw-dropping allegations have saturated the Georgia Senate race for months. Herschel Walker, the Republican candidate, has been accused of having children he did not publicly acknowledge, lying to his own campaign about them, misrepresenting his professional success and, last week, paying for an ex-girlfriend’s abortion despite his public opposition to the procedure. He denies it all.

title: What Is Your Reaction to the State of Abortion Rights in 2022?
description: On June 24, the Supreme Court eliminated the constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years. How will the decision affect you and your community?
text: Please Note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on NYTimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

title: Teaching and Learning About Abortion Laws in the United States After Roe
description: In this teaching resource, we provide resources and activities so students can explore key questions related to abortion laws and rights.
authors: By Natalie Proulx, Michael Gonchar and Jeremy Engle
text: On June 24, the Supreme Court overruled Roe v. Wade, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years in a decision that will transform American life, reshape the nation’s politics and lead to all but total bans on the procedure in about half of the states.

title: Some Couples Use Wedding Registries to Fund-Raise for Abortion Rights
description: On websites including Zola and the Knot, the number of registries requesting donations in support of reproductive rights has risen as the debate over abortion has moved to the political forefront.
text: When Jen McCartney and Jay Balagna made a registry for their wedding on Oct. 29, among the typical items they included — plates, towels, tablecloths — was a less traditional request: donations to the National Network of Abortion Funds.

title: Mike Pence Runs Toward Abortion Fight
description: While many in the G.O.P. are trying to avoid talking about abortion in the weeks before midterm elections, the former vice president wants to make the procedure “unthinkable.”
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Former Vice President Mike Pence shared his vision for a post-Roe America on Thursday evening, supporting efforts to further limit abortion rights, even as many in the Republican Party are running away from the issue in the final stretch of the midterm elections.

title: Five Key Moments From the Walker-Warnock Debate in Georgia
description: Herschel Walker had a badge, Raphael Warnock had a quip about his opponent’s law enforcement claims, and the candidates sparred on abortion.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Maya King
text: The debate between Senator Raphael Warnock and his less experienced Republican challenger, Herschel Walker, had its share of sharp clashes, as the two candidates in one of the country’s most-watched Senate races faced off for their one and only debate.

title: How Volunteers Open Their Homes to Women Seeking Abortions
description: Home stays have roots in a pre-Roe America, where women frequently traveled long distances for abortions.
text: The woman arrived at Jill’s Chicago apartment at around 10 at night. Her bus had been delayed for hours, and she was exhausted and nauseated, clutching a plastic bag with a container of Jell-O and a Powerade.

title: How a Republican Could Lead Oregon: Liberal Disharmony and Nike Cash
description: In a wild governor’s race, an independent candidate is siphoning Democratic votes and a billionaire Nike co-founder is pouring in money — giving an anti-abortion Republican a path to victory.
authors: By Mike Baker and Reid J. Epstein
text: MONROE, Ore. — Democrats haven’t lost a governor’s race in Oregon in four decades. Two years ago, Joseph R. Biden Jr. won the state by 16 percentage points. The only Republican to win a statewide election since 2002 died before finishing his term.

title: Republicans Gain Edge as Voters Worry About Economy, Times/Siena Poll Finds
description: With elections next month, independents, especially women, are swinging to the G.O.P. despite Democrats’ focus on abortion rights. Disapproval of President Biden seems to be hurting his party.
text: Republicans enter the final weeks of the contest for control of Congress with a narrow but distinct advantage as the economy and inflation have surged as the dominant concerns, giving the party momentum to take back power from Democrats in next month’s midterm elections, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found.

title: Abortions Are Legal in Ethiopia. But Half of These Clinics Won’t Provide Them.
description: A half-century-old U.S. law is stripping women of abortion rights they are legally entitled to in their home countries.
text: A half-century-old U.S. law is stripping women of abortion rights they are legally entitled to in their home countries.

title: 5 Takeaways From the Utah Senate Debate
description: Senator Mike Lee and Evan McMullin sparred about Donald Trump and Jan. 6, and had common ground on abortion.
text: Senator Mike Lee, Republican of Utah, and his independent challenger, Evan McMullin, a former C.I.A. officer, met Monday evening for their only debate, a largely genteel affair that showed flashes of tension mainly around Mr. Lee’s role in the effort to overturn the results of the 2020 election and keep Donald J. Trump in the presidency.

title: What Does ‘Abortion’ Mean? Even the Word Itself Is Up for Debate.
description: In medical terms, the definition is clear. But when disputes arise, opponents argue that not every termination is an abortion.
text: Even after five decades of argument about abortion in the United States, the most contentious question newly at the forefront is a very basic one: What is abortion?

title: Film Club: ‘48 Hours in a Kansas Abortion Clinic: Longer Wait Times, Growing Fears’
description: How has the growing number of state abortion bans affected women and health providers across the country?
text: On June 24, the Supreme Court overruled Roe v. Wade, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion after almost 50 years in a decision that will transform American life, reshape the nation’s politics and lead to all but total bans on the procedure in about half of the states.

title: Biden Says Codifying Roe Will Be a Priority if Democrats Expand Majorities
