text: Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, who died Friday at 93, was the sort of figure once familiar in American political and judicial life: a moderate Republican ready to look for compromise and common ground.

title: Talk About Abortion, Don’t Talk About Trump: Governors Give Biden Advice
description: At an annual gathering in Arizona, Democratic governors offered a series of explanations for the president’s political struggles and suggested ideas for selling voters on his re-election.
text: America’s Democratic governors brag about booming local economies, preside over ribbon-cuttings of projects paid for with new federal legislation and have successfully framed themselves as defenders of abortion rights and democracy.

title: Tuberville Drops Blockade of Most Military Promotions
description: Under pressure from senators in both parties, the Alabama Republican allowed more than 400 promotions to move forward, saying he would continue to block only the most senior positions.
text: Senator Tommy Tuberville, Republican of Alabama, on Tuesday lifted his blockade of nearly all the military promotions he had delayed for almost a year in protest of a Pentagon policy ensuring abortion access for service members, saying he would continue to hold up only the most senior generals.

title: Texas Woman Asks Court to Allow Her Abortion
description: A woman who is 20 weeks pregnant, and whose fetus has been diagnosed with a deadly condition, is suing for an abortion under a medical exception to the state’s bans.
text: A pregnant Texas woman whose fetus has a fatal condition sued the state on Tuesday seeking an emergency court order to allow her doctor to perform an abortion, despite the state’s strict bans on the procedure.

title: Senator Says He Will Drop His Blockade of Most Military Promotions
description: Also, a top Democratic donor boosts Nikki Haley. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
text: Senator Tommy Tuberville, Republican of Alabama, announced today that he would lift his blockade of nearly all the military promotions he had delayed for months to protest a Pentagon policy ensuring abortion access for service members.

title: Our Columnists Aren’t Moderating Tonight’s Debate. Here’s What They’d Ask if They Were.
description: They propose questions designed to test the candidates on guns and crime, foreign wars and health care.
text: Wednesday night’s Republican presidential debate, held in Tuscaloosa, Ala., will feature just four candidates — Nikki Haley, Ron DeSantis, Vivek Ramaswamy and Chris Christie — sparring over everything from abortion to Israel to former President Donald Trump. When we asked Times Opinion columnists and contributors what they would ask the candidates if they were moderating the debate, they came back to us with questions designed to test them on guns and crime, foreign wars and health care — exposing where the field stands on, say, military aid for Ukraine or a draconian state abortion ban. But above all, what they wanted to see was the moderators needling the candidates into taking a strong stance on the former president. Here are the responses:

title: Texas Judge Grants Woman’s Request for Abortion, in Rare Post-Roe Case
description: A state court judge said a woman whose fetus was diagnosed with a fatal condition could legally obtain an abortion despite the state’s bans.
text: A Texas judge granted a request on Thursday to allow an abortion despite the state’s strict bans, ruling in the case of a pregnant woman whose fetus was diagnosed with a fatal condition.

title: Remembering Norman Lear’s Most Controversial Episode
description: A two-part November 1972 episode of “Maude,” in which the title character decides to get an abortion, still seems radical, particularly after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
text: Norman Lear, who died this week at 101, left behind a legacy of groundbreaking television. But there was perhaps no hour of TV on his lengthy résumé more controversial than a two-part episode of the CBS sitcom “Maude,” from the show’s first season.

title: A Texas Judge Granted a Woman’s Request for an Abortion
description: Also, Israeli evidence of Hamas operations. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
text: Despite Texas’ strict ban on abortion, a judge there ruled today that Kate Cox, whose fetus was diagnosed with a fatal condition, could terminate her 20-week pregnancy. Her case is believed to be among the first attempts to seek a court-approved abortion since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year.

title: Defense Bill Agreement Angers Hard Right, Posing a Threat to Johnson
description: The new Republican speaker is facing fury from ultraconservative lawmakers for agreeing to drop limits on abortion, transgender care and diversity training.
text: The annual defense bill has become entangled in a tumultuous Republican feud in the House, as hard-right lawmakers revolt over a bipartisan agreement to jettison a raft of deeply partisan dictates that would have limited abortion access, transgender care and diversity training.

title: A Texas Court’s Approval of an Abortion Request
description: Readers discuss a judge’s ruling in a case in which the fetus had a fatal condition. Also: Aid to Ukraine; a threat to the media; teaching civics.
text: To the Editor:

title: Texas Supreme Court Temporarily Halts Court-Approved Abortion
description: The court, responding to an appeal from Attorney General Ken Paxton, put on hold a lower court order allowing an abortion for a woman whose fetus has a fatal condition.
text: The Texas Supreme Court late Friday temporarily halted a lower court order allowing a Dallas woman to obtain an abortion in spite of the state’s strict bans, after she learned her fetus has a fatal condition.

title: Texas Supreme Court Rules Against Woman Who Sought Court-Approved Abortion
description: Hours before the ruling, a group representing the woman, whose fetus received a fatal diagnosis, said she was leaving Texas for an abortion.
text: The Texas Supreme Court on Monday overturned a lower court order allowing an abortion for a pregnant woman whose fetus was diagnosed with a fatal condition, hours after her lawyers said she had decided to leave Texas for the procedure in the face of the state’s abortion bans.

title: A Texas Case Shows That Abortion Ban Exemptions Are a Sham
description: Kate Cox’s predicament exposes the lie behind anti-abortion groups’ claims.
text: This essay has been updated to reflect news developments.

title: Zelensky in Washington, and a Texas Abortion Case Ruling
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
text: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

title: What Is the Real Meaning of ‘Pro-Life’?
description: A discussion about the phrase’s ambiguous meaning among Republicans. Also: The Texas abortion ruling; speech on campus; the Electoral College; Trump and NATO.
text: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Will Hear Challenge to Abortion Pill Access
description: The justices announced that they would hear a case challenging a federal agency’s approval of the commonly used pill.
text: The Supreme Court announced on Wednesday that it would decide on the availability of a commonly used abortion pill, the first major case involving abortion on its docket since it overturned the constitutional right to the procedure more than a year ago.

title: Abortion Ruling Keeps Texas Doctors Afraid of Prosecution
description: In ruling that a pregnant woman did not qualify for a medical exception to abortion bans, the Texas Supreme Court left doctors without clear guidance on which cases might pass legal muster.
text: Texas doctors, women and lawyers have been asking the state for nearly two years to clarify what is and what is not allowed under strict, overlapping abortion bans. Lawmakers passed a bill this year that makes some exceptions to the bans clearer, but it wasn’t enough to help doctors decide whether they could legally give a Dallas woman, Kate Cox, an abortion.

title: Democrats Seize on Texas Case in Push for Abortion Rights
description: Democratic candidates jumped on the story of a woman who left Texas for an abortion as a cautionary tale for voters, and Republicans were largely silent.
text: The case of a Texas woman who sought a court-approved abortion but wound up leaving the state for the procedure is reigniting political arguments that have roiled elections for more than two years, placing Democrats on the offensive and illustrating Republicans’ continued lack of a unified policy response or clear strategy on how to talk about the issue.

title: Senate Passes Defense Bill, Steering Clear of Far-Right Policy Dictates
description: The $886 billion legislation is the product of bipartisan negotiations between the House and Senate in which right-wing restrictions on abortion, transgender care and diversity initiatives were jettisoned.
text: The Senate on Wednesday overwhelmingly passed an $886 billion defense bill that would set Pentagon policy and provide a 5.2 percent pay raise for military personnel, defying the demands of Republicans who failed to attach a raft of deeply partisan restrictions on abortion, transgender care and diversity initiatives.

title: The Woman Who Fought the Texas Abortion Ban
description: Kate Cox is at the heart of one of the most contentious cases since the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Jessica Cheung, Mary Wilson, Lisa Chow, Brendan Klinkenberg, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
text: A major case in Texas this week drew attention to the question of who can get exempted from an abortion ban. Most states that have banned the procedure allow for rare exceptions, but while that might seem clear on paper, in practice, it’s far more ambiguous.

title: House Passes Defense Bill, Clearing It for Biden
description: Republicans and Democrats banded together to push through the legislation over the objections of right-wing lawmakers, who had sought abortion, transgender care and diversity restrictions.
text: The House on Thursday overwhelmingly passed an $886 billion defense bill, clearing the measure for President Biden after pushing past a revolt from the far right over the exclusion of restrictions they had sought to abortion access, transgender care, and racial diversity and inclusion policies at the Pentagon.

title: Inside the Supreme Court’s Dismantling of Roe
description: The Supreme Court deliberates in secret. Insiders who speak can be cast out of the fold. This is the behind-the-scenes story of how the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion — shooting down compromise and testing the bounda...
authors: By Karen Hanley, Rebecca Suner and James Surdam
text: The Supreme Court deliberates in secret. Insiders who speak can be cast out of the fold. This is the behind-the-scenes story of how the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion — shooting down compromise and testing the boundaries of how the law is decided.

title: Behind the Scenes at the Dismantling of Roe v. Wade
description: This is the inside story of how the Supreme Court overturned the constitutional right to abortion — shooting down compromise and testing the boundaries of how the law is decided.
authors: By Jodi Kantor and Adam Liptak
text: On Feb. 10 last year, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. showed his eight colleagues how he intended to uproot the constitutional right to abortion.

title: 5 Takeaways From Inside the Overturning of Roe v. Wade
description: A Times investigation reveals the behind-the-scenes story of how the Supreme Court abolished the constitutional right to abortion.
authors: By Jodi Kantor and Adam Liptak
text: By the time the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year, a draft of the ruling had been leaked to the press and the outcome was anticipated. The story behind the decision seemed obvious: The constitutional right to abortion effectively had died with Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose replacement, Amy Coney Barrett, was a favorite of the anti-abortion movement.

title: Why Democracy Hasn’t Settled the Abortion Question
description: Post-Roe voting might bring America to a new consensus — but only if the voters keep getting their say.
text: As long as the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade was the law of the land, conservatives complained that it had squelched the democratic process — that unelected men in black robes had handed down a national edict rather than letting the American people sort out a consensus.

title: What Happened to Kate Cox Is Tragic, and Completely Expected
description: It’s very hard to determine when an abortion is medically necessary.
text: Many people were shocked when the Texas Supreme Court intervened recently to stop Kate Cox from getting an abortion in the state — an abortion needed to protect her health and future fertility after her fetus was diagnosed with a severe fetal anomaly in her second trimester. She ultimately traveled out of state to get the abortion she needed.

title: Harris Will Tour the Country in Support of Abortion Rights
description: The vice president has been the administration’s most forceful voice for abortion rights in the year and a half since Roe v. Wade fell.
text: Vice President Kamala Harris will tour the country next year to host events in support of abortion rights, a galvanizing issue for Democrats and one that has become a focus for the vice president in the months since Roe v. Wade was overturned last summer.

title: Trump’s Disqualification by a Colorado Court
description: Readers discuss a court ruling based on the 14th Amendment. Also: Abortion laws; climate tax; Holocaust movies.
text: To the Editor:

title: A Forgotten Chapter of Abortion History Repeats Itself
description: More than 60 years ago, America was confronted with the story of a young woman forced to seek an abortion abroad after unwittingly taking a drug that caused severe birth defects.
text: Much of the country no doubt watched in amazement last week as a woman with a doomed pregnancy was forced to flee her home state, Texas, to get the abortion her doctors deemed necessary to protect her future ability to bear children. Could this really be happening in the United States in 2023?

title: The Free Speech Debate on Campus About the Israel-Gaza War
description: Readers discuss what sort of speech should be permissible and fears about speaking up. Also: Hillary Clinton scenario; traveling for abortions; morning sickness.
text: To the Editor:

title: Arsonist Ordered to Pay Nearly $300,000 for Damages to Wyoming Abortion Clinic
description: A woman serving a five-year sentence for setting fire to an abortion clinic in Casper, Wyo., in 2022 has been ordered to pay restitution to the clinic and its insurance company.
text: A federal judge has ordered a woman serving a five-year sentence for setting fire to an abortion clinic in Wyoming last year to pay nearly $300,000 in restitution, according to documents filed in the U.S. District Court in Wyoming.

title: A Gaza Mayor’s View of the Conflict
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about the war’s toll in Gaza. Also: Western businesses in Russia; abortion pill case; dogs and social media.
text: To the Editor:

title: More Women Who Are Not Pregnant Are Ordering Abortion Pills Just in Case
description: Rates of requests were highest in states where abortion bans were expected.
text: Tens of thousands of women who are not pregnant are ordering abortion pills just in case they might need them someday, especially in states where access is threatened, according to a study published on Tuesday.

title: What the Civil War Was About
description: Yes, it was about slavery — and slavery was driven by greed.
text: Of course the Civil War was about slavery, and everyone knew it at the time. No, Nikki Haley, it wasn’t about states’ rights, except to the extent that Southern states were trying to force Northern states to help maintain slavery — something that, as I’ll explain in a bit, has echoes in the current fight over abortion rights.

title: Court Rules Texas Can Ban Emergency Abortions Despite Federal Guidance
description: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit affirmed a ruling that sided with the state on whether emergency rooms are required to perform emergency abortions.
text: Emergency room doctors in Texas are not required to perform emergency abortions despite federal guidance that requires hospitals to offer stabilizing care, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Idaho’s Strict Abortion Ban
description: The court also temporarily reinstated the state law, which the Biden administration said conflicts with a federal statute on emergency-room care.
text: The Supreme Court agreed on Friday to hear a challenge to Idaho’s near-total ban on abortions, which the Biden administration said conflicted with a federal statute that allowed for some exceptions.

title: In Speech, New Jersey Governor Backs Phonics and Medical Debt Relief
description: “Nobody should have to worry about being able to afford critical health care,” Gov. Philip D. Murphy said in his sixth-annual State of the State address.
text: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey embraced proposals to make it easier to build affordable housing and cut out-of-pocket expenses for abortions in his annual State of the State address on Tuesday.

title: With Roe Gone, Some House Republicans Back Away From National Abortion Ban
description: Nearly three dozen House Republicans who supported a federal abortion ban in the last Congress have yet to sign on this year, reflecting a shifting political calculus after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
text: In 2021, Representative Michelle Steel, a California Republican whose district President Biden won in 2020, cosponsored the Life at Conception Act, a bill to recognize a fertilized egg as a person with equal protections under the 14th Amendment.

title: Dobbs Didn’t Reduce Abortions. The Anti-Abortion Movement Needs a New Vision.
description: The pro-life movement once championed a safety net for pregnant women. It should return to that idea.
text: Most abortion opponents did not expect the overturning of Roe v. Wade and the passage of state abortion bans to lead to the expansion of legal abortion in much of the United States.

title: How Much Power Should Government Experts Have?
description: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments yesterday on one of the biggest cases of the current term.
text: Now that abortion is restricted and affirmative action is hobbled, the conservative legal movement has set its sights on a third precedent: Chevron v. Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: Abortion-Rights Backers in Missouri Start Ballot Initiative to Undo Ban
description: Advocates present a united front after disagreements over how far they could go in asking voters to legalize abortion in the state.
text: A coalition of reproductive-rights groups in Missouri kicked off a campaign on Thursday to establish a right to abortion in the state constitution, setting up the nation’s next big test of public support for legalized abortion.

title: What to Know About the Federal Law at the Heart of the Latest Supreme Court Abortion Case
description: The federal Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act, known as EMTALA, requires hospitals to provide medically necessary care to stabilize patients in emergency situations.
text: One of the newest battlefields in the abortion debate is a decades-old federal law called the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act, known by doctors and health policymakers as EMTALA.

title: Abortion Opponents March in Washington, With Obstacles Ahead
description: A year after celebrating the reversal of Roe v. Wade, the annual March for Life gathered Friday in a very different political climate.
text: Last year, anti-abortion activists descended on the National Mall in triumph for the annual March for Life, eager to enter a new era for their ambitions to end abortion following the reversal of Roe v. Wade, the landmark Supreme Court ruling that established federal abortion rights.

title: Biden Campaign Sharpens Its Post-Roe Message: Abortion Is About Freedom
description: In events next week, the president and vice president will argue that abortion access is crucial to personal freedoms, and warn of what is at stake if Donald J. Trump is re-elected.
text: President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris will headline events next week centered around protecting abortion rights, throwing more heft behind an issue that has galvanized voters in the 18 months since the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade.

title: Biden Ad Shows Woman Forced to Leave Texas to End Dangerous Pregnancy
description: The new ad from the president’s campaign features the testimonial of Dr. Austin Dennard, who left Texas to end a life-threatening pregnancy because of the state’s abortion ban.
text: President Biden’s campaign is releasing a new advertisement featuring the testimonial of a woman who was forced to leave Texas to end a planned pregnancy that put her life at risk.

title: Biden and Harris Target Abortion Laws, and Trump, on Roe’s 51st Anniversary
description: The president said abortion restrictions “have no place” in the United States. The vice president was more blunt: “These extremists are trying to take us backward, but we’re not having that.”
text: Vice President Kamala Harris visited Wisconsin on Monday to begin a national tour in support of reproductive rights and highlight steps the Biden administration has taken to navigate around restrictive abortion laws in the United States.

title: Biden, Harris Criticize Republican Efforts to Ban Abortion
description: On the 51st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris denounced former President Trump and congressional Republicans for expanding restrictive abortion laws across the nation.
text: On the 51st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris denounced former President Trump and congressional Republicans for expanding restrictive abortion laws across the nation.

title: Biden, Brushing Off Gaza Protesters at Rally, Calls for Restoring Abortion Rights
description: The event was interrupted by at least 10 people protesting the war in Gaza, but the president focused on calling attention to restrictive abortion laws.
text: President Biden headlined a rally in support of abortion rights on Tuesday, trying to focus on an issue that has galvanized his supporters even as he was interrupted every few minutes by at least 10 people protesting the war in Gaza, an issue that has just as quickly divided Democrats.

title: What Happens After You Ask if Your Date Is Pro-Choice?
description: For the under-30 set, it really depends.
text: A few weeks ago, when I asked Times readers under 30 how politics influences their dating lives, I expected that the subject of reproductive choice would come up pretty frequently. After all, there are few political issues that affect dating and relationships quite as intimately or permanently, and since the overturning of Roe v. Wade in 2022, theirs is the first generation of young people since the 1970s who may be living in states where abortion isn’t legal.

title: Dobbs Overturned Much More Than Roe v. Wade
description: Lawmakers in Tennessee, Oklahoma and other Republican states want to turn the clock back to the 19th century.
text: Most of my writing this week was on the recent elections in Iowa and New Hampshire, but most of my reading was focused elsewhere. In particular, I want to highlight this report from Jessica Valenti, published in her excellent newsletter, on proposed travel bans for abortion care in Tennessee and Oklahoma. The Tennessee ban, proposed by State Representative Jason Zachary, would make it a felony to take a minor out of state to obtain an abortion. As Valenti notes, “That means a friend, aunt or grandmother who helps a teenager get an abortion could be sent to prison for 15 years.” The Oklahoma bill, if signed into law, would punish anyone who helped a minor obtain abortion care with up to five years in prison.

title: Charles Fried, Legal Scholar Who Broke With Conservatives, Dies at 88
description: As solicitor general under Reagan, he argued against abortion rights and affirmative action. But he came to see the current Supreme Court as “reactionary, not conservative.”
text: Charles Fried, a conservative legal scholar who as President Ronald Reagan’s solicitor general argued against abortion rights and affirmative action before the Supreme Court — but who later rejected the conservative legal movement’s rightward march, calling the current high court “reactionary” — died on Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88.

title: In the Race to Replace George Santos, National Issues Reverberate
description: Here’s what you need to know about the special House election on Feb. 13, pitting former Representative Tom Suozzi, a Democrat, against the Republican Party’s candidate, Mazi Pilip, a local legislator.
text: The Israel-Hamas war. Abortion rights. Immigration policy.

title: How Trump Could Institute a Backdoor Federal Abortion Ban
description: President Biden should be clear about the risks of a second Trump term.
text: For many Americans who support abortion rights, the election in November will most likely come down to a choice between voting for President Biden and staying home. They won’t vote for the man who ensured Roe v. Wade’s demise, but many of them are unenthusiastic about the prospect of Mr. Biden being the Democratic nominee.

title: Why Democrats Are Using Personal Abortion Stories
description: Plus: A Taylor Swift endorsement is Biden’s wildest dream.
text: When Dr. Austin Dennard, an OB-GYN in Dallas, learned that her 11-week-old fetus had a fatal medical condition in July 2022, she immediately understood the medical implications.

title: French Lawmakers Vote to Enshrine Abortion Rights in Constitution
description: Most of France’s political parties broadly support the right to abortion. But the proposal still has to undergo a long and complex legislative process before it comes to fruition.
text: French lawmakers on Tuesday overwhelmingly approved a bill to enshrine abortion rights in France’s Constitution, the first step in a complex legislative process that began in direct response to the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: A Second Trump Term Could Lead to a ‘Backdoor Federal Abortion Ban’
description: The future of reproductive rights in America may hinge on the next election.
authors: By Mary Ziegler and Jillian Weinberger
text: With Donald Trump seemingly unstoppable in his bid for the Republican presidential nomination, the law professor Mary Ziegler considers what a second Trump term would mean for abortion rights. In this audio essay, she argues that while Trump may seem indifferent on the campaign trail to tightening abortion laws, there is a real possibility that if re-elected he will seek to appease his base by using his executive power to ban abortions nationwide.

title: Florida Court Weighs Ballot Measure to Allow Abortion ‘Before Viability’
description: Several justices pushed back on Wednesday against arguments that the language of the proposed constitutional amendment was too broad and would deceive voters.
text: The Florida Supreme Court seemed reluctant on Wednesday to block a proposed measure protecting abortion rights from appearing on the November ballot, even though several members of the conservative-leaning court questioned whether the measure’s language made clear its potentially sweeping effects.

title: Man Who Drugged Wife’s Drinks to Cause Abortion Gets 180 Days in Jail
description: Mason Herring, 39, of Houston, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to injury of a child and assault of a pregnant woman.
text: A Texas man who drugged his wife’s drinks in an unsuccessful attempt to induce an abortion was sentenced on Wednesday to 180 days in jail and 10 years of probation, the Harris County district clerk’s office said.

title: Who Will Replace George Santos? Takeaways From the Pilip-Suozzi Debate
description: Five days before a special House election in New York, Tom Suozzi and Mazi Pilip traded blows in the race’s lone debate.
text: The candidates vying to replace George Santos in a special House election squared off on Thursday in an exceedingly bitter debate, tangling over the roots of New York City’s migrant crisis, abortion rights and, at one point, the definition of “assault weapon.”

title: Journal Retracts Studies Cited in Federal Court Ruling Against Abortion Pill
description: The journal found that the studies, which had suggested that medication abortion is unsafe, included incorrect factual assumptions and misleading presentation of the data.
text: An academic journal publisher this week retracted two studies that were cited by a federal judge in Texas last year when he ruled that the abortion pill mifepristone should be taken off the market.

title: Don’t Underestimate the Mobilizing Force of Abortion
description: Poland voted out authoritarianism. Reproductive rights tipped the scales.
authors: By Michelle Goldberg and Jillian Weinberger
text: Poland recently ousted its right-wing, nationalist Law and Justice Party. In 2020, a party-appointed tribunal severely restricted the country’s abortion rights, sparking nationwide protests and an opposition movement. After a trip to Poland, the Times Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg came to recognize that similar dynamics could prevail in the United States in 2024. In this audio essay, she argues that Joe Biden’s campaign should take note of what a “powerful mobilizing force the backlash to abortion bans can be.”

title: Abortions by Telemedicine and Mailed Pills Are Safe and Effective, Study Finds
description: Researchers analyzed the experiences of more than 6,000 women and found the method to be 98 percent effective and safe for 99 percent of patients.
text: Taking abortion pills prescribed through telemedicine and received by mail — a method used by growing numbers of abortion patients — is as safe and effective as when the pills are obtained by visiting a doctor, a large new study found. The method was about 98 percent effective and was safe for over 99 percent of patients, the study reported.

title: The Meaning of the Super Bowl ‘He Gets Us’ Ad
description: It’s a challenge to Christians to forgo hate and practice love.
text: During Super Bowl Sunday, a 60-second ad aired about Jesus Christ, and no one seemed angrier about it than Christians. The ad depicts a series of images of one person washing another person’s feet. Each pairing seems unlikely. An oil rig worker washes the feet of a climate activist. A cop washes the feet of a young Black man. An older woman washes the feet of a young woman outside an apparent abortion clinic while abortion protesters look on. A priest washes the feet of a young gay man. As the commercial ends, words appear on the screen: “Jesus didn’t teach hate. He washed feet.”

title: Trump Privately Expresses Support for a 16-Week Abortion Ban
description: In supporting a 16-week ban with exceptions, Donald Trump appears to be trying to satisfy social conservatives who want to further restrict abortion access and voters who want more modest limits.
authors: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Lisa Lerer
text: Former President Donald J. Trump has told advisers and allies that he likes the idea of a 16-week national abortion ban with three exceptions, in cases of rape or incest, or to save the life of the mother, according to two people with direct knowledge of Mr. Trump’s deliberations.

title: Trump Allies Plan New Sweeping Abortion Restrictions
description: His supporters are seeking to attack abortion rights and abortion access from a variety of angles should he regain the White House, including using a long-dormant law from 1873.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
text: Allies of former President Donald J. Trump and officials who served in his administration are planning ways to restrict abortion rights if he returns to power that would go far beyond proposals for a national ban or the laws enacted in conservative states across the country.

title: What a Reported Trump Plan on Restricting Abortion Would Mean
description: The idea, a federal ban after 16 weeks, is not very popular — nor would it stop very many abortions.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: A nationwide ban on abortions after 16 weeks of pregnancy — which Donald J. Trump is considering backing, according to a New York Times report — would prevent very few abortions in the United States.

title: A Setback for the Transition to Electric Vehicles
description: Responses to plans to ease the deadline on car emissions. Also: Donald Trump and abortion limits; keeping Aleksei Navalny’s work alive; $399 Trump sneakers.
text: To the Editor:

title: A Politics Reporter Walks Into a Singles Mixer
description: Politics and speed dating: What could go wrong? Astead Herndon, host of “The Run-Up,” talks to Anna Martin about his recent reporting excursion.
authors: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Jen Poyant, Daniel Ramirez, Astead W. Herndon, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Pat McCusker, Diane Wong and Elisheba Ittoop
text: The New York Times political reporter Astead Herndon went speed dating in a swing state to ask daters fun questions like: How early do you tell a prospective date whether you lean red or blue? When do you talk about your stances on issues like abortion or gender equality? It’s hard enough to find someone you click with. Then add election-year tensions into the mix, and things get even more complicated.

title: Abortion Shield Laws: A New War Between the States
description: Doctors in six states where abortion is legal are using new laws to send abortion pills to tens of thousands of women in states where it is illegal.
text: Behind an unmarked door in a boxy brick building outside Boston, a quiet rebellion is taking place. Here, in a 7-by-12-foot room, abortion is being made available to thousands of women in states where it is illegal.

title: A New Abortion Access Strategy
description: Doctors in a handful of blue states are using shield laws to provide abortions to women in red states.
text: Doctors in a handful of blue states have found a way to provide abortions to women in red states where it is banned or restricted. They are doing it with a new tool: laws that protect them from prosecutors elsewhere.

title: Accidents, Lax Rules and Abortion Laws Now Imperil Fertility Industry
description: Fertility clinics are routinely sued by patients for errors that destroy embryos, as happened in Alabama. An effort to define them legally as “unborn children” has raised the stakes.
authors: By Azeen Ghorayshi and Sarah Kliff
text: To the fertility patients whose embryos were destroyed at an Alabama clinic, the circumstances must have been shocking. Somehow, a patient in the hospital housing the clinic had wandered into a storage room, pulled the embryos from a tank of liquid nitrogen, and then dropped them on the floor — probably because the tank was kept at minus 360 degrees.

title: Kamala Harris Pushes Abortion Rights in Michigan, With Gaza Anger as Backdrop
description: During a quiet visit before the state’s primary, the vice president spoke to a small group about a subject that is far more comfortable for Democrats than the Mideast war.
text: Vice President Kamala Harris has emerged as a leading Democratic defender of abortion rights, a potent campaign issue for her party, and on Thursday she brought her message to Michigan before the state’s presidential primary next week — her third trip so far this year to a battleground state to talk about abortion.

title: Alabama I.V.F. Ruling Opens New Front in Election-Year Abortion Battles
description: As some Republicans rushed to distance themselves from a decision that upended popular fertility treatments, Democrats vowed to tie them to it.
authors: By Lisa Lerer, Elizabeth Dias and Annie Karni
text: A ruling by the Alabama Supreme Court that frozen embryos should be considered children has created a new political nightmare for many Republicans, as they try to portray the court’s decision as a fringe view and rush to declare their support for fertility treatments, which have broad support among Americans.

title: Samuel Alito Opened the Door to Reproductive Hell
description: The Alabama Supreme Court’s decision that frozen embryos are children is only part of the problem.
text: Despite the lofty and expansive rhetoric of his majority opinion in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, Justice Samuel Alito insisted throughout the text that the actual decision was more modest than it might appear. The end of Roe, he said, was not the end of abortion access as much as it was the beginning of a new era of democratic deliberation and decision making. No longer shackled by a prior dictate of the Supreme Court, the people were free to choose. “It is time to heed the Constitution and return the issue of abortion to the people’s elected representatives,” Alito wrote.

title: Trump Says He Supports I.V.F. and Calls for Treatment to Remain Legal
description: The Alabama Supreme Court ruling highlighted divisions in the Republican Party between staunch abortion opponents who say life begins at conception and those who want to protect in vitro fertilization treatments.
text: Former President Donald J. Trump on Friday broke his silence on the Alabama Supreme Court’s declaration that frozen embryos are entitled to legal protection, distancing himself from the staunchest abortion opponents in calling on the state’s Legislature to “act quickly” to protect in vitro fertilization treatments, which he said should remain legal in every state.

title: A Conservative Judge’s Critique of the Supreme Court’s Reliance on Tradition
description: In remarks at Harvard, Judge Kevin C. Newsom said the justices had strayed from originalism in parts of their blockbuster opinions on abortion and guns.
text: Judges who are committed to originalism, which seeks to interpret the Constitution based on what it meant when it was adopted, often say they are guided by “text, history and tradition.” The phrase rolls nicely off the tongue.

title: Republican Opposition to Birth Control Bill Could Alienate Voters, Poll Finds
description: A survey conducted by Americans for Contraception shows the overwhelming popularity of birth control, and suggests voters are primed to punish Republicans for opposing a measure to protect access to it.
text: One month after the Supreme Court struck down the right to an abortion, Democrats who then controlled the House pushed through a bill aimed to ensure access to contraception nationwide. All but eight Republicans opposed it.

title: One in Six Abortions Is Done With Pills Prescribed Online, Data Shows
description: The first nationwide count of telehealth abortions includes pills mailed to states with abortion bans by clinicians in states with shield laws.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: A growing share of abortions is now being administered through telemedicine, with clinicians prescribing mail-order abortion pills after online consultations, according to the first nationwide count of telehealth abortions in the U.S. medical system. At least one in six abortions, around 14,000 a month, was conducted via telehealth from July through September, the most recent months with available data.

title: France Moves Closer to Enshrining Abortion Access in Its Constitution
description: The vote by lawmakers comes after supporters of the measure in France were galvanized by the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade.
text: France took a step closer to enshrining access to abortion in its Constitution, after senators backed a bill on Wednesday to include it as a “guaranteed freedom.”

title: The Pro-Life Movement Had a Plan Post-Roe. The G.O.P. Didn’t.
description: The hosts disagree on where America’s abortion debate is headed.
authors: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022, the Republican Party declared victory.

title: The Democrat Showing Biden How It’s Done
description: Gretchen Whitmer knows that abortion could decide the presidential race.
text: At a Detroit union hall in mid-February, Gov. Gretchen Whitmer and Senator Debbie Stabenow of Michigan gathered representatives from local carpenters and construction unions, along with participants in an apprenticeship program, for a round-table event to draw attention to the ways the Biden administration has helped organized labor. At every seat around the U-shaped table, there was a flier from Whitmer’s Fight Like Hell PAC, but it didn’t address jobs; it was about abortion.

title: CVS and Walgreens Will Begin Selling Abortion Pills This Month
description: The pill mifepristone will be available with a prescription at pharmacy counters in a few states to start.
text: The two largest pharmacy chains in the United States will start dispensing the abortion pill mifepristone this month, a step that could make access easier for some patients.

title: Why ‘Fetal Personhood’ Is Roiling the Right
description: An Alabama decision on I.V.F. has put an uncompromising principle on a collision course with political reality.
text: In vitro fertilization creates life, in the most literal sense. The procedure offers a chance to make a baby, with eggs that are fertilized and develop into embryos in a lab. I.V.F. has helped countless people have children, including couples struggling with infertility and an increasing number of L.G.B.T.Q. parents. In a sense, it’s the opposite of an abortion, which ends a pregnancy.

title: French Lawmakers Enshrine Access to Abortion in Constitution
description: Legislators passed an amendment giving women the “guaranteed freedom” to end their pregnancies, which experts called a global first.
text: French legislators on Monday voted to explicitly enshrine access to abortion in the Constitution, making their country the first in the world to do so.

title: Tuesday Briefing: Trump can appear on ballots
description: Also, France protects abortion rights and a U.N. report on sexual assault during the Oct. 7 attack.
text: The U.S. Supreme Court ruled that states may not bar Donald Trump from running for another presidential term, rejecting a challenge to his eligibility that had threatened to upend the race by taking him off ballots around the nation.

title: Trump’s on the Ballot for Super Tuesday, and France Puts Abortion in Its Constitution
description: Plus, what screen time is doing to toddlers.
text: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

title: Reflections on a Trump-Biden Rematch
description: Readers react to articles about the two candidates’ dominance on Super Tuesday. Also: Older bike riders; French abortion amendment; shrinkflation.
text: To the Editor:

title: Six Key Questions Ahead of Biden’s State of the Union
description: What campaign themes will he lay out? How directly will he attack Donald Trump? Will he say the word abortion?
authors: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
text: Follow live updates on Biden’s State of the Union address.

title: The 20 Guests Who Will Sit With Jill Biden at the State of the Union
description: Among the attendees will be the prime minister of Sweden and women who were denied an abortion and in vitro fertilization.
text: Follow live updates on Biden’s State of the Union address.

title: Democrats Invite Reproductive Rights Advocates, Putting Abortion and I.V.F. in the Spotlight
description: Democrats are contrasting their support for reproductive rights with Republicans’ records of opposing protections for abortion and fertility treatments.
text: Among the hundreds of guests who will fill the House chamber on Thursday evening — each invited to telegraph distinct political messages — will be dozens of reproductive rights advocates and providers invited by Democrats who are looking to put access to abortion and fertility treatments front and center this election year.

title: How America’s Two Abortion Realities Are Clashing
description: The legal historian Mary Ziegler takes stock of how conservative and progressive states have diverged since the fall of Roe.
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, it scrambled the landscape of abortion access in America, including in ways that one might not entirely expect. Many conservative states made the procedure essentially illegal — that part was predictable. But there’s also been this striking backlash in blue states, with many of them making historic efforts to expand abortion access, for both their residents and for women living in abortion-restricted states.

title: Biden Aims to Pump Energy Into Campaign After a Fiery National Address
description: The president will follow up his State of the Union speech with a campaign swing to several battleground states, and will begin a $30 million advertising push.
authors: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
text: In his State of the Union address, President Biden laid out a campaign blueprint for the next eight months, assailing Donald J. Trump as a threat to democracy, vowing to protect abortion rights and aiming to reassure voters who are worried that he is too old for the job.

title: Wyoming Banned Abortion. She Opened an Abortion Clinic Anyway.
description: The only abortion clinic left in the state has been protested and set on fire, rebuilt and opened as Wyoming grapples with what it means to be conservative in a post-Roe nation.
text: It was not such an implausible idea, back in 2020, when a philanthropist emailed Julie Burkhart to ask if she would consider opening an abortion clinic in Wyoming, one of the nation’s most conservative states and the one that had twice given Donald Trump his biggest margin of victory.

title: A new generation of abortion voters
description: Plus: Trump flips on a TikTok ban.
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June 2022, it created shock waves that reverberated through American politics, helping Democrats stave off a Republican rout in the midterm elections.

title: New Federal Judiciary Rule Will Limit ‘Forum Shopping’ by Plaintiffs
description: For years, litigants have tried to cherry-pick the judges in sweeping cases on abortion and immigration. Random judge selection is about to make that harder.
text: When anti-abortion activists sued the Food and Drug Administration in 2022 seeking to overturn the approval of the abortion drug mifepristone, they filed their suit in the federal court in Amarillo, Texas, where it was all but assured that the case would be heard by Judge Matthew J. Kacsmaryk, an outspoken opponent of abortion.

title: Trailing Trump in Polls, Biden Can Be More Bullish in One Battleground
description: The president faces lagging energy in many key states. But in Wisconsin, which he will visit on Wednesday, rolling clashes over abortion rights and democracy have kept Democratic voters fired up.
text: Across most of the battleground states, President Biden’s re-election campaign is trailed by worrisome polling, gripes about a slow ramp-up and Democratic calls to show more urgency to the threat posed by former President Donald J. Trump.

title: Kamala Harris Visits Abortion Clinic, in Historic First
description: The vice president met with abortion providers and staff members in St. Paul, Minn., a striking political move that shows how assertive Democrats have grown on the issue.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Nicholas Nehamas
text: Vice President Kamala Harris met with abortion providers and staff members on Thursday in the Twin Cities, a visit that is believed to be the first stop by a president or vice president to an abortion clinic.

title: A Historic Visit to an Abortion Clinic, and What Could Happen to TikTok
description: Plus, why America is suddenly using so much electricity.
text: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

title: At Abortion Clinic Visit, Harris Says U.S. Is Confronting ‘Health Care Crisis’
description: The trip made history and offered a vivid look at how the politics of abortion rights have transformed since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Nicholas Nehamas
text: Vice President Kamala Harris described the flood of laws restricting abortion access as a “health care crisis” as she visited with abortion providers and staff members on Thursday at a clinic in St. Paul, Minn.

title: Kellyanne Conway Has Some Weak Advice for Her Party
description: Voters’ concerns about abortion rights won’t be easy to avoid.
text: It is beyond obvious at this point that abortion is the Achilles’ heel of the Republican Party. The prospect of a national abortion ban almost certainly helped Democrats stave off a red wave in the 2022 midterm elections and assisted them the following year in statewide and state legislative races in Virginia and Kentucky. The prospect of abortion bans has also pushed voters in states such as Ohio and Michigan to approve sweeping affirmations of reproductive freedom in their state Constitutions. And abortion looms over the 2024 race, as well; Democrats will spend countless millions to tell Americans that a vote for Trump, or any Republican on the ballot, is a vote for a national abortion ban.

title: The High Cost of Weight-Loss Drugs
description: Readers discuss the costs and benefits. Also: Donald Trump’s remark about American Jews and Israel; subway shootings; abortion providers; FAFSA chaos.
text: To the Editor:

title: In Arizona, Democrats Could See Opportunity in an 1864 Abortion Ban
description: Democrats are focusing on their support for abortion access, while Republicans pivot away from hard-line positions. But no one knows what restriction will actually be in effect when Arizonans vote this fall.
text: Democrats in Arizona are eager for a fight over abortion access in the state, a political battleground where they’ll need every advantage to support President Biden and hang on to a key Senate seat.

title: Trump Indicates He Would Back a 15-Week Federal Abortion Ban
description: The remarks on a radio show came after he had been privately expressing support for a similar ban, at 16 weeks.
text: Former President Donald J. Trump indicated this week that he was likely to back a 15-week federal ban on abortion, with exceptions for rape, incest and life-threatening emergencies.

title: Challenging Abortion, Again
description: A Supreme Court suit against the F.D.A. could change the national abortion landscape.
text: How safe is it to take abortion pills? The F.D.A., the nation’s authority on drug regulation, says that it’s very safe. But the agency’s judgment is the topic of a sweeping challenge that the Supreme Court will hear tomorrow. The case could curtail Americans’ access to mifepristone, the first pill taken in a two-drug regimen for a medication abortion.

title: Use of Abortion Pills Has Risen Significantly Post Roe, Research Shows
description: Two new studies show fast-growing use of the pills on the eve of the Supreme Court’s consideration of a case seeking to ban or restrict them.
text: On the eve of oral arguments in a Supreme Court case that could affect future access to abortion pills, new research shows the fast-growing use of medication abortion nationally and the many ways women have obtained access to the method since Roe v. Wade was overturned in June 2022.

title: The Supreme Court Got It Wrong: Abortion Is Not Settled Law
description: Two cases offer the Supreme Court an opportunity to shape the landscape of abortion access in the post-Roe era.
authors: By Melissa Murray and Kate Shaw
text: In his majority opinion in the case overturning Roe v. Wade, Justice Samuel Alito insisted that the high court was finally settling the vexed abortion debate by returning the “authority to regulate abortion” to the “people and their elected representatives.”

title: Erin Hawley: The Woman Arguing Against the Abortion Pill
description: Erin Hawley, a law professor and wife of Senator Josh Hawley, is arguing the Supreme Court case.
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Abbie VanSickle
text: It was 2014, and Erin Morrow Hawley was fighting against the egg-laying hens of Missouri. Specifically, a new requirement that chicken cages have enough space for the hens to stand up, turn around and stretch out.

title: Abortion Pill Dispute Centers on Central Question: Who Can Sue?
description: The parties in the fight over access to the abortion pill sharply disagree on whether anti-abortion doctors and groups can show they will suffer harm.
authors: By Abbie VanSickle and Pam Belluck
text: The future of access to abortion pills may turn on a basic legal question: Who has a right to bring a lawsuit?

title: Supreme Court Seems Inclined to Reject Bid to Curtail Abortion Pill Access
description: A majority of the justices questioned whether a group of anti-abortion doctors and organizations trying to sharply limit availability of the medication could show they suffered harm.
text: A majority of the Supreme Court appeared deeply skeptical on Tuesday of efforts to severely curtail access to a widely used abortion pill, questioning whether a group of anti-abortion doctors and organizations had a right to challenge the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the medication.

title: Abortion Is Back in Front of the Supreme Court, and a Baltimore Bridge Collapses
description: Plus, a revolt at NBC.
authors: By Tracy Mumford, Pam Belluck, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
text: On Today’s Episode:

title: What Is Mifepristone and How Is It Used?
description: More than half of people who get legal abortions in the United States — and three-quarters in Europe — use medication abortion.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: Mifepristone is one of two drugs used in a medication abortion. It is combined with a second drug, misoprostol, to end a pregnancy.

title: How Common Is Medication Abortion?
description: It’s now the most used abortion method.
authors: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Claire Cain Miller
text: Medication abortions involving the drug mifepristone now represent the majority of abortions in America.

title: Here’s What Is at Stake in the Supreme Court’s Abortion Pill Case
description: Changes the F.D.A. made in 2016 and 2021 significantly broadened access to mifepristone.
authors: By Pam Belluck and Abbie VanSickle
text: The main dispute before the Supreme Court centers on whether changes the F.D.A. made in 2016 and 2021, which significantly broadened access to mifepristone, should remain in effect.

title: What is the Comstock Act?
description: The law prevents the mailing of drugs used for abortions.
text: When a Trump-appointed judge, Matthew J. Kacsmaryk, overrode the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the abortion pill mifepristone last year, he relied in part on a statute from a 19th-century law.

title: Demonstrators Make Themselves Heard on Abortion Pill Case
description: Thirteen abortion-rights protesters were arrested near the Supreme Court as part of a civil disobedience action. Abortion opponents were less numerous but still vocal.
text: Bearing colorful signs and banners that read “Doctors Not Doctrine” and “Abortion is Health Care,” hundreds of activists chanted, marched and rallied for hours outside the Supreme Court starting Tuesday morning, before the justices weighed the availability of a commonly used abortion pill.

title: 4 Takeaways From the Abortion Pill Arguments
description: Several justices questioned the remedy of applying nationwide restrictions to mifepristone because it would be the first time a court had second-guessed the F.D.A.’s expert judgment on a drug.
text: A majority of the Supreme Court seemed inclined on Tuesday to reject a bid to sharply limit access to abortion pills.

title: A Baltimore Bridge Collapsed After a Ship Collision
description: Also, the Supreme Court seemed skeptical of an effort to curtail abortion pill access. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
text: A 948-foot cargo ship that left the Port of Baltimore early this morning collided just minutes later with a pillar of a major bridge, quickly causing much of the bridge to collapse into the water. Divers and other emergency responders searched for six construction workers who had been fixing potholes on the Francis Scott Key Bridge when it fell and are now missing. Two other workers were rescued from the water.

title: Key Takeaways From Supreme Court Arguments on Abortion Pill Access
description: A majority of the Supreme Court seemed inclined on Tuesday to reject a bid to sharply limit access to abortion pills.
authors: By Abbie VanSickle, Rebecca Suner and Claire Hogan
text: A majority of the Supreme Court seemed inclined on Tuesday to reject a bid to sharply limit access to abortion pills.

title: Democrat Running on Abortion and I.V.F. Access Wins Special Election in Alabama
description: Marilyn Lands flipped a State House seat in the deep-red state by 25 percentage points, underscoring the continued political potency of reproductive rights.
text: Marilyn Lands, a Democrat, won a special election Tuesday for a State House seat in Alabama after campaigning on access to abortion and in vitro fertilization, underscoring the continued political potency of reproductive rights.

title: ‘A Chance to Live’: How 2 Families Faced a Catastrophic Birth Defect
description: Cases of trisomy 18 may rise as many states restrict abortion. But some women choose to have the babies, love them tenderly and care for them devotedly.
authors: By Gina Kolata and Kim Raff
text: Ashlee Wiseman, a waitress at a Sizzler in Idaho Falls, Idaho, was 10 weeks pregnant when a nurse phoned with crushing news: a test of fetal DNA in her blood had found that her baby girl had trisomy 18, a catastrophic genetic abnormality, and was unlikely to survive.

title: The Persistent Threat to Abortion Rights
description: A lawsuit that restricts a widely used abortion drug is unlikely to be the last challenge to Americans’ reproductive freedom.
text: The Supreme Court this week heard the first major challenge to abortion rights since it struck down Roe v. Wade two years ago — an attempt to severely limit access to mifepristone, the most commonly used abortion pill in the country, by a group of doctors who are morally opposed to the practice.

title: Woman Who Was Charged With Murder After Abortion Sues Texas Prosecutor
description: Lizelle Gonzalez was arrested after using an abortion pill in 2022, and her charge was since dropped. Now she is seeking $1 million in damages.
text: A woman in Texas who was falsely charged with murder over a self-induced abortion in 2022 has filed a lawsuit against the local prosecutor’s office and its leaders, seeking more than $1 million in damages.

title: Read the Florida Supreme Court’s Ruling on the Constitutional Amendment
description: The Florida Supreme Court allowed voters to decide this fall whether to expand abortion access, ruling 4 to 3 that a proposed constitutional amendment that would guarantee the right to abortion “before viability,” usually around 24 weeks, could go...
text: The Florida Supreme Court allowed voters to decide this fall whether to expand abortion access, ruling 4 to 3 that a proposed constitutional amendment that would guarantee the right to abortion “before viability,” usually around 24 weeks, could go on the November ballot.

title: Florida Court Allows 6-Week Abortion Ban, but Voters Will Get to Weigh In
description: The Florida Supreme Court found that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion. But it also allowed a ballot question on whether to expand abortion access.
text: The Florida Supreme Court overturned decades of legal precedent on Monday in ruling that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion, effectively allowing Florida to ban the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy.

title: Read the Florida Supreme Court’s Ruling on the Abortion Ban
description: The Florida Supreme Court overturned decades of legal precedent in ruling that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion, effectively allowing Florida to ban the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy.
text: The Florida Supreme Court overturned decades of legal precedent in ruling that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion, effectively allowing Florida to ban the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy.

title: Florida’s Top Court Allowed a Six-Week Abortion Ban
description: Also, an Israeli strike killed top Iranian commanders, Iran said. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
text: The Florida Supreme Court ruled today that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion. The move overturns decades of precedent and clears the way for a ban on abortions in the state after six weeks of pregnancy to take effect within 30 days.

title: I Hope to Repeal an Arcane Law That Could Be Misused to Ban Abortion Nationwide
description: The Comstock Act is a major concern if Donald Trump is re-elected.
text: A long discredited, arcane 150-year-old law is back in the news in 2024, and that should terrify anyone who supports reproductive freedom. Last week at the Supreme Court, the Comstock Act of 1873 was referenced on three separate occasions during oral arguments in a case dealing with access to mifepristone, one of two drugs typically used in medication abortions.

title: With Abortion Ballot Question, a ‘Path to Relevance’ for Democrats in Florida?
description: Rulings allowing a strict abortion ban, along with a ballot question on expanding abortion access, may inject new life into Democratic campaigns in the state.
text: Suddenly, November got a lot more interesting in Florida.

title: Trump to Focus on Border as Democrats Eye Boost From Florida Abortion Ruling
description: Democrats, bolstered by a pair of court rulings out of Florida on Monday, have fresh optimism about their ability to center the campaign on abortion.
authors: By Chris Cameron and Maggie Astor
text: Former President Donald J. Trump will campaign on immigration and border policy today with events planned in Michigan and Wisconsin, two crucial battleground states in the Midwest.

title: Biden Assails ‘Outrageous’ Florida Abortion Ruling as His Campaign Blames Trump
description: The president’s campaign moved to pin responsibility squarely on Donald Trump after the Florida Supreme Court cleared the way for a six-week ban.
text: President Biden on Tuesday called a decision by the Florida Supreme Court to uphold a restrictive abortion law “outrageous” and “extreme,” saying that it had effectively eliminated access to the procedure across the American South.

title: With Abortion on the Ballot, Trump Says He’ll Address the Issue ‘Next Week’
description: Two rulings on abortion by the Florida Supreme Court shook up the race in Donald Trump’s home state and present a potential new vulnerability for his campaign.
text: Donald J. Trump, appearing in two crucial swing states on Tuesday, avoided discussing abortion but teased that he would address the issue “next week,” once again demurring on taking a clear position on the issue after two Florida Supreme Court rulings shook up the 2024 campaign in the former president’s home state.

title: Abortion and the Florida Fakeout
description: Will the state sit the presidential election out, like a retiree watching pickleball?
text: It seemed, for a while there, that 2024 was going to be The Presidential Election Year Without Much Florida.

title: Florida Court Rulings Pose Risks for House Republicans on Abortion
description: The twin decisions have all but guaranteed that voters will have the issue on their minds in November, bringing potential risks for two anti-abortion Republicans in the state whose districts aren’t solidly red.
text: Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a hard-right Republican from Florida, has proudly described herself as a “pro-life extremist.”

title: Trump Says Abortion Restrictions Should Be Left to the States
description: After months of mixed signals, Donald Trump said that whatever states decide “must be the law of the land,” adding that he was “strongly in favor of exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.”
authors: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Michael Gold
text: Former President Donald J. Trump said in a video statement on Monday that abortion rights should be left up to the states, remarks that came after months of mixed signals on an issue that he and his advisers have worried could cost him dearly in the election.

title: Leading Anti-Abortion Group Says It Is ‘Deeply Disappointed’ in Trump’s Comments
description: The president of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America said she was “deeply disappointed” in Donald J. Trump’s position that states should decide abortion rights.
text: After former President Donald J. Trump announced his position that abortion rights should be decided by individual states, the leading anti-abortion group supporting Republican candidates said his stance fell short.

title: How Abortion, and I.V.F., Flipped an Alabama State House Seat
description: Marilyn Lands’s victory in a special election provided an early blueprint for Democrats who are eager to make reproductive rights central to their campaigns.
authors: By Maya King and Micah Green
text: When Marilyn Lands, a Democrat, won an election last month for a northern Alabama State House district that Republicans had held for more than two decades, she stretched the political power of reproductive rights into the edges of Appalachia.

title: Four Takeaways From the Vatican’s Document on Human Dignity
description: The document restated the Roman Catholic Church’s rejection of abortion, gender fluidity and transition surgery.
authors: By Jason Horowitz and Elisabetta Povoledo
text: The document issued on Monday by the Vatican puts human dignity at the center of Catholic life, but in doing so, it broaches some of the most difficult and sensitive social issues, those that Pope Francis has spent his papacy avoiding.

title: Biden and Other Democrats Tie Trump to Limits on Abortion Rights
description: The former president said he supported leaving abortion decisions to states, but political opponents say he bears responsibility for any curbs enacted.
text: Democrats, seeking to tie abortion restrictions to former President Donald J. Trump and Republicans, again laid the blame for limits on reproductive rights at Mr. Trump’s feet, saying the former president’s statement on Monday calling for abortion restrictions to be decided by states was part of a pattern of “extreme” lawmaking.

title: Pence Attacks Trump’s Abortion Statement as a ‘Slap in the Face’
description: Mike Pence, an evangelical Christian who embraced abortion restrictions at the federal level shortly after Roe was overturned, called Mr. Trump’s statement a “retreat” on the matter.
text: Former Vice President Mike Pence delivered a scathing rebuke to former President Donald J. Trump’s announcement on Monday that he thought abortion rights should be left to the states, calling Mr. Trump’s video statement a “slap in the face” to the anti-abortion voters who supported him in 2016 and 2020.

title: Putting Abortion Question to Florida Voters Is Unlikely to End Court Fights
description: Though the Florida Supreme Court allowed a ballot question on expanding abortion rights, it also laid out a way for anti-abortion groups to challenge such an expansion.
text: Abortion-rights supporters celebrated last week when the Florida Supreme Court said voters could decide this fall whether to approve a state constitutional amendment protecting and expanding abortion rights in Florida. But the court also laid out a road map for anti-abortion groups to challenge any expansion, by raising the prospect of “fetal personhood.”

title: Biden Campaign Ad Blames Trump for Near-Death of Woman Who Was Denied Abortion
description: The ad encapsulates the strategy by the president’s campaign to seize on anger about the Supreme Court’s 2022 decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers
text: President Biden’s re-election campaign on Monday released a searing campaign ad blaming former President Donald J. Trump for the near-death of a Texas woman who suffered infections after she was denied an abortion following a miscarriage.

title: The Eclipse Brought Darkness and Fascination
description: Also, Donald Trump said abortion limits should be decided by states. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
text: In an awe-inspiring cosmic coincidence, the moon and sun perfectly aligned this afternoon, producing a total solar eclipse visible across North America. The moon’s shadow plunged daylight into darkness, carving a path from Mexico, up to Maine and into Canada. We took lots of photos.

title: Trump Says Abortion Will Be Left to the States. Don’t Believe Him.
description: His allies are planning to resurrect and enforce the 19th-century Comstock Act.
text: When Donald Trump was asked about the recent Florida Supreme Court decision upholding his adopted state’s abortion ban, he promised that he would announce where he stands this week — a sign of how tricky the politics of reproductive rights have become for the man who did more than any other to roll them back. Sure enough, on Monday he unveiled his latest position in a video statement that attempted to thread the needle between his anti-abortion base and the majority of Americans who want abortion to be legal.

title: On Abortion, Trump Chose Politics Over Principles. Will It Matter?
description: With his video statement on Monday, Donald Trump laid bare how faulty a messenger he had always been for the anti-abortion cause.
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
text: When Donald J. Trump ran for president in 2016, the leaders of the anti-abortion movement extracted a series of promises from him in exchange for backing his nomination.

title: The Man Who Snuffed Out Abortion Rights Is Here to Tell You He Is a Moderate
description: He landed a major blow against legal abortion during his first term. If given a second, he will land another.
text: Donald Trump does not speak from conviction. He does not speak from belief or at least any belief other than self-obsession. He certainly does not speak from anything we might recognize as reason; when he’s holding forth at a microphone, even the most careful students of Trump the rhetorician will struggle to find the light of complex thought.

title: Trump’s Calculus on Abortion, and Iran’s Secret Smuggling Network
description: Plus, the fight against “deepnudes.”
authors: By Tracy Mumford, Ben Protess, Natasha Singer, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
text: On Today’s Episode:

title: A day after Trump’s abortion statement, Arizona awaits a key ruling.
text: A day after former President Donald J. Trump dominated headlines with a statement declaring that abortion policies should be left to the states, the issue will continue to be at the forefront of the nation’s political conversation.

title: Swing-State Republicans Embrace Trump’s New Abortion Stance
description: Several of the party’s candidates, particularly those in battleground states, said they favored letting states regulate the procedure instead of having a national ban.
text: Multiple Republican candidates in swing-state races aligned themselves with former President Donald J. Trump after he said abortion access should be left up to the states, avoiding mention of a national ban and laying bare the party’s rift over the issue.

title: Arizona Reinstates 160-Year-Old Abortion Ban
description: The state’s highest court said the law, moribund for decades under Roe v. Wade, was now enforceable, but it put its decision on hold for a lower court to hear other challenges to the law.
authors: By Jack Healy and Kellen Browning
text: Arizona’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, a decision that could have far-reaching consequences for women’s health care and election-year politics in a critical battleground state.

title: Trump’s New Stance on Abortion
description: Readers discuss his statement that abortion policy should be left to the states. Also: J Street; student “brands”; GPS satellites; alternatives to social media.
text: To the Editor:

title: Abortion Jumps to the Center of Arizona’s Key 2024 Races
description: Democrats quickly aimed to capitalize on a ruling by the state’s highest court upholding an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.
authors: By Lisa Lerer, Nicholas Nehamas and Reid J. Epstein
text: Democrats seized on a ruling on Tuesday by Arizona’s highest court upholding an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, setting up a fierce political fight over the issue that is likely to dominate the presidential election and a pivotal Senate race in a crucial battleground state.

title: Read the Arizona Supreme Court’s Abortion Ruling
description: The state’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.
text: The state’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.

title: Biden Condemns Arizona’s Abortion Ban as ‘Cruel’ and ‘Extreme’
description: President Biden, who promised to continue to fight for the restoration of Roe v. Wade, said the ban was first enacted “well before women had secured the right to vote.”
text: President Biden condemned a decision by Arizona’s Supreme Court on Tuesday to uphold an 1864 ban on nearly all abortions as “cruel” and “extreme,” saying the law was first enacted well before women even had the right to vote.

title: Arizona Reinstated a 160-Year-Old Abortion Ban
description: Also, Iran is smuggling weapons into the West Bank. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
text: Arizona’s highest court today ruled that an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions “is now enforceable.” With the federal right to abortion now overturned, the justices explained, there was nothing stopping the state from reinstating its long-dormant prohibition.

title: What We Know About the Arizona Abortion Ban
description: The state’s highest court upheld enforcement of an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions. Here’s what to know about the ruling.
text: Arizona’s highest court upheld enforcement of an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, a decision that could have far-reaching consequences for women’s health care and election-year politics in a critical battleground state. But the law is not immediately in effect.

title: Arizona Ruling Spurs Strong Reactions, but Election Impact Is Unclear
description: Some in the battleground state said they would still vote for former President Donald J. Trump even if they were frustrated by the reversal of abortion rights.
authors: By Jack Healy and Rowan Moore Gerety
text: Pam Raphael pulled up to the Arizona State Capitol on Tuesday afternoon bearing ice-cold treats and red-hot anger. She had come to deliver an order of her frozen prickly pear and lime pops but was preoccupied by a just-released decision by Arizona’s highest court that upheld an 1864 law banning nearly all abortions.

title: This Is Probably Not the Deal the Pro-Life Movement Bargained for With Trump
description: Abortion opponents are entirely misaligned with the Trumpist form of conservatism.
text: The captivity of the pro-life movement to the character of Donald Trump is a crucial aspect of contemporary abortion politics. But maybe not quite in the way suggested by Trump’s decision this week to publicly distance himself from his pro-life supporters by refusing to endorse national restrictions on late-term abortions.

title: Arizona’s 1864 Abortion Law, and New Boeing Allegations
description: Plus, the fight against “forever chemicals.”
authors: By Tracy Mumford, Jonathan Swan, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
text: On Today’s Episode:

title: Trump’s Abortion Dilemma
description: After months of mixed signals, the former president said abortion rights should be left to the states.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lisa Lerer, Rob Szypko, Luke Vander Ploeg, Shannon M. Lin, Summer Thomad, Lexie Diao, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
text: By the time his first term was over, Donald J. Trump had cemented his place as the most anti-abortion president in U.S. history. Now, facing political blowback, he’s trying to change that reputation.

title: Abortion Politics in 2024
description: Four key points to help you make sense of the current debate.
text: No American president has done as much to restrict abortion as Donald Trump. When he was running in 2016, he promised to appoint Supreme Court justices who would overturn Roe v. Wade, and his three nominees helped do precisely that in the 2022 Dobbs decision. Twenty-one states have since enacted tight restrictions. Yesterday, Arizona’s highest court reinstated an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.

title: Kari Lake Called Arizona’s Abortion Ban a ‘Great Law,’ but Now She Denounces It
description: In her 2022 race for governor, Ms. Lake delivered a strict anti-abortion message. Now running for Senate, she is retreating from that position.
text: Kari Lake, the leading Republican candidate for Senate in Arizona, was quick to denounce the state Supreme Court’s ruling upholding an 1864 law banning nearly all abortions in the state. The law is “out of step with Arizonans,” she said in a statement. She called on state lawmakers to “come up” with a “solution that Arizonans can support.”

title: The History Behind Arizona’s 160-Year-Old Abortion Ban
description: The state’s Supreme Court ruled that the 1864 law is enforceable today. Here is what led to its enactment.
text: The 160-year-old Arizona abortion ban that was upheld on Tuesday by the state’s highest court was among a wave of anti-abortion laws propelled by some historical twists and turns that might seem surprising.

title: Fixing the Quality Problems at Boeing
description: Readers discuss Boeing’s woes. Also: Arizona’s abortion ban; student loans; “nice” countries; “pro-humanity” protesters; caring about fish.
text: To the Editor:

title: Trump Criticizes Arizona Abortion Ban
description: During a campaign stop in Atlanta, former President Donald J. Trump said that the Arizona abortion ruling went too far, adding that it will be “straightened out.”
text: During a campaign stop in Atlanta, former President Donald J. Trump said that the Arizona abortion ruling went too far, adding that it will be “straightened out.”

title: Trump Says He Wouldn’t Sign a Federal Abortion Ban, Criticizing Arizona Ruling
