description: Days after he said that abortion policies should be left to the states, former President Donald J. Trump criticized an Arizona court ruling that upheld an 1864 law.
text: Days after saying that abortion policies should be left to the states, former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday criticized an Arizona court ruling for upholding an 1864 law that banned nearly all abortions and said he would not sign a national abortion ban if he were elected president.

title: Arizona Republicans Thwart Attempts to Repeal 1864 Abortion Ban
description: Democrats in both houses of the Legislature were blocked from advancing bills to roll back the reinstated ban on nearly all abortions in the state.
authors: By Jack Healy and Kate Zernike
text: A decision by Arizona’s highest court upholding an 1864 ban on nearly all abortions created chaos and confusion across the state on Wednesday. As abortion providers were flooded with phone calls from frantic patients, Republican lawmakers at the State Capitol blocked efforts to undo the ban, prompting angry jeers from Democrats.

title: In Arizona’s Crucial Senate Race, a Liberal Fighter Courts the Center
description: Ruben Gallego has long embraced his progressive background. Now, with his state newly in the spotlight over abortion politics, he’s getting tough on the border and targeting swing voters.
text: As Representative Ruben Gallego campaigned for Arizona’s vital Senate seat last week, he did something that might seem unusual to those who know him as a fierce liberal combatant: He struck a moderate tone.

title: Two Imperfect Messengers Take On Abortion
description: Neither side of the abortion divide would probably design the exact candidate they have in 2024.
text: In the summer of 2019, as a crowded Democratic primary was picking up speed, Joe Biden was on the defensive, pummeled by abortion-rights groups and his opponents for his support of the Hyde Amendment, a measure that prohibits the use of federal funds for most abortions.

title: How the G.O.P. Molded the Arizona Court That Upheld the Abortion Ban
description: Arizona’s former governor, Doug Ducey, expanded the court to seven justices. All solid conservatives, they upheld a 160-year-old abortion ban that presents a political risk to Republicans.
authors: By David W. Chen and Michael Wines
text: When a split Arizona Supreme Court upheld a Civil War-era abortion ban this week, it rejected the argument that the 160-year-old statute had been overtaken by decades of newer laws regulating the procedure, including a recent law banning abortion after the 15th week of pregnancy.

title: Comedians Rage Against Arizona’s Abortion Ruling
description: “That is crazy — but remember it’s Arizona, so it’s a dry crazy,” Stephen Colbert said of the state’s 160-year-old ban on abortion, newly reinstated.
text: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Democrats Hammer a Simple Attack on Abortion: Donald Trump Did This
description: The party is unifying around a blunt message that Vice President Kamala Harris pushed for privately ahead of her Friday trip to Arizona, where Democrats hope to keep Republicans reeling.
authors: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
text: In a meeting with her staff last week, Vice President Kamala Harris offered a prediction: Former President Donald J. Trump would not support a national abortion ban. Instead, she said, he would take a position that would muddy the waters on an issue that she believed could be deeply damaging for his campaign.

title: The Great Hypocrisy of the Pro-Life Movement
description: There is no longer a truly pro-life party in the United States.
text: To understand the remarkable moral, political and intellectual collapse of the pro-life movement, look to the Alabama Supreme Court, not just to Donald Trump’s recent pledge not to sign a national abortion ban or Kari Lake’s flip-flop on Arizona’s reinstated 1864 anti-abortion law.

title: Kari Lake Backs G.O.P. Effort to Drop 1864 Abortion Law in Favor of 15-Week Ban
description: The Senate candidate and Donald Trump ally is supporting a handful of state Republicans who have backed away from a near-total ban that was upheld by the State Supreme Court this week.
authors: By Kellen Browning and Jack Healy
text: A handful of Arizona Republican legislators looking to overturn a 160-year-old state law that bans nearly all abortions have a new high-profile supporter: Kari Lake, a prominent Senate candidate and a close ally of Donald J. Trump.

title: Abortion Is Dividing the ‘Religious’ From the ‘Right’
description: Does God have to be Republican?
authors: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
text: This week, the “Matter of Opinion” hosts debate how religious voters will react to Donald Trump’s betrayal of anti-abortion positions, the evolution of Christianity as the domain of the right and whether religion is actually as powerful as it seems in modern U.S. politics.

title: Kamala Harris, Traveling to Arizona, Will Slam Trump Over Abortion
description: The vice president is set to lean into a partywide attack on Donald Trump and fellow Republicans, who are newly on the defensive over the issue.
authors: By Nicholas Nehamas, Lisa Lerer and Reid J. Epstein
text: Vice President Kamala Harris will travel to Arizona on Friday to assail former President Donald J. Trump over abortion restrictions, with plans to blame him for bans in the state and across the country.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week
description: The late-night hosts started the week by talking about the total solar eclipse before moving on to political news — including former President Trump’s failed bids to delay his criminal hush-money trial and Arizona reinstating a 160-year-old aborti...
text: The late-night hosts started the week by talking about the total solar eclipse before moving on to political news — including former President Trump’s failed bids to delay his criminal hush-money trial and Arizona reinstating a 160-year-old abortion ban.

title: Republican Women Are Divided on Abortion as Bans Spread
description: Across the country, fractures are emerging among conservative and centrist women, as they confront a steady drumbeat of new abortion restrictions and court rulings.
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer
text: Rebecca Gau, a self-described “reasonable Republican” in Mesa, Ariz., is conflicted about many things that her party promotes. But she knows exactly what she thinks about Arizona’s new — or rather, very old — Civil War-era abortion ban. And about the idea that Republicans like her might be happy with the outcome.

title: Harris Blasts Trump on Abortion in Arizona
description: During a campaign rally, Vice President Kamala Harris blamed former President Donald J. Trump for the Arizona Supreme Court’s ruling to uphold a near-total ban on abortion.
text: During a campaign rally, Vice President Kamala Harris blamed former President Donald J. Trump for the Arizona Supreme Court’s ruling to uphold a near-total ban on abortion.

title: Harris Blasts Trump on Abortion at Arizona Campaign Stop
description: At a rally in Tucson, Ariz., days after the state’s top court upheld a near-total ban on abortion, Vice President Kamala Harris placed the blame directly on former President Donald J. Trump.
text: Vice President Kamala Harris laid into former President Donald J. Trump over abortion rights at a campaign rally in Arizona on Friday, accusing him of being directly responsible for a court decision this week that upheld the state’s 160-year-old near-total ban on abortion.

title: You Ask, We Answer: How The Times/Siena Poll Is Conducted
description: The New York Times/Siena College Poll has earned a reputation for accuracy and transparency. But as with any poll, there are limits to just how much you can derive.
text: Polls can give us important insight into how people’s views on the issues, the state of the country and the candidates may affect how they vote. Polls have helped us understand how motivating issues like abortion and immigration are for Americans, how the war in Gaza is perceived by Democrats and Republicans, and how many voters believe misinformation.

title: Why Can’t Biden Triangulate Like Trump?
description: There’s a difference between being aware of your base and being its prisoner.
text: For anyone with sincere and absolute convictions on abortion, pro-life or pro-choice, Donald Trump’s attempts to reposition himself this week should be somewhere between depressing and infuriating.

title: How Women at One Arizona Clinic Are Grappling With the Abortion Ruling
description: Inside Acacia Women’s Center, patients described a mix of fear, anger and anxiety after the State Supreme Court’s decision to reinstate a law that bans nearly all abortions.
authors: By Jack Healy and Caitlin O'Hara
text: Leah found out she was five weeks pregnant on the same day that the Arizona Supreme Court upheld an 1864 law banning nearly all abortions in the state.

title: Expert Panel Calls on Germany to Legalize Abortion in First 12 Weeks
description: For decades, Germany allowed early abortions even while keeping them illegal. A government-appointed commission says the system is “untenable.”
text: A government-appointed commission in Germany recommended on Monday that lawmakers legalize abortion during the first trimester of pregnancy, a move that could push the country into a long-avoided debate on an issue that for decades remained in a legal gray zone.

title: Under Pressure From Trump, Arizona Republicans Weigh Response to 1864 Abortion Ban
description: Liberal activists are proposing a ballot measure that would enshrine the right to an abortion in the state Constitution. Republicans in the State Legislature are considering plans to undermine it.
text: Facing mounting pressure to strike down a near-total abortion ban revived last week by Arizona’s Supreme Court, Republican state legislators are considering efforts to undermine a planned ballot measure this fall that would enshrine abortion rights in the Arizona Constitution, according to a presentation obtained by The New York Times.

title: The Smothering of Abortion Rights Reveals Something Else About Republicans
description: The federal courts and the Arizona Supreme Court have conjured a past that rejects the right to bodily autonomy.
text: Last Monday, Donald Trump said that abortion rights were best left to the states. “The states,” he said, “will determine by vote or legislation or perhaps both, and whatever they decide must be the law of the land. In this case, the law of the state.”

title: Weekly Student News Quiz: Israel, Abortion Law, Trial of the Century
description: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
authors: Compiled by Jeremy Engle and Michael Gonchar
text: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

title: California Man Gets 9 Years in Firebombing of Planned Parenthood Clinic
description: The clinic, which provided abortion, birth control and other health services in Costa Mesa, Calif., was the target of a “brazen attack” in 2022, a prosecutor said.
text: A California man who used a Molotov cocktail to firebomb a clinic providing abortion services was sentenced to nine years in prison on Monday in the 2022 attack on the facility, which is operated by the Planned Parenthood Federation of America in Costa Mesa, Calif., federal authorities said.

title: Arizona Republicans Splinter Over Repeal of 1864 Abortion Ban
description: The State Senate introduced a bill to repeal a near-total abortion ban dating back to the Civil War, while the House blocked an effort to do so.
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Kellen Browning
text: The two chambers of Arizona’s State Legislature diverged sharply on Wednesday over whether to repeal the state’s 1864 law banning abortion, capping a chaotic day as legislators and activists sparred over the fate of the Civil War-era ban.

title: Women Talk Through Their Abortions on TikTok
description: At a time of heightened confusion and legal battles over access to abortion, women are looking to social media for answers.
text: “Have an abortion with me,” a single mother from Brooklyn named Sunni says as she twirls around her kitchen to light jazzy piano, before walking TikTok viewers through the steps she took to end her pregnancy at home.

title: Abortion Is Remaking Our Political Landscape. Why Aren’t Guns?
description: Is it possible for us to get to the same place on gun safety that we’re getting to on abortion — where the people who make the policy feel pressure to be sensible?
text: Why don’t we talk more about guns?

title: The Kamala Harris Moment Has Arrived
description: With the issue of abortion rights, the vice president has hit her stride.
text: One of Kamala Harris’s most memorable moments during the 2020 presidential election cycle was when, during a Democratic primary debate, she sharply criticized Joe Biden for working with segregationists in the Senate in their shared opposition to busing.

title: After Decades on the Court, I Want a Divided America to Know This
description: A former Supreme Court justice on how to disagree.
authors: By Stephen Breyer and Derek Arthur
text: Justice Stephen Breyer spent 28 years on the Supreme Court. During that time, he witnessed fiery disagreements among his peers over abortion, voting rights and marriage equality. What he never saw, though, was his colleagues hurling personal attacks over their differences in points of view. That’s a lesson, he says in this audio essay, that our politically divided nation should learn as well.

title: Ken Loach: Championing the Strugglers and Stragglers
description: A retrospective of the director’s work at Film Forum shows how his movies have kept a focus on working-class solidarity.
text: From the start, the British filmmaker Ken Loach came out swinging in support of the underdog. Long before his films opened in theaters, his 1960s television plays introduced uncomfortable topics like back-street abortion (“Up the Junction”) and homelessness (“Cathy Come Home”) to audiences who were not always appreciative of their documentarylike realness and divisive politics.

title: Beverly LaHaye, Soldier of the Christian Right, Dies at 94
description: A pastor’s wife, she formed Concerned Women for America to oppose the Equal Rights Amendment. Ronald Reagan called her “one of the powerhouses on the political scene.”
text: Beverly LaHaye, a pastor’s wife whose recoil from 1970s feminism led her to build an organization advancing conservative views of the family, Concerned Women for America, which became a pillar of the Christian right, waging battles against abortion, gay rights and the Equal Rights Amendment, died on Sunday in hospice in El Cajon, Calif., near San Diego. She was 94.

title: Bucking Trump, Anti-Abortion Movement Shows Deep Roots in Arizona
description: Even as abortion rights ballot issues have had some striking successes, anti-abortion forces have stood firm in state legislatures like Arizona’s where they have deep convictions and positions of power.
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Jack Healy
text: Speaker Ben Toma walked off the floor of the Arizona House of Representatives, resolute — if stressed — after he cast the pivotal vote to again block an effort to repeal the state’s 1864 abortion ban.

title: When Pregnant Patients ‘Become Radioactive to Emergency Departments’
description: Exceptions to abortion bans aren’t worth the paper they’re printed on.
text: I thought I would follow up my Tuesday column on abortion rights with this report from The Associated Press, on the state of emergency services for pregnant women.

title: Kristi Noem Refuses to Say Whether She Would Have Certified the Election on Jan. 6
description: The South Dakota governor and potential vice-presidential pick for former President Donald J. Trump also dodged questions about abortion.
text: Gov. Kristi Noem of South Dakota, a potential vice-presidential pick for former President Donald J. Trump, refused to say on Sunday whether she would have certified the 2020 election if she had been in Vice President Mike Pence’s position. She also dodged questions about whether she supported exceptions to abortion bans for rape and incest.

title: Coming to Alabama: Newsom’s Abortion-Access Ad, Depicting an Arrest
description: The ad portrays a woman trying to leave the state to have an abortion. The Campaign for Democracy, a political action committee started by Mr. Newsom, the California governor, created it.
text: A woman nervously peers into her rearview mirror as a patrolman activates his car’s lights and sirens. She is less than a mile from leaving Alabama to seek abortion services, but it’s too late: The next thing she knows, she is being handed a pregnancy test and is handcuffed.

title: As College Students Protest, Harris Keeps Her Focus on Abortion
description: “When we think about what is at stake, it is absolutely about freedom,” Vice President Kamala Harris said during a visit to Wisconsin.
text: Vice President Kamala Harris, campaigning on Monday in Wisconsin, again took sharp swipes at former President Donald J. Trump for his actions on abortion, a hot topic across the country. But she stayed silent on the war in Gaza, another issue erupting elsewhere among the critical bloc of young voters she has been courting.

title: Abortion Data Wars: States and Cities Debate How Much Information to Collect
description: Some states with Republican-controlled legislatures want more data, while some controlled by Democrats want less, fearing it could be used to target patients or providers.
authors: By Pam Belluck and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
text: In the fierce debate over abortion in the United States, the subject of data collection might seem wonky and tangential. But the information that state and city governments collect about abortion patients is becoming another flashpoint in the country’s bitter divide over the issue.

title: Biden Campaigns on Abortion Rights in Florida, Tying State Ban to Trump
description: The Biden campaign has made abortion one of its top issues, as polling shows it is one of the few subjects in which voters place more trust in President Biden than Donald Trump.
authors: By Nicholas Nehamas and Patricia Mazzei
text: President Biden on Tuesday strongly condemned a six-week abortion ban that will soon take effect in Florida, saying it would force women to endure “unbearable pain and cruelty” and blaming former President Donald J. Trump for their suffering.

title: Planned Parenthood Plans $10 Million Boost for Democrats in North Carolina
description: The party is banking on abortion access as an issue to animate the state’s competitive race for governor and, they hope, galvanize voters for President Biden.
text: Aiming to bring the national fight over abortion access to a key battleground state, a political arm of Planned Parenthood will spend $10 million on organizing efforts in North Carolina this year, its largest-ever investment in a single state.

title: Italy’s New Abortion Law Is a Lesson in How Meloni Governs
description: The measure, largely restating existing law, shows the prime minister’s skill at reassuring her right-wing base without sacrificing her increasingly mainstream image.
authors: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Jason Horowitz
text: At a family counseling center in Verbania, a leafy lakefront town in northern Italy, employees not only explain to women the rules for getting abortions, they have also distributed leaflets supplied by a local anti-abortion group.

title: Biden Says Trump Is Responsible for ‘Nightmare’ State Abortion Laws
description: President Biden tied a six-week abortion ban that will soon take place in Florida to former President Donald J. Trump and Republican efforts to ban abortion nationwide.
text: President Biden tied a six-week abortion ban that will soon take place in Florida to former President Donald J. Trump and Republican efforts to ban abortion nationwide.

title: Two Lawsuits, in Texas and Idaho, Highlight Fight Over Emergency Medicine Law
description: Federal trial judges in Texas and Idaho came to opposite conclusions in a battle between conservative states and the U.S. government over limits on abortion access.
text: In the weeks after the Supreme Court dismantled a constitutional right to abortion in 2022 and returned the issue of access to the states, a new series of court battles began.

title: Supreme Court Appears Sharply Divided in Emergency Abortion Case
description: The justices weighed whether a federal law aimed at protecting access to emergency medical care superseded Idaho’s near-total abortion ban.
text: The Supreme Court appeared sharply divided on Wednesday over whether federal law should allow doctors to perform emergency abortions in states with near-total bans on the procedure, in a case that could determine access to abortion in emergency rooms across the country.

title: Arizona House Votes to Repeal 1864 Abortion Law
description: The almost-complete ban on abortions in the state could go into effect as soon as June 8 if the State Legislature does not repeal it, the state’s attorney general said.
authors: By Jack Healy, Elizabeth Dias and Kellen Browning
text: Arizona took a major step on Wednesday toward scrapping an 1864 law banning abortion, when three Republican lawmakers in the state House of Representatives broke ranks with their party and voted with Democrats to repeal the ban.

title: ‘Unborn Child’ or ‘Fetus’: Parsing Word Choices on Abortion at the Supreme Court
description: The word choice is not merely a question of semantics but gets to the heart of the ultimate goal of the anti-abortion movement: fetal personhood, and prohibiting abortion entirely.
text: On its face, the case argued before the Supreme Court on Wednesday was about whether doctors in Idaho have the obligation to provide abortions to women facing emergency risks to their lives.

title: 5 Takeaways From the Supreme Court Arguments on Idaho’s Abortion Ban
description: The court’s ruling could extend to at least half a dozen other states that have similarly restrictive bans, and the implications of the case could stretch beyond abortion.
text: The abortion case before the Supreme Court on Wednesday featured vigorous questioning and comments, particularly by the three liberal justices. At issue is whether Idaho’s near-total ban on abortion is so strict that it violates a federal law requiring emergency care for any patient, including providing abortions for pregnant women in dire situations.

title: Justices Seemed Split on Emergency Abortion Access
description: Also, U.S. weapons are headed to Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
text: Supreme Court justices appeared sharply divided today over whether federal law should allow doctors to perform emergency abortions in states that have adopted near-total bans on the procedure.

title: The Looming Decision That Could Get Pro-Choice Voters to the Polls
description: A ruling in the emergency abortion case heard at the high court on Wednesday could turn out abortion rights supporters to the polls.
text: If you had asked me at the start of this Supreme Court term what the blockbuster abortion case would be, I would have focused on the one that could limit access to mifepristone, a drug used in a majority of U.S. abortions. But oral arguments last month suggested strongly that the justices might not even think that case has standing — which is to say, that decision is likely not to make much of a difference.

title: The Teen Trend of Sexual Choking
description: Responses to an essay about risks of choking during sex. Also: Abortion and the Supreme Court; Columbia unrest; hiring discrimination; Trump’s “fake news.”
text: To the Editor:

title: Arizona Republicans Who Supported Repealing an Abortion Ban Face Blowback
description: On social media, Arizona lawmakers are accused of being baby killers, cowards and traitors.
text: State Representative Matt Gress, a Republican in a moderate slice of Phoenix, was in line at his neighborhood coffee shop on Thursday when a customer stopped and thanked him for voting to repeal an 1864 law that bans abortion in Arizona.

title: Florida Abortion Ban to Take Effect, Cutting Off Major Access Point
description: The state has dozens of clinics that serve tens of thousands of women a year, including from across the Southeast. The six-week ban will require most to travel much farther.
text: Florida has long played a significant role in the American abortion landscape, with dozens of clinics providing the procedure to tens of thousands of residents a year while also taking in patients from across the Southeast.

title: With Abortion and the Border, Arizona Becomes a 2024 Political Hothouse
description: A battle over abortion bans and criminal charges against allies of former President Donald J. Trump continue to raise the state’s election-year profile.
authors: By Jack Healy, Kellen Browning and Michael Wines
text: To see the battle lines over Arizona’s political future, head to a patch of dirt along the Carefree Highway on the edge of Phoenix, where the state’s big ambitions and bitter grievances are separated by a wire fence.

title: Amid Cases on Abortion and Trump, Roberts Reflects on Supreme Court’s Work
description: Oral arguments serve a crucial role at the Supreme Court, Chief Justice John Roberts said last week at Georgetown University. But they are not always what they seem.
text: Just hours after the Supreme Court heard arguments last week in an important abortion case and the day before it considered whether former President Donald J. Trump must face trial on charges that he plotted to subvert the 2020 election, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. took a break to share some timely reflections on the role of oral arguments in the court’s work.

title: The Campus Protests: Voices From Columbia, Barnard and Beyond
description: Sampling the outpouring of responses to the continuing protests on college campuses. Also: The Trump criminal cases; Trump, Pence and abortion.
text: To the Editor:

title: The First Six Weeks of Pregnancy, Explained
description: Florida is set to ban abortions after six weeks. Experts explain how that can often be before a woman knows she is pregnant.
text: By the time a woman is considered six weeks pregnant, she would have had two weeks, at most, to realize it.

title: How Michigan Ended Minority Rule
description: Though the notion would have been laughable a decade ago, Michigan is one promising national model for how state-level activists can retake power.
text: On April 8, one day before the Arizona Supreme Court reinstated a ban on abortion from 1864, Donald Trump said the issue of abortion rights should be left to the states and “whatever they decide must be the law of the land.”

title: Inside an Abortion Clinic Days Before Florida’s Six-Week Ban Takes Effect
description: On one of the last days it would be legal to get an abortion until 15 weeks of pregnancy in Florida, a clinic in Fort Pierce was completely booked.
text: The sky was still dark outside the clinic, but two women were already sitting quietly in the small, beige waiting room while Candace Dye and her staff prepared for an extremely busy morning. It was a few minutes past 5 a.m. on one of the last days it would be legal to get an abortion until 15 weeks of pregnancy in Florida, and A Woman’s World Medical Center in Fort Pierce was completely booked.

title: Trump Again Vows Mass Deportations and Won’t Rule Out Political Violence
description: In an interview with Time magazine, the former president said he planned to use the military to deport migrants and would not dismiss the possibility of political violence after this year’s election.
text: Former President Donald J. Trump told Time magazine in an interview published Tuesday morning that if elected in November, he would deploy the U.S. military to detain and deport migrants, hedged on the possibility of political violence after the 2024 election and said he would permit states to decide whether to prosecute those who violate abortion bans.

title: Florida’s Six-Week Abortion Ban Is Now Law, With Political Implications
description: The ban, which took effect on Wednesday, was part of Gov. Ron DeSantis’s push into cultural conservatism. But Florida politics is rarely that simple.
text: As Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida prepared to run for president last spring, he gathered anti-abortion activists in his Capitol office for an unusual bill signing, held late at night and behind closed doors.

title: Arizona Lawmakers Repeal 1864 Abortion Ban, Creating Rift on the Right
description: Two Republican state senators broke with their party to ensure final passage of the repeal. Gov. Katie Hobbs, a Democrat, is expected to sign it on Thursday.
authors: By Jack Healy and Elizabeth Dias
text: Arizona lawmakers voted on Wednesday to repeal an abortion ban that first became law when Abraham Lincoln was president and a half-century before women won the right to vote.

title: Florida’s Abortion Ban Will Reach Well Beyond Florida
description: Seven hundred miles to the nearest clinic: how one ban will reshape access in the South.
authors: By Josh Katz, Margot Sanger-Katz and Claire Cain Miller
text: Seven hundred miles to the nearest clinic: how one ban will reshape access in the South.

title: The New Abortion Fight Before the Supreme Court
description: The Biden administration is arguing that Idaho’s near-total abortion ban violates a federal law on emergency treatment.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Pam Belluck, Abbie VanSickle, Stella Tan, Alex Stern, Jessica Cheung, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
text: As the presidential race moves into high gear, abortion is at the center of it. Republican-controlled states continue to impose new bans, including just this week in Florida.

title: Florida Abortion Ban Takes Effect, and U.C.L.A. Calls in Police
description: Plus, a possible shift on marijuana policy.
authors: By Tracy Mumford, Patricia Mazzei, Jonah E. Bromwich, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
text: On Today’s Episode:

title: From Florida to Arizona, Abortion Politics Dominate the 2024 Race
description: As a six-week ban takes effect in Florida, and Arizona legislators repealed their 1864 law restricting the procedure, Democrats hope the issue will help carry them through a tough political environment.
text: In Florida, a ban on most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy took effect.

title: Harris Blasts Trump Over Florida Abortion Ban
description: On the day that Florida began to enforce its six-week abortion ban, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a searing attack on former President Donald J. Trump in Jacksonville, Fla., calling the measure “another Trump abortion ban.”
text: On the day that Florida began to enforce its six-week abortion ban, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a searing attack on former President Donald J. Trump in Jacksonville, Fla., calling the measure “another Trump abortion ban.”

title: In Florida, Harris Looks to Make Trump the Face of the State’s Abortion Ban
description: The vice president sought to tie former President Donald J. Trump to the state’s six-week abortion ban, which took effect on Wednesday.
text: On the day that Florida began to enforce its six-week abortion ban, Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a searing attack on former President Donald J. Trump in Jacksonville, calling the measure “another Trump abortion ban” and saying he was forcing women to live a “horrific reality” without access to essential medical care.

title: Arizona Voted to Repeal Its Abortion Ban
description: Also, the Fed eyes a longer period of high rates. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
text: Arizona lawmakers today repealed an abortion ban that first became law in 1864, when Abraham Lincoln was president and a half-century before women won the right to vote.

title: How Six-Week Abortion Bans Went From Fringe to Reality
description: Even opponents of abortion saw such curbs as too controversial just over a decade ago. Times have changed.
text: Just over a decade ago, six-week abortion bans were seen as too radical even by many members of the anti-abortion movement, who worried they carried too much political and legal risk.

title: How Technology Has Outpaced the Law
description: Abortions in the U.S. have risen slightly since Roe was struck down. One factor: pills ordered online.
text: After the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade, red states raced to restrict abortion, as Florida did yesterday with a new ban after six weeks of pregnancy. It was reasonable to expect the number of abortions in the U.S. to decline. Instead, it appears to have risen slightly. Why? One factor is pills prescribed online, which now make up one in six abortions.

title: Why Yes-or-No Questions on Abortion Rights Could Be a Key to 2024
description: In states that will help decide control of the White House and Congress, Democrats are campaigning furiously alongside ballot measures to protect abortion rights, putting Republicans on their heels.
authors: By Nick Corasaniti and Nicholas Nehamas
text: As Democrats confront a presidential race against a resurgent and resilient Donald J. Trump as well as a brutally challenging Senate map, they believe they have an increasingly powerful political weapon: ballot measures to protect abortion rights.

title: MAGA Is Demoting the Anti-Abortion Forces It Once Coddled
description: Swing-state Republicans are running from the anti-abortion movement.
text: Kari Lake’s appearance at Arizona State University last week was billed as a town hall, but it wasn’t really, because only representatives of young conservative groups were permitted to ask her anything.

title: Missouri and South Dakota Move Toward Abortion Rights Ballot Questions
description: Both states are reliably Republican and have abortion bans that are among the strictest in the nation.
text: Two more states with near-total abortion bans are poised to have citizen-sponsored measures on the ballot this year that would allow voters to reverse those bans by establishing a right to abortion in their state constitutions.

title: The Deep, Tangled Roots of American Illiberalism
description: Our biggest mistake would be to believe that Trumpism is a historical exception.
text: In a recent interview with Time, Donald Trump promised a second term of authoritarian power grabs, administrative cronyism, mass deportations of the undocumented, harassment of women over abortion, trade wars and vengeance brought upon his rivals and enemies, including President Biden. “If they said that a president doesn’t get immunity,” Mr. Trump told Time, “then Biden, I am sure, will be prosecuted for all of his crimes.”

title: Democrats, Sensing Shift on Abortion Rights Among Latinas, Push for More Gains
description: Hispanic views on the issue vary widely, and Democrats face hurdles, but opportunities, too. As one House candidate said: “I go to Mass, but I also support a woman’s right to choose.”
text: Hours before Arizona state legislators voted to repeal an 1864 abortion ban last month, a group of mostly Latina Democrats huddled at a nearby Mexican restaurant for a strategy session on galvanizing Latina voters over abortion rights.

title: A Judge’s Dilemma: How to Punish Trump for Gag Order Violations
description: Readers discuss Justice Juan Merchan’s options. Also: If there’s a Trump conviction; TikTok and China; abortion exceptions; saving the bees.
text: To the Editor:

title: Anti-Abortion Activist Who Led Blockade of Clinic Gets Nearly 5 Years in Prison
description: Lauren Handy, who drew widespread attention after human fetal remains were found at her home, was sentenced to 57 months in prison for her role in a 2020 blockade of a reproductive health clinic.
text: An anti-abortion activist who led a blockade of a reproductive health clinic in Washington, D.C., in 2020 and drew widespread attention after the authorities found human fetuses at her home was sentenced on Tuesday to nearly five years in prison.

title: 17% of Voters Blame Biden for the End of Roe
description: The mistaken belief, in a new poll, shows how even as abortion is mobilizing Democrats, confusion over the issue is also a challenge.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller, Ruth Igielnik and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: Nearly one in five voters in battleground states says that President Biden is responsible for ending the constitutional right to abortion, a new poll found, despite the fact that he supports abortion rights and that his opponent Donald J. Trump appointed three Supreme Court justices who made it possible to overturn Roe v. Wade.

title: Hogan Backs Codifying Roe, Tacking Left on Abortion Ahead of a Tough Race
description: The former two-term Republican governor, who vetoed legislation in Maryland to expand abortion access, called himself “pro-choice” in an interview and said he would back a federal law to ensure access to the procedure.
text: Larry Hogan, the former two-term Republican governor of Maryland who this week won his party’s nomination for the state’s open Senate seat, said in an interview on Thursday that he supports legislation to codify abortion rights in federal law, describing himself as “pro-choice” in a remarkable pivot as he heads into a highly competitive race.

title: Is There a Constitutional Right to Talk About Abortion?
description: The First Amendment looms large in lower court cases that may find their way to the Supreme Court.
text: There has hardly ever been as fierce a defender of free speech as the current Supreme Court.

title: Conservative Family Scion Sentenced to Nearly 4 Years for Jan. 6 Attack
description: Leo Brent Bozell, the son and grandson of influential right-wing figures, shattered a windowpane in the Capitol, pursued a police officer and made his way into the speaker’s office during the pro-Trump riot.
authors: By Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
text: For most of his life, Leo Brent Bozell IV has been known as the devout, but somewhat troubled, scion of a famous conservative family — the son of L. Brent Bozell III, a culture warrior and longtime critic of the media, and the grandson of L. Brent Bozell Jr., a fierce anti-Communist and one of the early architects of the anti-abortion movement.

title: The Good News for Biden in Our Battleground Polls
description: An enduring group of voters prioritizes abortion over all other issues.
text: It’s the weekend! Tonight, we’re looking at a bright spot for Biden in our battleground polls — and, inspired by a certain Supreme Court justice, we want to hear your stories of political spats with your neighbors.

title: Why the Equal Rights Amendment Is Again a Hot Topic in New York
description: The proposed amendment to the State Constitution has become a divisive culture-war issue that encompasses abortion, discrimination and transgender athletes.
authors: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
text: The former congressman rocked back and forth, his face turning red as he jabbed his finger in the air. It had been 18 months since Lee Zeldin lost his bid to become governor of New York, and now he was back at a rally in Albany, with a new war to fight.

title: Ruben Gallego and the Fight for Arizona
description: The Grand Canyon State is up for grabs — and so is its political future.
text: Arizona has become an epicenter of political discord and conflict over issues that have roiled the national discourse. In the fall, the outrage over an abortion ban from 1864 and a potential ballot initiative on the issue are likely to motivate Democrats, and the outrage over chaos at the border is likely to motivate Republicans.

title: Georgia Supreme Court Justice Fends Off Challenger Who Made Abortion Rights a Focus
description: Justice Andrew Pinson, who was appointed by the state’s Republican governor, faced an opponent who argued that the Georgia Constitution guaranteed the right to an abortion.
text: The incumbent in the lone competitive race for a seat on the Georgia Supreme Court won re-election on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, fending off a challenge from a former Democratic congressman who had built his campaign in the nonpartisan contest on protecting abortion rights.

title: Democrats See Wins in Losing Votes
description: The party is pursuing a “sword and shield” political strategy as Senator Chuck Schumer pushes showdown votes on border security and abortion rights ahead of this year’s elections.
text: In losing big votes, Senator Chuck Schumer, the New York Democrat and majority leader, believes his party stands to win.

title: Abortion Pills May Become Controlled Substances in Louisiana
description: A bill that is expected to pass would impose prison time and thousands of dollars in fines on people possessing the pills without a prescription.
authors: By Pam Belluck and Emily Cochrane
text: Louisiana could become the first state to classify abortion pills as dangerous controlled substances, making possession of the pills without a prescription a crime subject to jail time and fines.

title: Louisiana Lawmakers Vote to Make Abortion Pills Controlled Substances
description: The legislation would make possession of the drugs without a prescription a crime in Louisiana, punishable with jail time.
authors: By Emily Cochrane and Pam Belluck
text: Louisiana lawmakers passed legislation on Thursday to make the state the first in the nation to designate abortion pills as dangerous controlled substances. Possession of the drugs without a prescription would be a crime punishable with jail time and thousands of dollars in fines.

title: This Is the Democrats’ Best Shot in 2024. And They Are Spending Like Crazy on It.
description: Democrats have continued to leverage abortion rights as a powerful culture-war wedge issue against Republicans, seen in their ad campaigns.
authors: By Lakshya Jain and Harrison Lavelle
text: Democrats have continued to leverage abortion rights as a powerful culture-war wedge issue against Republicans, seen in their ad campaigns.

title: Hillary Clinton Has Some Tough Words for Democrats, and for Women
description: In an interview for a forthcoming book, Mrs. Clinton also suggested that if Donald Trump won in November “we may never have another actual election.”
authors: By Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias
text: Hillary Clinton criticized her fellow Democrats over what she described as a decades-in-the-making failure to protect abortion rights, saying in her first extended interview about the fall of Roe v. Wade that her party underestimated the growing strength of anti-abortion forces until many Democrats were improbably “taken by surprise” by the landmark Dobbs decision in 2022.

title: The Unlikely Women Fighting for Abortion Rights
description: The end of Roe has turned women who terminated pregnancies for medical reasons into a political force.
text: For a long time, many women who had abortions because of catastrophic fetal diagnoses told their stories only privately. Grieving pregnancies they dearly wanted and fearing the stigma of abortion, they sought the closely guarded comfort of online communities identified by the way many doctors had described the procedure — TFMR, or “termination for medical reasons.”

title: Eyeing Trump, but on the Fence: How Tuned-Out Voters Could Decide 2024
description: Politically disengaged Americans are increasingly Trump-curious, but President Biden has a shot at winning some of them back. Reaching them in a changed media environment will be his challenge.
authors: By Katie Glueck and Nick Corasaniti
text: Joe Perez is exactly the type of voter President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump are fighting over: A 22-year-old Hispanic man in Las Vegas who grew up leaning Republican, he also supports abortion rights and was turned off by the Capitol rioters on Jan. 6, 2021.

title: Melinda French Gates: The Enemies of Progress Play Offense. I Want to Help Even the Match.
description: A philanthropist is focusing on gender issues around the world, including abortion access in the United States.
text: Many years ago, I received this piece of advice: “Set your own agenda, or someone else will set it for you.” I’ve carried those words with me ever since.

title: The Untold Story of the Network That Took Down Roe v. Wade
description: A conservative Christian coalition’s plan to end the federal right to abortion began just days after Trump’s 2016 election.
authors: By Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer
text: It happened almost by accident, over cocktails. Exactly the kind of accident that Leonard Leo intended to happen at his Federalist Society’s annual conference — a three-day gathering of the conservative tribe and a strategy session for right-wing lawyers, officials and judges that drew both big names and those who had lower profiles but were no less ambitious.

title: In Florida, Democrats Hope Abortion Will Revive Their Fortunes
description: They may not win the state in the Electoral College, but Democrats may improve their chances in the statehouse.
authors: By Mara Gay and Damon Winter
text: On the Miami River recently, a parade of gleaming white pleasure boats cruised through the city. Half-naked revelers basked on their decks, swaying to Taylor Swift anthems and waving bottles of champagne as they floated by.

title: How Republicans in Key Senate Races Are Flip-Flopping on Abortion
description: Several G.O.P. Senate candidates used to embrace anti-abortion views. Now they are shifting their positions on an issue that has become an electoral liability for their party.
authors: By Jess Bidgood and Lisa Lerer
text: Republican candidates in all eight of the country’s most competitive Senate races have changed their approach on the issue of abortion, softening their rhetoric, shifting their positions and, in at least one case, embracing policies championed by Democrats.

title: Top Minnesota Democrats Call on State Senator Charged With Burglary to Resign
description: A Democratic state lawmaker was charged with burglary in April. Her fate could threaten a slim majority Democrats have in the Minnesota Senate.
text: After Minnesota Democrats took control of the State Legislature and the governor’s mansion in 2022, they passed a trove of legislation, including measures legalizing marijuana and expanding abortion rights, with the help of a mere one-seat majority in the Senate.

title: Hopeful Yet Cautious, Biden’s Team Aims to Exploit Trump’s Conviction
description: The verdict in Manhattan gave the president and his allies a new way to frame the race: a choice between someone who is a felon and someone who is not.
authors: By Reid J. Epstein and Nicholas Nehamas
text: For more than a year, President Biden has sought to cast the 2024 election not as a referendum on his four years in office but on whether voters want to return Donald J. Trump to office after a first term in which he undermined abortion rights, democracy and the rule of law.

title: Trump Pledged Support to an Organization That Wants Abortion ‘Eradicated Entirely’
description: The group, known as the Danbury Institute, opposes abortion in all cases and has asserted that life begins at the moment of fertilization.
text: Former President Donald J. Trump promised on Monday to join forces with the leaders of the Danbury Institute, a Christian coalition of churches, organizations and conservative activists that wants abortion “eradicated entirely” in the United States.

title: Abortion Groups Say Tech Companies Suppress Posts and Accounts
description: The groups say they are increasingly confused and frustrated by how major technology platforms moderate posts about abortion services.
authors: By Emily Schmall and Sapna Maheshwari
text: TikTok has briefly suspended the account of Hey Jane, a prominent telemedicine abortion service, four times without explanation. Instagram has suspended Mayday Health, a nonprofit that provides information about abortion pill access, without explanation as well. And the search engine Bing has erroneously flagged the website for Aid Access, a major seller of abortion pills online, as unsafe.

title: My Son’s Ex-Girlfriend Wants to Keep Her Pregnancy. Is That Unfair to Him?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether a co-parent’s wishes should matter to a pregnant woman.
text: I’ve always supported a woman’s right to choose, not least because legal access to abortion once saved me from an untenable situation. I also believe that if a woman chooses to abort, her wish should supersede any opposition to it by the father. The physical, practical and emotional effects on a woman obliged to carry a child to term (and to care for it afterward) are, in my view, far more significant than they are for the father.

title: Southern Baptists Vote to Oppose Use of I.V.F.
description: With almost 13 million church members across the United States, the Southern Baptist Convention has long been a bellwether for American evangelicalism.
text: Southern Baptists, the country’s largest Protestant denomination, voted on Wednesday to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization. The vote was an indication that evangelicals are increasingly open to arguments that equate embryos with human life, and that two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade, “fetal personhood” may be the next front for the anti-abortion movement.

title: How Conservatives Plotted Roe’s Downfall for Years, in Plain Sight
description: In “The Fall of Roe,” Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer explain exactly how Roe v. Wade was made — and unmade.
text: In 2020, a writer at the feminist website Jezebel pitched an article on abortion pills. Her editor liked the idea, but knew what those of us who have tried to write about reproductive access had long internalized: The piece would not do well.

title: 171,000 Traveled for Abortions Last Year. See Where They Went.
description: Out-of-state trips for abortions more than doubled in 2023, demonstrating the upheaval in access since the overturn of Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Molly Cook Escobar, Amy Schoenfeld Walker, Allison McCann, Scott Reinhard and Helmuth Rosales
text: Out-of-state trips for abortions more than doubled in 2023, demonstrating the upheaval in access since the overturn of Roe v. Wade.

title: Maybe It All Comes Down to Abortion
description: In the battleground state of Arizona, Democrats hope that anger over Dobbs and state-level restrictions will send people to the polls and keep Biden in the White House.
authors: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Anna Foley
text: Arizona is a battleground state that both parties are desperate to win in November.

title: Weakened G7 Takes On an Unruly World, and Mapping Abortion Travel
description: Plus, a scramble to shrink student loan bills.
authors: By Tracy Mumford, Mark Landler, Ruth Maclean, Davis Land and Jessica Metzger
text: On Today’s Episode:

title: What is mifepristone and how is it used?
description: More than half of people who get legal abortions in the United States — and three-quarters in Europe — use medication abortion.
authors: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
text: Mifepristone is one of two drugs used in a medication abortion. It is combined with a second drug, misoprostol, to end a pregnancy.

title: Read the Court’s Decision to Uphold Access to Abortion Pill
description: The Supreme Court upheld access to a widely available abortion pill, rejecting a bid from a group of anti-abortion organizations and doctors to unravel the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the pill.
text: The Supreme Court upheld access to a widely available abortion pill, rejecting a bid from a group of anti-abortion organizations and doctors to unravel the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the pill.

title: Telehealth Abortions, Protected by Court for Now, Are Growing Rapidly
description: One-fifth of abortions are being done via telemedicine, nearly half in states with abortion bans or restrictions.
authors: By Margot Sanger-Katz and Claire Cain Miller
text: The Supreme Court, for now, has protected telehealth abortion, which accounts for a substantial and growing share of abortions in the United States.

title: Abortion Ruling Has Nothing to Do With the Pills’ Safety or Morality
description: The opinion in the case focused entirely on standing, the legal doctrine that requires plaintiffs to show that they have suffered direct and concrete injuries in order to sue.
text: The Supreme Court’s unanimous decision ensuring access to an abortion pill took no position on its safety or morality. Instead, Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh, writing for the court, focused entirely on standing. That is the legal doctrine that requires plaintiffs to show that they have suffered direct and concrete injuries in order to sue.

title: Abortion Pill Ruling May Help Republicans Minimize a Political Disadvantage
description: A ruling limiting access to a widely available abortion pill would have given Democrats another way to hammer their opponents on an issue that’s become politically damaging for Republican politicians.
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to uphold access to a widely available abortion pill frustrated antiabortion activists. But it allowed Republicans to dodge a potentially toxic issue in the midst of a tight presidential race.

title: The Abortion Pill Fight Is Not Over. Here’s What’s Next.
description: Though the Supreme Court ruled upheld access to mifepristone, the case is likely to be revived by three Republican-led states as the plaintiffs.
text: The Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday to dismissing one effort to curtail access to abortion pills did not eliminate the possibility that other plaintiffs would continue to mount challenges to the medication that is used in a majority of abortions in the country.

title: Anti-Abortion Activists Press Ahead After Supreme Court Ruling
description: The activists were disappointed but planned to adapt strategies after the Supreme Court upheld access to a widely available abortion pill.
text: Anti-abortion stalwarts expressed widespread disappointment over the Supreme Court’s decision to uphold access to a widely available abortion pill, even as they vowed that their fight was far from over.

title: Abortion Rights Groups Celebrate Win but See Risks Ahead
description: Supporters of abortion rights hailed the ruling on a challenge they said was fueled by junk science, but warned that it only maintained the status quo as more challenges loomed.
text: Medical groups and supporters of abortion rights hailed the Supreme Court’s rejection of the challenge to medication abortion, but with a heavy dose of caution.

title: The Abortion Pill Stays Legal. But for How Long?
description: A ruling on technical grounds means a widely used drug will soon come under attack again.
text: Rarely has a straightforward 9-to-0 decision at the Supreme Court felt as unsettling as it did on Thursday.

title: Supreme Court Maintains Broad Access to Abortion Pill
description: The decision does not eliminate efforts to restrict the availability of the pill.
text: The Supreme Court on Thursday maintained access to a widely available abortion pill, rejecting a bid from a group of anti-abortion organizations and doctors to undo the Food and Drug Administration’s approval of the drug.

title: The Supreme Court Upheld Broad Abortion Pill Access
description: Also, G7 leaders agreed to lend Ukraine $50 billion. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
text: In a unanimous decision today, the Supreme Court rejected an effort to sharply curtail access to mifepristone, a medication used in a majority of abortions in the U.S.

title: House G.O.P. Pushes Through Defense Bill Nixing Abortion Access Policy
description: The annual defense policy legislation emerged from a House committee with bipartisan backing, but Republicans loaded it with right-wing mandates targeting abortion, transgender care and diversity initiatives.
text: House Republicans banded together on Friday to narrowly pass an $895 billion defense policy bill that would restrict access to abortion and transgender medical care in the military and eliminate all positions and offices of diversity, equity and inclusion across the Pentagon.

title: A Tense Debate Erupts at the G7, This Time Over Abortion Rights
description: Wording in the summit’s final statement led to a diplomatic tug of war, primarily between the United States and Italy.
authors: By Erica L. Green and Emma Bubola
text: The leaders of the G7 had plenty to discuss — and disagree about — at their annual meeting in Italy. Two major wars, in Gaza and Ukraine. One hefty loan for Ukraine. They navigated those.

title: One Week That Revealed the Struggles of the Anti-Abortion Movement
description: The movement looks for a path forward: “Is the goal the absolute abolition of abortion in our nation?”
text: The Southern Baptist Convention voted to condemn in vitro fertilization at its annual meeting in Indianapolis this week, over the objections of some members.

title: Biden’s Health Secretary Goes West With a Focus on Reproductive Rights
description: Xavier Becerra, the health and human services secretary, will travel to states with large Latino populations, including some with key races on the ballot in November.
text: Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, said on Friday that he would begin a national tour next week to promote the Biden administration’s efforts to preserve and expand access to abortion.

title: The Resistance to a New Trump Administration Has Already Started
description: An emerging coalition that views Donald J. Trump’s agenda as a threat to democracy is laying the groundwork to push back if he wins in November, taking extraordinary pre-emptive actions.
authors: By Charlie Savage, Reid J. Epstein, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
text: Opponents of Donald J. Trump are drafting potential lawsuits in case he is elected in November and carries out mass deportations, as he has vowed. One group has hired a new auditor to withstand any attempt by a second Trump administration to unleash the Internal Revenue Service against them. Democratic-run state governments are even stockpiling abortion medication.

title: Abortion United Evangelicals and Republicans. Now That Alliance Is Fraying.
description: The Southern Baptist Convention, long a bellwether for American evangelicalism, voted to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization.
authors: By Sabrina Tavernise, Ruth Graham, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Stella Tan, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rachelle Bonja, Marc Georges, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
text: The Southern Baptist Convention, the largest denomination of Protestant Christians in the United States, voted at an annual gathering last week to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization.

title: Contractions
description: In Memphis, a doctor and a volunteer driver contemplate the discontinuation of abortion services at a women’s health clinic two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
text: In Memphis, a doctor and a volunteer driver contemplate the discontinuation of abortion services at a women’s health clinic two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

title: Tennessee Abortion Clinic Workers Speak Out About the State’s Near-Total Ban
description: In Memphis, a doctor and a volunteer driver contemplate the discontinuation of abortion services at a women’s health clinic two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
text: I remember the hollowing sensation I felt on June 24, 2022, the day that the Supreme Court deemed that abortion was not a protected right under the U.S. Constitution. Everyone — on both sides of this debate — knew that women’s lives across the country were going to be drastically transformed. Since then, a lot of attention has been paid to the most heart-wrenching cases, but this decision affects all women’s bodily autonomy across the country.

title: What Republicans Lost When They Won on Roe
description: In Arizona, the G.O.P. is divided over the future of opposing abortion.
authors: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe and Elisa Gutierrez
text: For decades, the mainstream Republican position on abortion rights was clear: Overturn Roe v. Wade and send the issue back to the states.

title: Biden’s Lead With Women Is Smaller Than Trump’s With Men, a Warning for Democrats
description: A new poll of female voters finds that concerns about inflation are still paramount, even as abortion could motivate Democratic women in states where the issue is on the ballot.
text: Almost every path to victory for President Biden relies on strong support from women. But his current standing among women is the weakest lead a Democrat has had since 2004, a key factor in how tight the race is.

title: Trump’s Allies Say They’ll Enforce the Comstock Act. Believe Them.
description: Democrats should rally around a bill to overhaul the 1873 anti-vice law.
text: Until the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022, it was hard for feminists to get Americans to take the threat of losing the constitutional right to abortion seriously. Describing Hillary Clinton’s inability, in 2016, to shake pro-choice voters out of their complacency, The New York Times’s Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias wrote, “Internal campaign polling and focus groups showed that the issue did not resonate strongly with key groups of voters, because they did not believe Roe was truly at risk.”

title: In Montana, Abortion Rights Groups Submit Signatures for Ballot Measure in November
description: The measure would affirm the right to abortion in the State Constitution. Democrats hope that it will help Senator Jon Tester in his bid for re-election.
text: A coalition of abortion rights groups in Montana announced Friday that it had submitted enough signatures to put a measure on the November ballot that would ask voters to affirm a right to reproductive freedom in the State Constitution.

title: Abortion Debate Shifts as Election Nears: ‘Now It’s About Pregnancy’
description: Two years after Roe was struck down, the conversation has focused on the complications that can come with pregnancy and fertility, helping to drive more support for abortion rights.
text: In the decades that Roe v. Wade was the law of the land, abortion rights groups tried to shore up support for it by declaring “Abortion Is Health Care.”

title: On Dobbs Anniversary, Democrats Look to Make the Court a Campaign Issue
description: An outside group supporting President Biden is embarking on a million-dollar campaign to focus voters’ attention on the makeup of the Supreme Court.
text: A Democratic-leaning group announced on Monday the beginning of a seven-figure campaign to focus voter attention on the importance of the Supreme Court in the presidential election, with a heavy emphasis on the high court’s role in issues like abortion, gun safety and voting rights.

title: In Abortion Cases, Legions of ‘Friends’ Seek to Persuade Supreme Court
description: A new study analyzed 50 years of friend-of-the-court briefs and found that abortion opponents were more relentless than their adversaries, with some reflected in the justices’ opinions.
text: When the Supreme Court decided Roe v. Wade in 1973, establishing a constitutional right to abortion, it noted that it had received 14 friend-of-the-court briefs and listed them in a snug footnote at the beginning of the decision.

title: Democrats Lean on Abortion Rights Message for Anniversary of End of Roe
description: Across the country this week, Democrats are focusing on abortion issues and emphasizing Donald Trump’s role in nominating the justices who helped overturn Roe v. Wade.
authors: By Katie Glueck and Lisa Lerer
text: Two years after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, unleashing a cascade of state-level abortion bans and prompting an angry political backlash, Democrats are marking the anniversary by highlighting the role former President Donald J. Trump played in ending the constitutional right to an abortion.

title: Biden Attacks Trump on Abortion, and an Illicit Hajj Industry
description: Plus, the soaring costs of caring for pets.
authors: By Tracy Mumford, Lisa Lerer, Ivan Nechepurenko, Katie Thomas, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
text: On Today’s Episode:

title: How Many Abortion Seekers Are Traveling to California
description: After the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and some states banned abortions altogether, many Americans began crossing state lines to get one.
text: After the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade and some states, mainly in the South, banned abortions altogether, many Americans began crossing state lines to get one.

title: Where Joe Biden and Donald Trump Stand on the Issues
description: Here’s what President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.
text: Here’s what President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.

title: Quotation of the Day: Realities of Abortion Bans Shift the Terms of the Issue
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 25, 2024.
text: “It’s profoundly personal to a majority of the public.”

title: The Four Issues Trump and Biden Will Clash Over at the Debate
description: Immigration, the economy, democracy and abortion rights: Here are the main ways each candidate is likely to slam the other at Thursday’s high-stakes confrontation.
authors: By Nicholas Nehamas and Michael Gold
text: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have sparred for months on the campaign trail, in interviews with reporters and through paid advertisements, creating phantom likenesses of each other to thrash and tear down.

title: In Texas, Infant Mortality Rose After Abortion Ban
description: Deaths of infants in the state increased by 13 percent in 2022, a study found, driven by fatal birth defects.
text: New data from Texas shows a possible consequence of abortion bans: a rise in infant mortality.

title: Supreme Court Appears Poised to Allow, for Now, Emergency Abortions in Idaho
description: A document posted briefly to the court’s website suggested a majority of the justices would reinstate a lower-court ruling that paused the state’s near-total abortion ban.
text: The Supreme Court seems poised to temporarily allow emergency abortions in Idaho when a woman’s health is at risk, according to a copy of what appeared to be the opinion that showed up briefly on the court’s website on Wednesday.

title: Read the Posted Document
description: Bloomberg published a copy of an opinion that appeared briefly on the Supreme Court’s website and seemed to concern an Idaho abortion case.
text: Bloomberg published a copy of an opinion that appeared briefly on the Supreme Court’s website and seemed to concern an Idaho abortion case.

title: In South Carolina, 3 G.O.P. Women Fought an Abortion Ban. They Lost Their Races.
description: The Republican women in the group of five “Sister Senators” faced primary challenges who support a near-total ban.
text: Last year, the five self-proclaimed “Sister Senators” from South Carolina were awarded the John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage Award after they joined together across party lines to block the legislature from passing a near-total abortion ban.

title: Justices Appear to Mistakenly Reveal a Key Abortion Ruling
description: Also, a new poll on the eve of the debate. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
text: The Supreme Court seems poised to temporarily allow emergency abortions in Idaho when a woman’s health is at risk, according to a copy of what appeared to be the court’s opinion that was posted today, and then removed, from the court’s website.

title: Supreme Court Allows, for Now, Emergency Abortions in Idaho
description: A majority of the justices voted to dismiss the case, reinstating a lower-court ruling that paused the state’s near-total abortion ban. The ruling mirrored a version inadvertently posted a day earlier.
text: The Supreme Court said on Thursday that it would dismiss a case about emergency abortions in Idaho, temporarily clearing the way for women in the state to receive an abortion when their health is at risk.

title: Fact-Checking Biden’s and Trump’s Claims on Domestic Policy
description: We scrutinized the presidential candidates’ recent claims on abortion, health care, crime and climate change ahead of the debate.
text: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump will face off Thursday night for the first time in four years, giving each ample opportunity to fling accusations about the other’s positions. Some will hew close to the facts, but there will most likely be ample exaggeration or statements lacking adequate nuance.

title: Supreme Court’s Abortion Rulings May Set the Stage for More Restrictions
description: The court’s strategy of avoidance and delay cannot last and may have been shaped by a desire to avoid controversy in an election year.
text: Superficially, abortion rights had a good run at the Supreme Court this term. Two weeks ago, the justices unanimously let an abortion pill remain widely available. On Thursday, the court dismissed a case about Idaho’s strict abortion ban, which had the effect of letting emergency rooms in the state perform the procedure when the patient’s health is at risk.

title: Iowa Supreme Court Allows Six-Week Abortion Ban to Take Effect
description: Republican lawmakers passed the restrictions last year, but a lower court blocked enforcement of the law.
text: The Iowa Supreme Court ruled on Friday that the state’s six-week abortion ban could be enforced, a decision that sharply limits access to the procedure and fulfills a longstanding aim of the state’s Republican leaders.

title: Read the document: What the Iowa Supreme Court said
description: The Iowa Supreme Court ruled that the state’s six-week abortion ban could be enforced. Read its ruling here.
text: The Iowa Supreme Court ruled that the state’s six-week abortion ban could be enforced. Read its ruling here.

title: Social Conservatives Push Trump on the G.O.P.’s Anti-Abortion Platform
description: Leaders of the anti-abortion movement sent a letter to Donald J. Trump amid worries he may try to weaken the anti-abortion language in the party platform.
authors: By Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Swan
text: A group of some of the most powerful social conservatives in the country, fearful that Donald J. Trump may push to water down the Republican Party’s official position on abortion, sent a pointed letter to the former president this month imploring him to keep strong anti-abortion language in the party platform.

title: Conservative Christian Activists See Opportunity in Supreme Court Ruling
description: The decision overturning a precedent known as Chevron deference was celebrated by those who would target medication abortion and rights for transgender people.
text: Conservative Christian activists and lawyers are celebrating the Chevron decision as a significant win for their ambitions to target medication abortion and rights for transgender people.

title: House G.O.P. Begins Push on Hard-Right Spending Bills, Teeing Up Future Battles
description: The Republican-led House loaded its funding measures with provisions that have no chance of becoming law, as both parties look toward a bigger fight later this year, most likely after the elections.
text: The Republican-led House voted on Friday to strip President Biden’s homeland security secretary and secretary of state of their salaries. It approved measures banning military installations from having drag queen story hours for children. And it passed legislation prohibiting paid leave for Pentagon employees who get an abortion.

title: She Needed an Emergency Abortion. Doctors in Idaho Put Her on a Plane.
description: In states that have banned abortion, hospitals have struggled to treat pregnant women facing health risks. A Supreme Court decision this week did not help.
text: Nicole Miller had gone to the emergency room in Boise, Idaho, after waking up with heavy bleeding in her 20th week of pregnancy. By afternoon, she was still leaking amniotic fluid and hemorrhaging and, now in a panic, struggling to understand why the doctor was telling her that she needed to leave the state to be treated.

title: In An Unpredictable Debate, a Tussle Over Golf Was Par for the Course
description: Bickering about their golf handicaps in Thursday’s presidential debate was panned as a petty exercise between two aging men trying vainly to outdo one another.
text: It was a surreal detour during a presidential debate already filled with peculiar exchanges and meandering remarks. On Thursday night, after squabbles about the economy, abortion and the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot, President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump tussled over … golf.

title: Quotation of the Day: For Emergency Abortion, Idaho Doctors Flew Her Away
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 30, 2024.
text: “I couldn’t comprehend: I’m standing in front of doctors who know exactly what to do and how to help and they’re refusing to do it.”

title: Abortion Rights Supporters Put a Winning Strategy to the Test in Arkansas
description: Organizers have until Friday to collect enough signatures to put abortion access on the ballot this fall in a state where conservative and evangelical values run deep.
text: In states like California, Ohio and Michigan, supporters of abortion rights have been undefeated in using ballot measures to ensure constitutional access to the procedure.

title: The Uproar Over the Immunity Ruling
description: Lawyers and other readers discuss the landmark Supreme Court decision. Also: A ruling on corruption; doctors and abortion bans; religion in public schools.
text: To the Editor:

title: A Dismissed Abortion Case Points to Internal Tensions and Dysfunction at the Supreme Court
description: The court dismisses an abortion case it now says it should never have accepted, opening a window on internal tensions.
text: Given the breathtaking sweep of the Supreme Court’s decisions in the final days of its term, it’s easy to overlook a decision that had no sweep at all because it was a decision not to decide.

title: Organizers Say Abortion Access Is Headed to the Ballot in 3 More States
description: Arkansas is the third state this week where organizers said they had collected enough support for a petition to enshrine some abortion access in the State Constitution.
text: Abortions rights supporters in three states this week said they had secured enough signatures to put measures on the November ballot that would enshrine some abortion access in their state constitutions.

title: Kansas Supreme Court Rejects Republican-Backed Abortion Regulations
description: The rulings were the latest blow for abortion opponents in Kansas, where abortion protections in the State Constitution have vexed Republicans for years.
text: The Kansas Supreme Court reaffirmed abortion protections in the state’s Constitution on Friday, striking down Republican-backed laws that banned a common second-trimester abortion procedure and created additional licensing requirements for abortion clinics.

title: Biden Campaign Ad Targets Trump on Abortion
description: After President Biden’s rocky answer on abortion at the debate, his campaign has ramped up its messaging on Donald Trump’s role in overturning Roe v. Wade and his policy stances.
text: President Biden’s campaign will release a new advertisement on Monday taking direct aim at former President Donald J. Trump’s abortion policy, arguing that he is largely responsible for the end of Roe v. Wade, according to a campaign official.

title: Following Trump’s Lead, Republicans Adopt Platform That Softens Stance on Abortion
description: The document reflects the former president’s ideological grip on his party, outlining the same nationalistic priorities that his campaign website does.
authors: By Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher and Jonathan Swan
text: Donald J. Trump told officials on Monday that he supports a new Republican Party platform, one that reflects the presumptive nominee’s new position on abortion rights and slims down policy specifics across all areas of government.

title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Is Perverting the 14th Amendment
description: There’s nothing particularly “moderate” about the new Republican platform.
text: Donald Trump pushed the Republican Party’s platform committee to change its language on abortion, and on the surface it looks like an exercise in relative moderation.

title: Statue Honoring Women and Justice Vandalized at University of Houston
description: An anti-abortion group had previously denounced Shahzia Sikander’s sculpture as “satanic.” University officials said they are investigating the attack.
text: Officials at the University of Houston said on Tuesday that a vandal attacked Shahzia Sikander’s sculpture “Witness,” beheading the work, which is a monument to women and justice installed on campus. Footage of the destruction, which occurred early Monday morning amid the harsh weather of Hurricane Beryl and power outages, was obtained by campus police, officials told the artist.

title: Trump Talks V.P. Shortlist Pros and Cons (He Likes Vance’s Beard)
description: Donald J. Trump has not generally offered explicit evaluations of his top contenders, but he acknowledged on Wednesday that Doug Burgum’s abortion ban and Marco Rubio’s Florida residency complicate his choice.
text: As the deadline for him to pick a running mate approaches, former President Donald J. Trump on Wednesday acknowledged that some of his top contenders have some factors that could complicate their being chosen.

title: Arkansas Rejects Abortion Rights Amendment Petition on Technicality
description: The Arkansas secretary of state said that the group collecting signatures to put an abortion-rights amendment on the ballot had failed to submit some of the necessary paperwork.
text: The Arkansas secretary of state on Wednesday rejected an effort to put an abortion-rights amendment on the ballot this November, saying the campaign had failed to submit some of the necessary paperwork.

title: Hispanic Male Democrats Make an Abortion-Rights Pitch to Latino Men
description: These candidates say the issue cannot be avoided in 2024, and dismiss the notion that focusing on men, who typically prioritize the economy, is a risk.
text: When he was a child, Representative Gabriel Vasquez never heard his parents discuss politics, much less abortion, a topic that was off limits in many Mexican Catholic households like his. So he can see why some might think he is taking a risk by focusing on abortion rights in campaigning to Latino men.

title: The Republicans Are Headed to Milwaukee. So Are Protesters.
description: A range of activists, energized over abortion limits, Israel’s military action in Gaza and immigration, say they plan to march in the city.
